Of course some people were dressed down, but what is the fun of going to a nice restaurant where the staff are all dressed up and dress down.  Plz, leave the jeans at home and step it up a notch fashion wise.  I saw a guy who was so dressed down with his date who was all dolled up.  Come on . . .In any event,   It was nice enough and quite enough to have a conversation.  

There is an small elevator that takes you upstairs so those who have ADA issues, you don't have to fight the stairs.
author: Vanilla C.

description: I've always been a BIG fan of the restaurant. I love the roasted crab and the garlic noodles! I would have given them 5 stars, but our waitress wasn't attenative at all. Downer but the food was great as always!
author: Michelle R.

description:
Highly overrated. Very disappointed. First of all, the infamous garlic noodles was NOT all that. Yes I said it! It's pretty much top ramen sprinkled with salt, sugar, and garlic powder so I don't know what the whole fuzz was about. The Crispy Panko Crab Cake was the biggest disappointment of the night. 2 pieces of crab cakes, 2 pieces of fried eggplants, and mixed green salad for $21.00 wow!. 

This place requires you to dress casual. For what? we're gonna have crabs!!!! Eating crabs can get messy and you want us to dress casual? And if you dont, they will make you wear they're polo shirt. Seriously, and there is no free refill. My bill said "Coke x 3" wtf

I'll give it a star for the $30+ roasted garlic crab. 

PS.
Our bill was $150+ and I was still hungry. Maybe we should've spent $250 instead
author: Thyrone A.

description:
Crustacean is an upscale Vietnamese fusion restaurant; a good place to impress a date or a client.

I came here for a large dinner party and the service was unfortunately lacking throughout the night.  However, the restaurant was spacious enough to accommodate a large party of 25.  For a party of this size, they required that we order the prix-fixe set menu, which ended up being $70/person.

The roasted crab is delicious, especially when paired with the garlic noodles, but its extremely overpriced for what it is.  You are paying for ambiance and decor, I guess.  You can for sure get food of similar quality elsewhere, but the if you want the fancy vibe for a steep price, come to Crustacean.
author: Tu-Lien N.

description:
This place is definitely tasty so go there if you have an appetite.  However, I would only drop the $35 during crab season.  Highly recommend the roasted garlic dungeness crab  with the garlic noodles.
This dish deserves a four star but I gave the 3 star ranking for the average service and the other entrees were average in taste.
author: Kae O.

description: Garlic noodles the the best. Need to clean the windows and entrance.
author: Mark I.

description: I came here for dinner on a Sunday night. It didn't seem too busy but it wasn't empty. We ordered about 3 different crabs, I forgot the names (besides tamarind) but they were all good. Garlic noodles of course, beef carpaccio (pretty basic), summer rolls, giant prawns. Overall the food was not bad or amazing, but the service sucked. We had to wave down our waiter for everything. He never checked up on us, only quickly dropped off food. I expected better service since it's considered a high end restaurant. Eh... Nothing to go nuts for, but I wouldn't bash on the food either.
author: Rosanna T.

description:
Came here tonight for Thanksgiving dinner.  I'm going to keep this short and simple.  Order the ROASTED GARLIC CRAB and the GARLIC NOODLES.  I'm sure you know that by now after reading hundreds of reviews on these two dishes.  Beware though that this will definitely give you a kick in your mouth which will linger even after brushing your teeth.  Twice.  So don't be going to Crustaceans and hauling all that garlic if you're expecting to "get some" that same night.

For appetizer, their calamari is really good.  The Ahi Tuna though was rather dry.  How the heck can Ahi Tuna be dry??

The garlic bread is so light in flavor, it'll make you wonder if they got your order right.  But they did.

I also tried the Tiger Prawns which were not as exciting.  I'd skip them.  They were dry and there were only four prawns on a bed of garlic noodles.  I'd rather go straight for the crab.  

The crab is just delicious.  It's soaked in garlic butter that screams heart attack.  I was quite amazed at how fresh the crab tasted also.  Now with the garlic noodles, don't expect it to come out with vegetables or anything mixed with it.  It looks plain but it is so flavorful.  YUM!

For dessert, we got the creme brulee and chocolate bread pudding.  Not impressed.  You really don't need to order dessert anyways after feasting on crab and noodles.
author: Linh V.

description: great food and great service , garlic crab is a must , garlic rice is BLAH , but the Garlic Noodles is FANTASTIC.  The wait was a little long but weel worth it
author: Lance K.

description:
Myself and some friends went to celebrate my sweetie's birthday and our friend's anniversary. Everyone else had already been before and had rave reviews, this was my first time. 

I must say tat the decor and the host/hostess at the front desk were very nice. I had looked at the menu on line a few days before so that I was familiar with it. I ordered the roasted crab & combo fried rice. 

The crab came out in 'lightening' speed. I thought it would be at least a 15 minute wait. Minus one star for no bib being brought before. (even though I saw other patrons get one as they were waiting)

Minus another star for the fact that the salads that were ordered came AFTER the main entrees. 

I was not OVERWHELMED with the whole experience. It was nice. I think I want to visit Thanh Long or PPQ the next time.
author: Sherri J.

description:
Best garlic noodles.  EVER.  And really, really good roasted garlic crab.

They have a "secret" section in the kitchen where only specific chefs are allowed inside.  THAT's how awesome the noodles are.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Boy has this place taken a turn for the worse. BOO!  Went here last night for our first V-day dinner. YAY! No reservations and a prix fixe menu.  We were seated right away!  SCORE!  Once we were seated, we looked around and noticed the crowd. YIKES!  I wasn't sure if we stumbled upon a rap music video in the making or if it we were being punked.  I was looking around for 2 things, a way out "just in case" or for Ashton to jump out with cameras rolling. 

Now, we're all about diversity and open to all races but there is a reason we decided on coming to a high class restaurant, we wanted a certain ambiance. We most certainly are no stuffy snotty people but come on.  Once the sweat suits, FUBU and Rockawear showed up, I bowed my head in embarrassment.  How could we come so overdressed?  :-\  Not to mention the hyphy ruckus that was going on right next to our table.  Someone (who must of been really important wearing his shades while dining) started a fight with his lucky date which they then proceeded to knock over stuff and get escorted out of the restaurant... BUT not before pulling  the infamous dine and dash.  Now THAT Is classy!  We kept our heads low and finished our meal and took the party elsewhere.  WHEW! Felt a little relieved once the boys in blue showed up and stayed for the rest of the evening to make sure things didn't  "POP OFF".

2 stars - 1(GOLDEN STAR)  for the company I was with and 1 for the food which is always delish.  

HOWEVER, Next time we want to spend $350 on dinner for 2 and a bottle of wine it will not be this place.  Sadly.  Pull it together Crustaceans!
author: Sadie K.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I love this place...well, I love the food. The atmosphere is a little too bougie for me -- If I'm gonna be gettin' down with some crab I'm gonna use my damn hands and get it all over my face...I don't want to be forced to wear a collared shirt and slacks to do it!

I'm all about nice restaurants, but there's a time and a place for everything.

For me, their sister restaurant on Judah (Thanh Long) is a lot more casual and they serve the same food so it's right on point.

If you go here, make sure you get down on the roasted crab and the garlic noodles. GARLIC NOODLES. I could eat like 20 plates of that stuff.

Oh, and it's always nice to top it off with a fried banana w/ ice cream.
author: AC M.

description:
Went here valentines day. Was told not to but was willing to give it a try.

Dislikes-The server seemed uneasy when we asked him about what was in a dessert he pointed to the table beside us. But it just looked like a cake with ice cream. For the type of restaurant this is he should've have been more verbal. 
- the place was kinda dark and oldish unclean feeling. 
- had to wait awhile to get my check
- hard to get my waiters attention maybe it was busy
-the hosts in the front were not friendly and looked like they didnt want to be there, maybe because it was Valentines day?
-the who answers the phone for reservations was not too professional

Likes-  They get two stars cuz The latino guy that cleaned our table was friendly and made me feel welcomed.
-prawns were good


I had the crab and garlic noodles. 
the roasted crab is better at ppq
the garlic noodles are better at thanh long, however i havent been there for awhile

I will prob not come here again.
author: DOM d.

description: The roasted crab is so tasty! It is a must have! The garlic noodle is awesome too! In addition to these two most popular dishes, we had a lobster salad, which is also great. Service is excellent. This is the best crab place in SF. If I can be really picky: the deco is dated, it is dark inside.
author: Emmy P.

description:
We were told to try this restaurant by the concierge at our hotel.  Great recommendation!

We started with two orders of cold sake. Great.

Appetizer - Salmon Carpaccio. Great.

I order the Pan Roast Halibut. WOW. The sauce was amazing in this dish, perfectly paired. My boyfriend ordered the Royal Tiger Prawns which came with garlic noodles - delicious! If you like garlic you will absolutely LOVE the noodles.  

Based on our entrees this place definitely deserves 5 stars.
author: Kali M.

description: Unimaginable that this place has same owners as Thanh Long in outer sunset.  Dishes here are as boring, boring, boring and Thanh Long is yum, yum, yum.....what the heck?
author: Lev E.

description:
EXPENSIVE EXPENSIVE! it was not worth the money! i can probably make better food than them! not to mention they were being really racist toward us 3 Asian girls who look fairly young.  They probably thought we didnt have enough money to pay for the bill.  Anyways, i will not come back.


PPQ is 100x better!
author: Anna W.

description:
The highlight of San Francisco dining so far.
Their crabs are butterliciously yummy. One of the best crabs I've ever had. 
The saigon beef was also flavorful and the salad was fresh.
Calamari was perfectly cooked and has a good smoky grill taste.
The snow pea was very crunchy and sweet.
The only complaint was they put us in a very tight corner, I could barely move. 
 Incredibly noteworthy meal.
author: Natasha L.

description:
Everyone else have pretty much said everything about this place. Of course, we ordered the crabs and the garlic noodles. I like the garlic crab better than the drunken one, just my preference. Our waiter was an old guy and he made no conversation whatsoever. He took our order, dropped by for refills and replaced the bowls for your shells. Good enough service, but I was expecting more for such a fancy looking place. 
I think this is a nice place to treat someone for a special occasion. It's fancy enough for a date, if you don't mind getting down and dirty with the crabs. But if you are just in the mood for crabs, I suggest PPQ. The sister company Thanh Long is also good, but I would choose to eat here rather than Thanh Long. It's more spacious here and the location is a little better than the middle of a residential neighborhood.
WARNING: the soda comes in a small little glass and there is NO FREE REFILL on the soda. The waiter kept asking my husband for another glass and we thought it was free so he said okay. Turns out, they are about $2+ per glass. We ended up paying $9+ for 3 small glasses of soda. 
The attire to this place is business/casual. But i saw a lot more casual the night we came. 
Enjoy!
author: Faith P.

description:
I have lived in the bay area since 96 and had yet to explore Crustacean.  Further, I have heard multitudes about the garlic crab and how awesome it is.  Last night I took the plunge - finally.

To start, the crab puffs were delicious - not going to help you watch your weight though.
The mixed green salad with apple, pear and tomato was suprisingly good.  The dressing was unlike any I have ever had - it had ginger, but also toasted sesame yummmy.

Since there were two of us, we got both the garlic crab and the drunken crab.  Both were delicious.  The garlic crab was a little heavier - likely more butter and the drunken was a little sweeter - likely the wine broth.  I think the better of the two is the garlic crab.  It had a deep sensual feel and flavor - much like something your mom might make for you on a cold winter night when you were a child - definitely comfort food!  And we also had the garlic noodles which are delish!

For dessert we shared the baked alaska - which is not really baked alaska - it is more of an ice cream thing with merangue on top that they torch but it was yummy anyway.

All in all it is a great spot and the raves about the crab are on the money.
author: Andy B.

description: Ok, here's the deal, you come here and this is your order:Garlic crab, Garlic noodles and your choice of red wine. It's gonna be a $100 for two people and it will be worth every penny. The people writing these reviews came here and just expected the world for some reason. They thought there should be a "dress code". There is a dress code, and it says don't look like a slob but since we are a heavily touristed(made up word) area not many restaurants actually enforce it. People dress terribly in SF anyway. So, back to the food. DELICIOUS garlic crab and garlic noodles!! Always consistent and always fullfilling! I have ordered other food and appetizers from here but they were just ok and somewhat overpriced. Yes, you can drive out to TL(Thanh Long-the mother restaurant which is cheaper) but who wants to drive  to the outer sunset? I've been there too but I swear Crustacean is better. Go there and order what I said and you will be happy, it isn't cheap but its worth the price.
author: Joshua B.

description:
I went to Crustaceans on a Date Night with 2 other couples. I had been there once before. We went on a Saturday night. We had reservations which I strongly recommend because the place can get quite busy.

A couple people ordered the whole crab. I swear, they were the  biggest crabs I've seen served in a restaurant. They looked like they were about 2 lbs, no lie.  I ordered the beef short ribs with bok choy. The short ribs melted in my mouth and it was very flavorful. All of our meals were amazing!

To top it off, each couple ordered a different dessert. We had the creme brulee, and the other couples ordered the sorbet assortment and baked Alaska.

The waiters were very friendly and familiar with how each dish is prepared. They have valet parking for $10.

If you want to go out  for a special  occasion  in SF, you should try Crustaceans. You won't be disappointed.
author: Mari I.

description:
Good BUT have you gone to Than Long on 41st and Judah.  Same family of restaurants as Crustacean.  

The super casual version of Crust/TL is PPQ on Clement & 26th.  

Roasted Garlic Crab & Garlic Noodles all day long!
author: Deanna A.

description:
Hey... what's that white stuff on my plate? On my fork? On my FOOD??

Is... that... FAT??? =O *faints*

I usually don't support eating your food fast, but here... it might be in your best interest. After I was done eating and just continued on my conversation at the table, I noticed there was this opaque layer of something covering most of the plates, silverware and leftover food. There was sooooo much fat in the food that it was now solidifying right there on the table! =O Did I really just eat that??

Other than my reminder of how much butter was in my food, the food itself was pretty tasty. Though I really could taste all the butter along with the actual flavors of the food. Me and my boy went all out while we were here and dived into the roast crab and tamarind crab. Both crabs were pretty good. Just a little messy and a little on the heavy side. Definitely not good for those on diets. We also had the Saigon Beef, which was kind of like cubed steak. It was pretty good but nothing that spectacular either. And, of course, we had to try their garlic noodles. The garlic noodles were definitely a let down. You can get them better somewhere else in Chinatown. 

This place is good to go once to, but not enough to go again. You just have to at least get a taste of the An Family secret. But if you want to get your roast crab on, there are plenty of other restaurants that can serve up some of their secret for a little bit less.
author: Daisy T.

description: OMG! Yesssss......I LOVE this place! My husband and I will be going here for our 1 year wedding anniversary next Saturday, and we both are looking forward to it! Great crab and garlic noodles. Red wine is awesome!! Service is okay, but who gets dressed up to talk to the waiters..."bring me my crab good man" is all we have to talk about!! I wish they delivered!
author: Natalie J.

description:
So I came here after yelping this place and it is NOT AS GOOD as everyone states it is. I put 1 star to just bring down the average rating, (my thoughts are probably a 2 or 3 star rating).

So I got the roasted crab, garlic noodles and calamari for appetizer. 

Calamari was pretty good but they give you a spoon full on the plate. 

The garlic noodles are SOME OF THE MOST OVERHYPED items I have ever ate. Either it was made and let sit for about and hour, it was just noodles. Nothing that stands out. 

The roasted crab was good. Not the best crab I ate but good. Taste is good but not for the $45 a crab. If you want better crab there are authentic Chinese and Vietnamese places that make 'cua rang moui' (incorrect vietnamese spelling) that are much better. In fact there is a ABC supermarket in Santa Ana that sells 'cua rang moui' crab for $1 a pound that frankly is as good as this. 

SCREW YOU YELP!
author: Peter G.

description: The garlic noodles are exceptional. And yes it does have a fishy smell to the whole dated appearing restaurant. I can see past that. But I cannot see paying over 48 dollars a piece for Dungeness crabs. Got the ones suggested on here by everyone and they were good but not excellent. I would say they were 25 dollar crabs but definitely not 48 dollar crabs. Iced tea was not good but the service was.
author: Matt S.

description:
Poe, baby - I am telling the world that you just turned 40.  I mean, really - it's not like it's much of a secret . . .

Poe and a few of her dearest friends had a birthday dinner at Crustacean - and I crashed the party.  I'm like that.  

Crustacean made a bad first impression.  I wore a t-shirt, jeans, sneaks - and the maitre deeee informed me that the place has a dress code - no tshirts.  Excuse me?  But I am welcome to keep my jacket on.  Gosh thanks.  I could probably eat at any $200-a-head restaurant in San Francsico in jeans and a t-shirt if I felt like it - who the heck are these people to get all hoity on me?

Well, whatever - I was there for Poe, so I wore my jacket.  After everyone arrived and we started eating, Crustacean made a better second impression.  The waitress was friendly and attentive.  The wine list was actually decent (we had a couple bottles of an Oregon pinot that was just to die for).  Most importantly - the food was good.  Not fantastic, not mind blowing, but good.  My chicken was tasty.  The grilled oysters quite delicious.  The steak was melt-in-your-mouth tender, and the stuffed squid was quite edible.  The desserts were yummy too.   Again - not spectacular, but yummy.

Best of all, nobody asked us to pipe down as we all, ever more loudly, laughed our asses off while uttering some of the most culturally offensive semi-drunken blah blah blah that I've ever had the privilege to blah blah blah.  I think we probably mortally offended every other guest in the restaurant by the time the night was through.  All in all, it was a really nice party.  Poe should turn 40 every year.

4 stars for the food - minus-1 for hating on my SXSW t-shirt.
author: Joe C.

description:
I love this place!!! It doesn't get any better then this. Went on a date twice at this restaurant and had a great time both times. Service was excellent and the Dungness crab with garlic noodles was fantastic. Loved it so much the first time I ordered it again the second time. 

Casual restaurant that tends to get super busy on the weekends. Make sure you make a reservation!! Awesome place, awesome food. 5 thumbs up!!!
author: Michelle S.

description:
Even though our family did not make reservation, and 
sat at the non-dressy side, the service was still superb and
the food was wonderful!! 

Great roasted crab with garlic noodles!
author: Sunny S.

description:
i don't wanna just go around given everybody five stars. but if i had friends visiting from out of town and they wanted crab, i'd be taking them here. just like if they wanted steak i'd be taking them to house of prime rib. yes, it is expensive! two orders of crab and two orders of garlic noodles is gonna be $120 bucks, tip included.  they aren't real strict about dress code, cause i had a sweat shirt on. and my girl wasn't dressed up neither, but i'm not gonna tell you to test them cause i'm not gonna be to blame when they don't let you in. 

but to me, service is good. if i was on death row, and i had to pick something for my last meal, garlic noodles would be included. those who give bad reviews surprises me. giving a 5 can be disputed, but less than 4 is not true.
author: Michael L.

description:
Had dinner here with a friend again last night, before going to watch Avatar in 3d at the Metreon.   Reservations were kinda a pain, I wanted 7:15, they only had 6:45...which we were late too since the person I was going with didn't' get home until 6:20 or so, and still had to make the drive across the city.   

Dinner was great as usual, ordered the tuna and salmon dishes... both were excellent. dinner and 2 drinks came out to 67$...very reasonable.  Geoffre was our server, helpful and didn't intrude with questions all the time.   

Still a great Restaurant to go to whether on a date or for a nice dining experience.
author: Evan R.

description:
The food here is decent. If you tack $6-10 off the entrees and $3-5 off the appetizers, then you'd have a meal worth the quality of the food served here. If you're going to charge me the prices on the menu, I better have some shaved truffles on that shit or something.

The garlic noodles are bland in my opinion. The garlic crab is good, but way overpriced. The appetizers are abysmal. 

Not sure what they're going for here. It's in limbo between the food of your typical trying-to-be-fancy-Chinese eatery and the prices of an upscale restaurant. I'm sorry, I see through the boooooshiiiiit.

I give it a 2.5, but I have to round-down 'cause I also had a terrible time trying to find the entrance for a friend's birthday dinner here.

Just because you have living (and some dead) crabs in aquarium tanks doesn't mean you have to tack on the prices to maintain them on the menu.
author: Len L.

description: The prawns with garlic noodles, stuff squid& shaken beef is suuupppppeeerrrrrr YUMMY! The appetizers are on the bland side. Excellent service!!!
author: Jamie L.

description: I had heard about this restaurant for quite some time and finally persuaded my husband to go last month. We went with a couple friend of ours who happened to have eaten there before. They raved about the lobster. I'm not sure what possessed me to order an Apple Martini that evening, ( which I hadn't consumed in since my early twenties, perhaps it was my pissy mood from the hectic day I had!) Now I know why I don't drink them anymore, blah! Anyway, I ordered the garlic noodles with prawns which seems to be one of their popular and signature dishes. It was decent but I have to say I expected more given the "rave reviews" about it. I really had no clue it was mainly catered to seafood, which I don't necessarily have a problem with, however, my husband is not a big seafood eater. I think they should have more options for meat eaters even though their specialty is seafood. All in all, the company was great but the food wasn't great nor terrible.
author: ST1223 T.

description:
I had a blast, last night...  Food was delicious, service could not be better.  Although the lights went off but, service was still perfect..  I had the most amazing meal.   Garlic Noodles were great and the Roasted Crab delicious..  I also wanted to Thank the Service..   

They help my dated surprise me with this very romantic dinner..   THANKS TO ALL!!!!
author: Claudia P.

description: absolutely AMAZING!!! both food and service!!! i mean the food is GREAT but the service is AMAZING~~~ especially Paul is super-duper attentive and magical! and so is Miguel!!! both of them are extremely attentive, warm, and really really caring... YES! they are totallly comitted to deliver an unforgettable (in a best way!) experience. I high;y appreciate them and I will be back soon!!! THANK YOU! perfect food (oh, did I mention it was beyong delicious???!!!) and a ROYAL treatment!!! THANK YOU ALL!!!
author: Ewa Z.

description: Funny how another reviewer was here the same night my boyfriend and I were, and we had a totally different experience! Yes the bathrooms were out of order on this particular night...but hey it happens. What are you gonna do?! Anyway we went with the traditional route and did the crab and garlic noodles...ah-mazing..to DIE for yes so buttery but why would you ever NOT have butter with crab?! The service we got was remarkable as well. We will be coming back here again..definitely!
author: Azra K.

description:
Had a wonderful time at Crustaceans. Originally, we were going to go to Thanh Long but couldn't make it out there. 

No worries... I still dream about the garlic noodles. And the crab?! We ordered two crabs and really had to put in some work to get through all our food but it was sooooo heavenly.
author: Payal P.

description:
SOO YUMMY!! and def woth the mess you may make.
My date brought me here for dinner asking me to trust him completely and I did.  He ordered 2 of the roasted crabs and the garlic noodles and HE got to crackin'!!  And he meant business!
At the same time that it was so simple, it was so delish!!
Cocktails, crab and garlic - who could ask for a better date?!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
3 1/2 crab good, garlic noodles better

if i had to order anything it would be just the garlic noodles, crab is overpriced but good really dark inside neighboorhood also not so great would not go back due to the cost

food ***
garlic noodles ***** 
service ****
ambiance ** i can't see in here!!
author: Clarence A.

description:
An Family restaurants... thank you for not letting me down!

Garlic Noodles, thanks for making my breath hum. but we got gum for that fix.

I really wanted some crab, but since we were going out to a club right after, it wasn't appropriate to get down and dirty with our nice outfits.

The crab appetizer was so yum! so is the salmon carpaccio (sp?)

Just a bit disappointed you ran out of creme brulee, but it's all good! Fried Bananas fulfilled my sweet tooth.
author: Marissa D.

description:
This is also a tapas place with great cocktails. I can't believe I've lived in the general area for almost 4 years and never been here. It is within a sort of mall, and we noticed it because it has an elevator up to it (2nd floor), and the elevator has a lit of crab on it. 

There were 3 of us, we split 5 tapas and 1 main dish, and then took home leftovers. In order of which I liked best, we got the: grilled calamari (although it actually seemed like it was stir fried and was delicious), fresh shrimp spring rolls, seared tuna, seafood dumplings, and a shrimp/crab spring roll special. We also got the wok egg noodles with chicken. Everything was delicious, I would definitely go back, and would for sure order those first 2 or 3 tapas again before trying something new. 

Another group was there with a large group, like 20 people? So I'd assume they take large group reservations. They also have a good cocktail menu. The restaurant was casual, but definitely upscale with tablecloths.
author: Caitlin B.

description: HAPPY VALENTINES DAY, and when i say happy it was VERY happy. lol, they had a special for vday with an appetizer, entree, and then dessert. Everything was delish from the beginning to end. the Roasted Crab and the Drunken Crab or whatevs it was called was BOMBDOTCOM. deeeeem. thats all i have to say, any bad reviews for this place is trippin. And the place was sooooo cutesy the set up, lights dim low, OKAAY OKAAY i see you crustaceans (:
author: Rosh E.

description: Bit on the pricey side but an absolute must for any romantic meal or even just any upscale good seafood!
author: Sam G.

description:
i tried ordering to go on the phone last night, however, they didnt allow me to and said i had to order in person, why!? I don't see why can't i order over the phone and then pick it up in person! CRAZY! 

The usuals were good, however, after having my dinner my stomach wasnt well.... i woke up this morning and i've been in and out of the bathroom twice already within 30 mins.... :(
author: linda L.

description:
4 stars for my favorite dishes, subtract 1 star for the poor location and snooty ambiance.

I am an UBER FAN of the roast crab and garlic noodles. They are truly the best at what they do, and cannot be imitated (trust me, I've tried MANY times). 

I'm NOT a fan of the dark atmosphere, the long walk up the stairs in your heels, the horrible parking, or the expensive valet service. You have NO choice when it comes to these things.

But I guess you pay for the ambiance, which is a dimly-lit upscale version of Thanh Long. When I went to Crustaceans for my 7 year wedding anniversary, I had just gotten my lasik surgery that day and didn't realize until we had arrived at the restaurant, that there was a big fat sign describing the dress code (I could barely see- my new eyes covered by those dorky optomestrist glasses, I had no time to google or yelp before going). Luckily, my husband was dressed in a nice sweater vest/khaki's, while I stood behind him hiding in my black sleeveless shirt, black velour pants, and black sneakers. Anyone in their right mind could've seen I was underdressed, but it was dark and I dont think they really checked me (obviously). I got lucky, I definitely would not try that ever again. 

Anyhow.. although it's the same recipe as Thanh Long, it tastes 2nd rate to me. On the regular, I definitely choose Thanh Long in terms of quality, location, and I prefer their kick-back ambiance. I would only go to Crustacean's if I were on a date, for that super-snotty dimly-lit "fine dining" ambiance that you want to impress your date with. But even then, would you really look forward to a 2nd date if you came out of your 1st date smellling like garlic and covered in crab shells?

Don't worry, I still love you Crustaceans... but overall, I dont love you as much as I love your sister restaurant Thanh Long.
author: Joraine C.

description: High priced but roasted dungeness and garlic noodles are the bomb! Ambience, and great service. Parking can be tough but it's the city and expected. Fried wontons are excellent and well presented. The baked alaska and deep fried bananas with ice cream...mmm!
author: John G.

description:
I don't understand why some people would give less than 5 stars for this place... Yes, it is expensive... but it's CRAB!!  You don't get real quality crab just anywhere.  You can't just walk into any restaurant and expect the same quality for a lower price. Crab HAS to sell at market price, and for sure, it's worth every dollar you spend!

I have never been as satisfied with crab until I came here, and I've been to a lot of seafood places. Parking can be a pain but hey it's San Francisco.
author: Marvin R.

description:
Love the roasted crab and garlic noodles but it is a bit pricey.  We are not a big fan of the total old school decor.  Much prefer Thanh Long or PPQ but you can't beat the Ang family Garlic Noodles.  The House in North Beach is second runner up for Garlic Noodles.  The other items on the menu were not memorable.  Don't go to a steak house and order the fish.  Come here for the crab and garlic noodles and you won't be disappointed.

Roasted Crab          Garlic Noodles
1. Thanh Long         1. Thanh Long
2. PPQ                       2. Crustacean
3. Crustacean          3. The House
                                    4. PPQ
author: Alex H.

description:
AHHHHHHHH!  My friend took us here on the last day of our trip, not sure if she meant to end it with a bang.. but dude.. she sure did help us end it with a bang!  

Their roasted garlic/butter dungeness crab is the finger lickin' good yo!!  The crab was so fresh, it's full of flavor and it is gie-normous!  You've gotta try their garlic noodle also...   

Heads up:  Don't get so full off of the appetizer, because you may not be able to finish your crab!  Also, they don't do refills on soda!
author: Lisa T.

description: The roasted crab and garlic noodles are incredible. So messy but so much flavor. Eating with bare hands at such a fancy restaurant is quite an experience. I'd come back.
author: Sohiroshi C.

description: Come here and get the crab.  Nuff said.
author: Dylan T.

description:
Let's go back to the SATs

Question 1:

Harris' Restaurant : Steak :: 

(a) Bacon Dog Cart : Hot Dog
(b) Naan 'n' Curry : Indian
(c) Crustacean : Crab
(d) McDonald's : Food

Even if you don't know the answer, remember it's always a good idea to go with (c) as your guess.

Yeah, Crustacean is about that good.  I peeked a couple of other reviews prior to writing up this reviews.  I came to a quick conclusion.  Their expectations were entirely out of line.

THIS IS A FANCY RESTAURANT.

It's East Coast.  Let's go hypothetical.  Let's say you decide that Casual Friday is for suckers and you want to have Casual Thursday.  Even though you're rocking some sick threads (ltd. ed. Gama-Go t-shirt and an adidas originals hoodie), they're still going to insist you have a collared shirt.  Fortunately they have some stylish loaner shirts in rare and exotic douchebaggery bold stripped patterns.

But you're not hear to listen to my rants about their dress code.  You want to know that the food is like.

I'm a huge fan of calamari.  SQUID IS DELICIOUS.  (This is another important part of the review.  If you don't agree with the previous statement, you might as well just stop reading now.  It's not going to get any better.)  They served up this amazing fried calamari appetizer with a salt & pepper sprinkled over it that was nothing short of delightful.  I fell in love immediately.

I'm decidedly not a fan of eating an entire crab at a restaurant.  I know it's a delicacy.  I'm a man of principles and I don't believe I should work that hard for my food at a restaurant.  For crissake, I'm paying for this and I want someone else to do the work for me!  Is that too much to ask?!

Okay, enough ranting.  Back to the food.

My dining companions who do not share my avoidance of work at a fancy restaurant exclaimed jubilantly about the quality of their crab.  I  personally continued my love affair with eating squid by ordering the stuffed calamari dinner.  Simply put: delicious.  tasty.  awesome.  The whole experience was like some kind of ambrosiac sea sausage, delivered on a bed of lettuce.

I kinda wanted to keep the awful shirt they loaned me... but alas it was not meant to be.

Provided you know what you're getting into, Crustacean serves up a wonderful dining experience.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Don't ask me why I was hanging out on a yacht with a bunch of strippers. It wasn't my idea. But it happened. And then I got hungry. 

Me: I want to go to that place that everyone says has really good crab!
A Stripper: Crustacean?
Me: Oh, maybe?
Other Strippers: OOOOH Crustacean is the BEST place in the city for crabs!

To me, the crab seemed overpriced, especially given the lack of ambiance. It was smothered in sauce, which made it very messy to eat and seemed to cover up the flavor of the crab. 

But my opinion's not really important here. Clearly the strippers would know the very best place to get crabs...
author: Liz G.

description:
Kevin W.'s friend is hilarious! But I gotta agree with Kevin W. Completely overrated & over priced! Everyone  I know who ate there raved about the garlic noodles but when I tasted them.....they were just ok. And my skrimps were.... alright. No magic flavor to impress me.

The best part of the meal was when the hostess pulled out a mens button up and made a customer wear it because he was wearing a casual t-shirt. lol and that's why I gave them 2 stars.
author: Norma P.

description:
Fuck you, Crustacean.  You fired me.  Yes, I was fired from the Crusty Crab, a "fine dining" establishment with a fucking RED NEON CRAB adorning it.  Truly one of the shining moments of my life.

Oh, plus their crab is frozen.  So you might want to remember that while you're plunking down $34.95 or however much they charge for that swill.
author: Coco D.

description:
You know the crabs are frozen right?  Am I the only one that can taste the difference between a fresh crab from a frozen crab?  Hmmmmm.  I use to love Thang Long back in the day over on Judah st.  Loved the msg and butter garlic noodles.  As I got older, my body couldn't handle it anymore.  

The service is always great here but the food should be a lot better than this if they are going to charge this kind of price.  Don't you feel as though the garlic noodles have been reheated or recooked again?  They seem to have a following of people though.  You know what they say............there's one born every minute!!!

Restaurants that would be better than this.  R and G Lounge on Kearny and I don't even think that this place is that great neither, but hell, at least they serve fresh crab.  PPQ dungeoness crab on Clement st.
author: jason g.

description:
Crustaceans must have started the San Francisco tradition of upscale Vietnamese restaurants fleecing the predominantly non-Vietnamese customers on sub-par food at exorbitant prices. It's not that good, but I guess people haven't been to a real Vietnamese restaurant for comparison.

Their famous crab is a three pound monster that tastes pretty good for being frozen, but is not worth the $36 -- the menu says seasonal prices, and being crab season, it should have cost half that.

The recipe is painfully simple: boil, then roast the crab. Scoop out the guts, because Americans don't like that stuff. Then before serving, smother in garlic butter and season with salt and pepper. (For their $10 specialty noodles, just buy cheap chow mein noodles, and then soak them in garlic salt and butter.)

Eating the crab is a total mess, as the shell is too soft in comparison to how it's prepared in authentic Vietnamese or Chinese restaurants, where the shell is crunchy enough that you could get by without using a shell cracker. On a crab this big, the meat is abundant, but bland. A smaller crab would be more flavorful. Also, by the time you get to the second half of the crab, the butter has already started congealing on your plate... not very appealing.

Eating in the restaurant, it's noticeably cold. For a place where dinner and drinks can easily run $60-$80 a person, one would think the An family could afford carpeting and a heater.

The biggest gripe: after eating a sloppy crab meal and your hands are covered in crab guts and butter, they hand you a small wet towel and expect that it is enough. So you go to the bathroom to wash your hands, only to find that they have no hot water! Even McDonalds with their $2 Filet-O-Fish can afford hot water, but apparently Crustaceans cannot. Maybe they should charge $40 a crab and hire a plumber to put in a hot water faucet.

The food is decent, but not worth it at the price. If you're still bent on eating here, stick with the Roast Crab, the Tamarind Crab is surprisingly bland and the messiest dish to eat in the house. You're better off eating at a "divey but authentic" Vietnamese or Chinese restaurant. They might not have smarmy waiters in faux Asian outfits or valet parking, but they'll have better food and hot water.
author: Perci N.

description:
Ummmmm where do I start???

ok here, you know somethings wrong when after 3bites your done and the waiter notices.

I had to regretfully tell him I was very disappointed with the food. Especially with all the hoopla about the garlic noodles ( that were all clumped together, nevermind the fact that they were super oily...oh yeah where was the 'garlic') and the BOMB ass crab.

The only thing that I ate that I paid for was the crab corn chowder and my drinks, thankfully the waiter took the other stuff off.

It's a shame that I had to experience this on my first visit there.

I did tell the waiter that i'd give them another try, one day....this was about 2yrs ago now :-/
author: Sharee g.

description:
I was a former employer of Crustacean. I could fill a book about the stories I have from my three year tenure there. I will tell you that i love the "roasted" (roast in a microwave) garlic noodles and I could eat them until I had a massive coronary. The only restaurant in San Fran that utilizes more garlic is The Stinking Rose.

Secret kitchen....hmmmm...that was some real marketing hogwash. I applaud the Ahn family for making it in America from Viet Nam, and I genuinely enjoyed working there but I loathe the past mandate of deception to the dining public. We were told about young Helene Ahn, who was the youngest daughter of the last "Count" of Da Nang. She worked in her fathers'  aristocratic kitchen as the "irrelevant' Child under French, Chinese, and Vietnamese chefs. She recorded the ancient and refined "Euro-Asian" recipes and brought them to these shores.
Could be true...I was not there. However, the timer bell of the microwave was a constant sound of the "secret kitchen" during my tenure there in the late 90's.

Liquid margarine and loads of MSG laced frozen Dungeness crab nuked in the Amana are not some secret French Indochina secret recipe. Quite simply, that is "Hanoi Hannah" propaganda. Raytheon created the microwave, not Ho Chi Minh.

Do not be ashamed of utilizing MSG......Ahn Clan....don't cow to the junk science notion that MSG is bad for you. We need more umami flavor in our diet....besides Heinz Ketchup.

I wish that Crustacean would stop the parlor tricks and cook genuine Vietnamese cuisine...I am sure they are capable.
author: David J.

description:
My hat is ghetto-fabulous
My hat is my woobie
I've worn my hat since the Bush administration (the first one)
My hat is me.
My hat is ME!!!!!

Don't ask me to remove my hat.  I don't care how good your damn crab is. (and it was too)

You're not all that.  You're on Polk Street for Christ sake.  Hookers were getting it on within earshot.  Get over yourself.

The table to our left was on their cell phones for their entire meal and you all said nothing.  I mean COME ON.

And your bibs were glorified Glad bags.

Your Garlic noodles were tasty for sure...but your attitude left MUCH to be desired.  Really now...bottom-feeders are your specialty.

I'll be back for lunch, where apparently my Daisy Dukes are acceptable.
author: Mc Matty b.

description:
Let's get this straight: This is NOT a Vietnamese restaurant. It is a restaurant owned by smart Vietnamese who knew how to take the signature SF delicacy, dungeness crab, present it in several asian flavored presentations, and add some asian styled elegance to the mix., and charge a boat load to tourists to eat there. So bring your out of town business associates here and they will love it. 

If it is on your personal tab and you like crab, you can do much better and a lot cheaper in chinatown. If it is for important guests and you have the money, they will probably enjoy it if you play up the exotic SF crab/Vietnamese angles like the resturant does, and everyone will be happy. 

It can be a nice dining experience if you keep all the above in mind. And the garlic noodles (and crab) are good choices. Last time I was there I didn't see any  Vietnamese working there, in fact, no asians at all. The dress code is you have to have a collared shirt on, no t-shirts.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
Interesting place - I bet it was really a show-stopper when it was new. But now that it stays light until late - you can see how much dust is on the decor and how the rug is really worn out and all the nicks in the woodwork, the plants are looking kind of tired......   That all probably disappears when it's dark.

I found the food to be ok, not great. The Vietnamese carpaccio was quite tasty. But the lobster salad even with the big chunks of lobster was kinda meh.....   The lobster rolls were good as were the shrimps wontons with capers. 

Service was good with the exception of taking them an exceedingly long time to get my friend's glass of red wine to her.  Didn't seem right....

So it seems this place used to be pretty swanky, but she's just kind of tired now.
author: Laura C.

description:
The first time I ate here, I was blown away. I thought the food was really good. But then I realized it was probably because someone else was paying for it.

My second visit, everything was just alright. Totally not worth the price. 

The drunken crab wasn't drunk enough. Seriously, the menu said it's basted with 3 wines and I did not taste the wine at all. That crab could learn a thing or two from elite yelpers.

Buddha roll was flavorless.

Stuffed calamari tasted like something I can get at a $6 chinese restaurant, but for the price of $19.

Their saving grace was the garlic noodle. Even then it was extremely greasy.

Completely and utterly disappointed.

Especially since we're paying for it ourselves this time....
author: Ari C.

description: LOVE this place. The food is great! Especially the oven baked crab in the shell dunked in butter and herbs. The famous noodles are awesome too. This place is not to miss and we San Franciscians love it.
author: Telling T.

description:
Oh my!

No, no, no, no, no (five "no's")...

It started as a bad night and just got horribly worse.  

Nothing good to say about Crustacean.  Sketchy location, unattractive setting, dark and dated decor, stressful seating, filthy rugs, poor service, icky food, even the clientele sort of spooked me.  It was dreadful, especially when you look at how expensive this place is.  Zero stars.  (Okay, the bathroom was clean.  I'll give *it* three stars.)  Shocking.  I was led to believe...  Sigh!

Was it because I spent my early years eating Maryland crab?  Or that the place smelled bad?  I'm sure my house wine came out of a box.  Service was inept, stumbling, insincere.  The food was unappetizing with unfresh crab and garlic noodles that were overbearing and gooey greasy.  Even trying to stay clean and using many towels and finger bowl, I ended the meal feeling smelly and just plain dirty.  Argh!  Couldn't wait to leave.  A nightmare.

And to make matters worse, as we left, this poor homeless guy shows up trying to amuse us by tossing a lit cigarette into in the air and occasionally catching it in his mouth.  Against my better judgment, I gave him $5 just to go away, but he wouldn't, insisting my BMW (sic) was the best car ever made.  Just a heartbreaking night.

Don't go.  Trust me.  Just say no...

(Scary, 200+ reviews and an average at just about 3.5 stars.  Yelp!  Where are we, Stanford?)
author: Frank B.

description:
Oh my where do I begin........ oh I know. So we rode an elevator that had a giant neon crab on it to the third floor where the restaurant was located. This must have been a good idea......in the early 90's. Our reservations were for 8:00 and we didn't get seated until about 8:45. That was no problem since we sat at the bar and had a couple cocktails. The bartenders were quite nice but the drinks were incredibly overpriced but that was kind of expected. 

We were seated at an OK table by the window that had a great view of Polk St and all the madness that goes on down there. This was definitely a 9 on the unintentional comedy scale. Just watching the weird things that go on down there can keep someone entertained for hours. 

OK well I'm gonna pull a Seinfeld and kinda yadda yadda the rest of the meal. We had a couple appetizers, crab , garlic noodles, yadda yadda yadda and dessert. The food was good but not great and the prices were a little out of control. Right about the end of the meal that was probably on it's way to a 3 star rating everything changed. However the experience didn't come to a screeching halt as much as it crashed into a wall and exploded on impact. 

There was some issue with another table near by and the managers came over to find out what was wrong. I never was quite clear on it but almost instantly this stuffy guy in a suit completely berated the server in the middle of the dining room in front of all the customers. It was so embarrassing for all parties involved. I felt bad for the server who obviously had to deal with some ass hole on a power trip. At that point it was so uncomfortable sitting there I just wanted to get the hell out of there. That's no the way guests should feel in a restaurant where we just spent hundreds of dollars on a meal and more importantly the employee shouldn't be treated in that manner.  I definitely will never be back if that is the way this place treats their staff.
author: John M.

description:
i love it here.

for appetizers we had the vietnamese carpaccio, rice paper shrimp rolls, and calamari w/ mustard sauce. YUM.

i tried both the tamarind crab & roasted garlic crab. DAMNNNNNNNNNNN good. i don't care if im all dressed up with a plastic bib on and eating with my fingers. take me on a date here & i will be piggin out.

i thought the garlic noodles were good...but is it me or does it seem a litto soggy? either way, it was garlicky good & i can't get over it. 

for dessert, skip the fried bananas & ice cream. the fried banana was taken over by the massive thickness of fried flour. yuck!

this is just one of those places where you HAVE to come back to for some bomb ass crab.

:)
author: Rosalynn D.

description:
I'd heard a lot about Crustacean and was excited to see that it was on the Dine about Town menu back in January. Being Vietnamese, I was even mooore excited because it was a Vietnamese restaurant. Unfortunately, my excitement was quickly dispelled.

First of all, they have a dress code. Me and my group didn't know this and one of the girls had a zip up hoodie on. They were unnecessarily rude about their dress code, but they still let us in as long as the hoodie came off. Interesting though, their dress code said that they would provide a white collared shirt to any customers if necessary. I wonder if that ever happens...

The ambience of the place is ok, despite them trying to make the place super posh. Nothing that blew me away. It's def nicer than your average Vietnamese place, but I don't think as nice as some other Vietnamese fusion restaurants. The service was pretty attentive. 

Now, on to the food. The Dine About Town menu really wasn't all that great. It had spring rolls and chicken skewers as the appetizer...which honestly can be done a lot better AND a lot cheaper at your typical hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese place. Their main course options (again, for Dine About Town) were shrimp on garlic noodles and shaking beef (I think that's what it's called in English -- bo luc lac). We went for the shrimp with garlic noodles. Mm...the garlic noodles were tasty, as were the shrimp, but there were just a handful of shrimp, which was kind of disappointing. And as an entree...ehhh it got old pretty fast. Good thing we also got some of their famous crab too (instead of all of us doing Dine About Town)! We got the tamarind crab and the roast crab. The tamarind crab was pretty good but...there was just something off about the sauce. If you've never had tamarind flavored seafood before at other Vietnamese restaurants, you probably wouldn't notice...but us as three Vietnamese kids, it just wasn't quite right. The roast crab was super salty and super oily. I was really excited though because I LOVE the inside of the crab head. I love it so much that the waiter even brought us two more complimentary heads! Wheee!! To compliment the crab, we also got a bowl of fried rice. This fried rice is like your typical asian fried rice with some peas and carrots in it....the kind where you can get a whole tray for not much more $ than how much the little bowl they gave us costed :P Fiiiinally, we got fried bananas for dessert. Pretty standard, pretty good, but again...I could've gotten 5 times as many bananas for half the price elsewhere...

Overall, if you come, come for the crab and be prepared to spend more than you should. Maybe enjoy a bowl of their garlic noodles...but really, I'll make you a whole pot of garlic noodles for the same price :P
author: Christine L.

description:
the perfect meal:

Appetizer: greenlip mussels ( always have to order two orders cause I refuse to share them) and salmon carpaccio

Main Course: Tamarind Crab ( better than men! it satifies you, makes you happy, doesn't cheat, lie, or make tons of dishes and never wash them) - with Garlic noodles. I've had garlic noodles all over the state and this is by far the best out there. My meal always comes with more than 1 crabs worth ( I think its because I'm so darn small, they think they should feed me more) but I'm not gonna complain =).

dessert: The orange sorbet.  ( the fried bananas sometimes isnt cooked all the way through so the batter is soggy in the inside.) Don't get the creme brulee, its blah - if you want creme brulee, get it at The House.

I've been to thanh long and Crustaceans a million times ( okay maybe a hundred) but seriously, its a once a month thing for me and honestly, i think the food is the same. I prefer Crustaceans because of the ambiance and the service is faster.
author: Anna T.

description:
I have been going to this restaurant for over 15 years and love the food [especially the roasted crab and garlic noodles]. Went last night and was very disappointed. The food as usual was great but the service was not up to par. In fact it was the worst service I have had there. The waitress was unprofessional and sloppy. For example, 
she spilled our wine twice and our water once. Not one time did she apologize or even acknowledge this. We order our crab in shifts to share [and keep it hot]. She was late in following through on our second order and had the bus boy clearing all the dishes off the table even though one  person  was obviously still eating their meal.

If I could only rate the service, it would be one star.
author: Cynthia D.

description: This review is long overdue, but I came here a good while ago with two of my girlfriends. So we were waiting to be seated, and my friend saw the manager whisper something to the guy who greeted us and then the guy said that they have a dress code and the shirt (v neck white tunic) I was wearing is not quite acceptable and offered me a shirt to wear!?! I was pretty shocked and upset. First of all, I refuse to wear anything besides my own damn shirt! And the manager definitely needs to step up and do his own dirty work! Oh, and it was an early weekday dinner so we were practically the only ones there! Anyways, I just put my friend's jacket over my shirt and took it off at our table, wth is the difference anyways, obviously I was gonna take it off regardless. Have not gone back ever since! Douche bag, talk about leading by example! HA!
author: Carol C.

description:
The appetizers were all incredible. Lobster rolls, dumplings, and crab puffs. I would recommend any one of those. Very small but so delicious. 

This was my first experience eating a full on crab with a cracker (that cracking tool) and a bib. But it was delicious... I shared two roasted crabs and a side of garlic noodles between 3 of us. Excellent. Well I think that the garlic noodles are a little overrated... I think PF Chang's lemongrass noodles are better.  But they might have just been too hyped. Everyone else in my party loved them.
author: Natasha P.

description:
I've always had high hopes for this place because of all the hype behind it.  I went back recently for the second time and it reminded me of my first dining experience there... AVERAGE!

I've eaten at Thanh Long, so I thought that I would be getting the same level of yummy-ness (I ordered my own Tamarind Crab this time), and boy was I disappointed.  The sauce wasn't prepared the same way and I found it to taste more like BBQ sauce.  If I wanted that, then I would've just gone to a ribs joint...

Maybe third times the charm? I wouldn't pick this place to eat again if I had a choice, though. Personally, I would choose Thanh Long over Crustacean any day.  Sounds weird because they're pretty much the same restaurant, but there's just something about Thanh Long that Crustacean doesn't have.  Maybe a better chef???
author: Starleigh H.

description:
As Kanye says "Are ya Fuggin Kiddin me."
This place is a joke.  
Ambience - nice.  What do you expect when you are paying over a 100 bucks for two peeps.
Service - Ehh alright.  Definitely not good.
Food - Crap.  Crab was o.k, but wasn't fresh and was really salty.  I ean you would expect when you are paying over 30 bucks for a crab, they can at least have some fresh crab in the back.  Nope......
Garlic Noodles - Insult to my chinese culture.  This shiz tasted like they went to safeway to get some prepackaged chow mein noodles and added a 1 pound of garlic powder.  How can anyone a high class restaurant charge money for this crap?  I mean can you at least add a couple of vegetables?

Bottom Line - Another one of those asian fusion crap holes.  if you don't know good food, you may love this place.  For you hardcore foodies, don't insult your palette.

Zero stars for this crap-shack.
author: Tim L.

description:
garlic noodle - checked.

drunken crab - checked.

i can die now.
author: Betsy B.

description: I should have ordered the crab, based on the reviews below- but I ordered the stuffed calamari. It was just A-OK (hence the 3 stars). The appetizers were wimpy and I felt it was overpriced for what we were served. The garlic noodles were good, but again, nothing special.
author: Katherine B.

description: Well my first impression was that the restaurant was dated and smelled bad. Upon entering our waitress was very pleasant, I ordered a few starters one of which was the corn soup, well it was awful. So I asked her to take it back and that's when her attention to our group and attitude went down hill. The  crab cakes, seared ahi and beef skewers were delicious!  The whole crab dinner was tasty, but the garlic. Oodles were over cooked and dry, yuck!  The banana fosters desert was okay!  Would I go back yes, but not as my choice it would have to be selected  by someone else.
author: Bill L.

description:
I love visiting Fisherman's Wharf when I'm in town, even though its a major tourist trap.  However my last visit there, I was underwhelmed about the seafood they served there.  It must have been an off weekend.
However I redeemed myself by having the dungeness crab from this place.  I was in crab heaven. The crab sitting on my plate was just begging to be devoured.  Everyone raved about the garlic noodles so I ordered it and although its good, it's not that special IMO.
author: Dan O.

description:
Crustacean was the first unique crab restaurant I have been to.  Naturally I expected it to be a little pricey given that their signature dish is crab.  However, I wasn't fully prepared for the price we would have to pay.  I must note that the service was great and the food came out quickly.

We ordered garlic noodles, seasonal vegetables (turned out to be snap peas) and the signature garlic roasted crab.  I am glad the waiter talked us into getting the roasted crab, because, despite my initial thoughts of this being any "regular" roasted crab it was extremely good!  Well seasoned and flavor all over.  A very meaty crab as well.  The garlic noodles were good, but it would have been nicer if they were not cut--it's nice to have longer noodles if you prefer them that way (and of course you can always cut them on your own).  The snap peas were good but in my opinion sort've pricey.

At first I wanted to ding a star because the waiter brought out the warm towels to clean our hands too early (and it got cold), however he was very amiable and explained why the restaurant was so crowded on a Monday night (the reason being that their other location is closed on Mondays).

If you are looking for a unique place to celebrate a special occasion, give Crestacean a try!
author: Christopher W.

description:
Crab and Garlic Noodles.
I dont even bother looking at the menu. It can get pretty crowded but its a good place. Make sure you are there on time for your reservations. The drinks are also pretty good and actually reasonable price for this caliber of restaurant. It is nice to sit by the window facing out to polk street to people watch but once they put on the bib and bring out the crab i do not pay much attention to anything else. Helpful tip, they will reheat your crab when it gets to cold with all that butter and sauce. Maybe one day I will be look at the menu and maybe even order dessert.  but the crab and garlic noodles (with tiger prawns) can not be beat.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Delicious food, nice decor, pleasant staff. Prices, however, holy crap. I have been here twice when my family has been in town visiting, and both my brother and my father, crab lovers to the bone, declare the roasted crab to be the best they have ever had, and I believe them. I am less of a crab lover, so I've stuck to the other dishes and have been pleased, but not knocked out. In a town like this where good food is abundant and usually not this expensive, this would probably not be my first choice for a dinner spot, but I wouldn't be my last, either. 

*Special note: their current "Dine About Town" prix fix menu (for Jan 2007) looked very reasonable, so if you need an excuse to give this place a try, now is the time*
author: Tom H.

description:
I've never been to Crustacean's before this but friends and I went because it was participating in Dine About Town.
The service was great but the food was just mediocre.. It wasn't anything to write home about..   I'd say if you're going to spend that much Cash-Ola for "food" you might as well go to their original restaurant, Thanh Long...
Although the atmosphere at Crustacean's is nice, I'd rather spend money on better food.
I gave this place 3 stars cause the service and alcohol was great.. better than what we would've got had we gone to original house of An's..
author: Tupu S.

description: My husband loves this place but for me it is ok. The crab is delicious the garlic noodles can be hit or miss and thats about it. It is pricey! The tables are rather close together and it is small but I would go back because it's my husbands favorite place.
author: Victoria B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. My sister had raved about the GREAT food she had enjoyed in the one in Beverly Hills.  So maybe my expectations were too high.  

Location & Decor:
The building where this restaurant is located is filthy.
They need new carpeting, it smells like damp clothing inside the restaurant.  They need to remodel the place or at least replace the carpet.

Food:
An's Garlic Noodles - they were extremely sweet, I have had better from street vendors at China Town in NYC.  I'm not exaggerating.

Stuffed Calamari - Too sweet, I did not taste any Asian herbs.

Lobster Salad - This taste like they took a thousand island dressing and added lime juice.

Seafood Salad - This was more lime juice less thousand island dressing.

Saigon Beef - Oh god it was also too sweet, it does say it has caramelized white onions, so maybe It's me...LOL

Tiger Prawns - I'll give them this one even though the Prawns were a bit over done.  I like them crisp on the outside but tender and juicy inside.

POSITIVE:
Our waitress Celeste was EXCELLENT, she knew her menu inside out, she knew about the history of the family and the restaurant and suggested a superb wine.

Conclusion:
For the money I expected mouth watering food.  This is regular food at very expensive prices and the location needs a face lift.
author: Ydania O.

description: Roasted crab and garlic noodles.  You can't go wrong with that. We like to visit this reasturant annually and enjoy every minute of it.  They need to do a little updating and parking can somestimes be a challenge. We have opted to go at lunch on the weekends which makes it easier to find meter parking.
author: April L.

description: I really love this place, it's just soo expensive for what you get.  The crab is absolutely delicious.  The garlic noodles are a little greasy but equally wonderful.  But it's hard to walk out of here without dropping a $100 for two diners WITHOUT alcohol.  (The crab is close to $40 an order.)  If I were a millionaire, I'd eat here once a week.  Problem is, I'm not, so I eat here about once a year for a treat.
author: Josie O.

description:
My friends and I went to Crustacean during San Francisco's 8th Annual Dine-About-Town where folks can have a three course meal for a price to DIE FOR, but that was just a special...I didn't take the time to look at the prices on the menu out of fear that it'll taint the experience with spite that I'm a broke student. 

I went expecting the portions to be small and the variety on the menu for us Penny savers to be ridiculously minimal, but I was pleasantly surprised!

The famed garlic noodles, mind you I hated garlic prior to the experience, opened me up to the idea of trying more food with garlic in it...unfortunately...I think its just at crustacean where Garlic is delectable *whimpers*. 

The beef with jasmine rice is cooked to perfection. So Tender (yes with a capital T) that it melts in your mouth...you almost gotta close your eyes with every bite to truly appreciate it. 

The spring rolls (I'm a snob when it comes to these because I'm Vietnamese) were better than most Fusion restaurants, though the sauce was all wrong. 

Service? Well, just for you fellas, there is a dress code - dare to come with a T-shirt and you'll have Ms. Starch-faced hostess ready to stare you down with the eye of a tiger and throw a shirt in your face. Other than that, the other hosts were pleasant and inviting, while our waitress knowledgeable, sweet, and helpful.
author: Pari G.

description: Garlic crab & garlic noodles is the reason to go -- fabulous! Also, this may sound rediculous, but there is something in their pepper, it is DELICIOUS and makes their calamari appetizer better than any other I've had. We top off the night with dessert and coffee and spend ~$120 for two. A great price for a full crab dinner that knocks your socks off!
author: Felicia A.

description: Order their Crab and Garlic Noodles.  Then order Banana Fritter.  You're Welcome.
author: Michael S.

description:
I'm very excited to be blogging about the next restaurant I want to share: Crustacean, in San Francisco. The story of Crustacean is a very unique and heartwarming one, and can be found on their website. It's a win-win situation: my heart is happy to support a restaurant that has such a rich history and happy story of determined women succeeding against all odds, and my tummy is happy to support their food - again, and again, and again!

On the dollar scale, from fast food to once-in-a-lifetime, I would say Crustacean rates "special occasion" - However, since discovering it last year, I've been there three times already and would not hesitate to go again tomorrow. To start, we ordered several appetizers, called "Small Plates" and costing around $10.00.

First we had the Papaya Salad with Calamari, "lightly marinated calamari tossed in spicy Vietnamese vinaigrette with green papaya, rau ram and fresh Asian basil." I'm not even sure what a natural papaya looks like - such an uncultured foodie - however, I do know that it was amazing, and am now a permanent papaya salad fan and will order it wherever else I see it, just so I can compare them and see who makes it the best!

Next we had the Vietnamese Carpaccio, "thinly sliced raw beef with a spicy lemon vinaigrette, Asian basil, sliced red onions and roasted peppers." My last trip to Crustacean, and the Salmon Carpaccio small plate that I ordered, had made me a carpaccio fan, but something about this dish just wasn't as stunning as the last one I tried. I would definitely re-order the salmon carpaccio next time, or try one of their many other small plates.

Crustacean Shrimp Toast. This was actually really delicious! I was wary about the idea of minced shrimp on bread, but it was executed wonderfully. It was lightly broiled so that it was a tiny bit crunchy and toasty on the outside, but soft on the inside. They only serve three pieces, though, so if you go with a party of six like we did, you must be prepared to share. I would probably try something else next time.

Main Course Time! We ordered everything that Crustacean is famous for: first, the Roasted Dungeoness Crab. This is widely, widely recommended on blogs and review sites everywhere, and for a reason. The crab is perfectly roasted, and so savory that you have to try very hard to refrain from licking the shell! It's easy to crack (and it snaps crisply, not soggy and bendy like cheap crab does), and each bite of the tender meat inside reminds you why Crustacean is one of San Francisco's best seafood restaurants.

Second, and absolutely crucial for every visit, is the famous An's Garlic Noodles. I knew about these garlic noodles way, way before I ever set foot in Crustacean itself. The first time I had it, I was hooked. Second time I had it, I was still hooked. Third time....yep, still hooked. :) I can't emphasize how much I recommend these garlic noodles. TIP: If you're not feeling spendy enough for a restaurant that's "special occasion" priced, though, you can get a very good alternative garlic noodle dish at Unicorn that I heartily recommend. It's lighter, and still very delicious.

Dessert! Most of us were tempted into the fried banana and ice cream, which is delicious and a must-have if you've never tried it. However, if you have had it, Crustacean's take on it is not particularly special - but it's not bad at all. But, the best of the night was definitely the Baked Alaska. Now, I am not a big fan of bananas. However, the sauce on the banana slices was divine - sweet without overpowering. I seriously respect any restaurant that can prepare a food I don't particularly like into a dish that I could die for, and this was definitely it!

With the dessert still on my mind hours later, I looked up Baked Alaska on the interwebs, and I can't say that the description of the dessert sounded like what we ate - so I'll have to order it at the next restaurant that offers it, for the sake of comparison.

Yeah...obviously, I am a huge fan of this restaurant and it has not failed to impress me even upon my return trips. I am always recommending this restaurant to friends and/or taking them there personally so I can get another meal in!

Full review with photos here:
http://lorelai.vox.com/library/post/never-disappointed-crustacean-san-francisco.html
author: Wei-Ling W.

description:
My first time here...Love the ambiance of the place. The wait staff was excellent, very attentive. 

The crab was fresh, juicy, tender, amazing...FIVE stars for the crab.

The garlic noodles, really nothing special to me. They were good, but would have preferred some sort of vegetable mixed with them. Just too plain for me. THREE stars for the noodles.

The Tiger Prawns were very good. cooked perfectly and I think I tasted a hint of coconut milk. yum. FOUR stars for the prawns. 

The best part was the Manager's cute smile. He was so pleasant, handsome and charming. That definitely earns the FIVE stars!
author: Kat D.

description:
Hated it!

I went here w/ friends of out town friends upon their choice and was thoroughly unimpressed.  First off, the decor is very dated, and the building is gross.  You walk in and you get that not-so-fresh feeling the moment the aroma of stale fish hits your nose.  

And from there it goes downhill.  We ordered a soup that was way too sweet.  Vietnamese salad was ordinary.  Famous Garlic noodles weren't bad, but let's be honest here - at home: you take spaghetti, soy sauce, garlic, grease, and a touch of pepper and there you go!  Crabs were fine but no great culinary feat.  We ordered  a halibut that was horrendous and also came with an overly sweet sauce.  The shaking beef was overcooked and certainly not shaking.  At the end, my share of the bill was $40 and I felt like a fool watching 2 twenties come out of my wallet.

The company was good though.  I like my guests, and their friends were nice too...I just won't be returning to Crust-a-thon...
author: Chad K.

description:
This is really 4.5 stars:

After eating at Crustaceans, I had 2 heart attacks last night. Probably shouldn't have kept dipping my crab in the flavored oil that it was drenched in, but boy was it worth it. The roasted crab was amazing, the tiger prawns were equally delicious and the garlic noodles did not disappoint. I would probably not recommend anything else on the menu.

Most of the stuff on the menu was overpriced, but the crab was worth it - $35 for 1 roasted crab (very decently sized, could probably feed 2 girls or 1 hungry beast). 

Minus 0.5 star for giving you plastic bibs and then being retardedly pretentious about the dresscode. Also, for not willing to seat you until your entire party arrives. If they were truly an upscale/fine dining restaurant, they would do all they can do to accommodate their guests. 

But watevers - the service was good, our waiter was friendly, food came fast and we feasted like gods. Need i say more?
author: Rene Y.

description: I cant imagine anyone giving this place a bad review.  It's my favorite restaurant in the city bc the crab here is DELICIOUS!
author: NewtoIthaca N.

description:
Roasted crab & garlic noodles... you won't be complete unless you've eaten this meal!  It's probably the best dunganess crab I have ever had, comboed with the garlic noodles, it's the perfect meal! 

This restaurant came highly recommended by quite a few good friends, but we never got around to trying it until we visited San Francisco...so if you're ever in the SF area or Beverly Hills, give this restaurant a try.
author: Sarah T.

description:
I was excited to try this place, especially during crab season but don't like that they don't have online reservations. I called and didn't have a problem getting in though.

To start, my husband had a lobster salad which I think he enjoyed. I had the dumplings and they were fine but really pretty boring.

My husband got the prawns, again, think he liked them, I got the roast crab and that was really good. Messy, obviously and oddly they don't bring you extra napkins, lemon water, etc. My husband paid the bill, so I'm not sure how much the crab came out to (it's market price). The garlic noodles were good, but I don't think I'd crave them enough to go back just for that. I do think this is a great place to go maybe once a year during crab season.

Our server was good and very quick, but my husband did order a glass of wine from the man who brought out his entree and never got the wine. By the time our waitress came back around, he was over it/almost done with his dinner. My husband had to wait for me to finish the crab for a while, so right when I was done, he was ready to go. We flagged down our waitress and she did have it over to us immediately.
author: Lauren M.

description:
In actuality, I would say Crustacean's food is about a 4...not a 3.  We came here to order the famous crab - and boy did we get that damn crab alright.  Its messy and tedious, but the garlic pepper butter sauce it comes in makes it worth it.  In addition, the garlic noodles are off the hook.  Ive been wanting to get a takeout order of just the noodles for lunch, they were so good.

The reason Crustacean is getting 3 stars from me because of their ludicrous dress code.  Dont get me wrong, we appreciate dress codes and follow them by all means whenever we're headed to a very fancy restaurant or upscale lounge.  The thing that ticked me off about Crustacean's dress code was: 1.  It was not well advertised, and 2. This restaurant is nowhere near being upscale or fancy enough to be demanding this from their customers.  However, they do have black collared shirts available for customers to wear while they're digging their way to china and covered in crab meat.  

Its pretty ironic, being forced to wear fancy clothes at a restaurant where you eat with your hands...
author: Genevieve M.

description:
I agree with everyone else...this place is overrated!!  I came here with another person and spent like $200...

We went to PPQ's and got the same amount food (minus the alcohol of course!) for $42.00 !!!

Now that's a deal!! If you wanna get ripped off then go here..but for the same amount food and a better deal, please go to PPQ's!
author: Jade B.

description: Oh snap!  Even though several people recommended this place for the last 3 years to me, it STILL exceeded my expectations!  Roasted Garlic Crab will have me dreaming until I can get my paws on some more.  Our Server was so nice and I love that it is casual dress now, so you don't have to look spiffy if you don't want to.   We ordered the garlic noodles with prawns and although they were delightful going down... the $35.95 price tag for the 4 tiger prawns was a lil shocking.  All in all, a solid 5 stars for the garlic crab of my life!
author: Michelle M.

description:
If you like crab, garlic and noodles then this is the place for you.  As soon as you walk into this place the aromas alone make you hungry.  I do have to say if you order the crab, wear the bib they provide and get ready to get messy, there is no way to eat this crab without getting it all over your fingers, ladies with nails, watch out.  Garlic noodles are yummy and if you get the crab, order garlic rice and dish into the cavity of the crab, mix  it all up and enjoy:)

I heard that there is actually a secret kitchen within the kitchen to produce some of the more famous items on the menu.
author: jenny a.

description: Took visiting family after persuading them not to eat crab at Fishermans Wharf.  Two downsides, tiny little bathroom (not the worst thing in the world) and awful loud obnoxious patrons  who's voices carry throughout the entire room.
