A half bottle of wine somewhat lessened my pain but both the accoustics and the crowd here leave something to be desired.  Roasted garlic crab and garlic noodles were good.  Salt and pepper calamari was better than the corn and crab chowder.  Pitifully weak and cold coffee straight out of a clearly non functioning thermos and average desserts.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I don't get the hype about the food here. Five of us went here for dinner before drinks. We ordered all the right things - 2 different kinds of crabs, garlic noodles and a couple of other small dishes. Maybe my one year stint as an expat in Singapore taught me how whole crab dishes could taste like but I'm sure even if I had never tasted yummy pepper crab, butter crab, chili crab, I would still not be impressed with the food at Crustaceans. 

Service was great - very friendly. The guy at the bar where Mike, Nick and I ordered drinks while waiting for the rest of the party was especially nice. 

As far as atmosphere, it had the fine-dining/romantic-like aura about it. The elevator access to the place gave it an almost exclusive feel. Outside was not so nice.
author: Jane K.

description:
located in san francisco and beverly hills, ca it's known for two dishes; the roast crab and an's garlic noodles.  the roast crab always seems to be a hit and its pretty much what every table will order. its roasted and infused with garlic and spices and is enormous.  on the other hand, an's garlic noodles don't seem to have the same consistency as the crab.   according to many diners including myself they are sometimes cooked to perfection and other times extremely soggy and overcooked.  i do however always recommend getting both dishes.  executive chef helen an also roams the beverly hills location quite frequently which has also been known to host celebrities. 

favorites: roast crab and an's garlic noodles.
author: Robert R.

description:
Coincidentally located in Snob Hill.  

Just don't pay attention to the people who are snobs that frequent this place.  

Instead order the garlic noodles and the crab....is it roasted?  the one from the special secret kitchen menu that's all garlic infused.

Put the bib on.

Start cracking shell.  

Dig in.  

Get messy.  

Who cares if you're sitting right next to someone all eleganted out.  Go in jeans and a shirt.  You're there for the foooooooooooooooood.

Damn, that shit is good.
author: MiYong E.

description:
Upon entering the restaurant you get an almost zen-like feeling. It is an asian restaurant after all! Bamboo, waterfalls, slate and asian decor invoke that feeling, usually. I am greeted by a nice man. He asks my name and says my table will be ready soon. We head to the bar for a cocktail. 

The bar is rather small and lacks for seating if it's a busy night. The drinks are good, though. I have a fruity sort of martini and the maitre'd says the table is ready. Right on time! 

The wait-staff is friendly, possibly overly so. We look over the menu and settle on some deep fried tempura shrimp appetizer, the seared tune and some spring rolls. The only thing that stands out is the shrimp which I highly recommend. 

For dinner, it was the crab, noodles, rice and string beans. I'm impressed by everything. The garlic crab is perfect, yet messy, The noodles and rice are extremely garlicy but in a good way. The string beans are just perfection. 

Hints for this restaurant: 
- You will most likely have to pay for the valet parking
- You must wear a collard shirt. Stupid rule and they try and enforce it
- Crab is messy. Be prepared to get a little dirty even though they do provide bibs.
- Don't expect to be kissing anyone of you eat here!
author: Amy B.

description:
Oh Mi Lord.  I love Crustacean.  I've been a handful of times and have always had the best experience ever.  I go for the Drunken Crab and Garlic Noodles but once had the Tiger Shrimp and was very pleased too.  Crustacean is the ultimate SF dining experience.  Here and House of Prime Rib are my two faves. 

You need a lot of money when you come.  Once I went with two other girlfriends and our bill was almost $340.00.  Ofcourse we had about 4 drinks each.  The drinks are quite costly too.  However....it is SO worth it.
author: Virgo M.

description: i choose this over Thanh Long... yes, i get that it's owned by the same person but i just like the ambiance and service as well.  Roasted crab and garlic noodles is MANDATORY!
author: Kae B.

description:
The three truths about dining at Crustacean Restaurant:

1. Roasted crab (extra savory) + Garlic noodles (extra al dente) + Nut cracker (extra sharp) = Garlicky Great Time

2. Great place to visit with close friends and family. DO NOT go with your boss, pastor, or secret crush, lest your stinky garlic breath drive them away forever. 

3. Who knew that food requiring fingers and multiple bib changes to eat would ever be served in such a lavish (almost theatrical) restaurant?
author: Yb W.

description:
I love the crab at Crusty's! The roasted garlic crab is oh so delicious! I've tried the drunken and the tamarind crab, but still think roasted is the way to go. Garlic noodles, lobster rolls, coconut prawns and calamari are great accompaniments to the meal. I don't like the papaya salad prepared here. There's a funky aftertaste. The yellow corn bisque can be skipped.

It's pretty nice inside, although a bit worn down. Guys are required to wear a collared shirt. They are pretty strict with this rule. I had a co-worker who arrvied without a collared shirt, and the host gave him a dress shirt to wear while inside the restaurant.

As much as I love Crusty's, on my last trip here the crab had a gimp claw that was half the size of the other one, and the meat was shriveled, like it'd been sitting in the freezer for a while. Overall, I like Crustacean's better than Thanh Long because of the better appetizer/side dish options here. And the crab is better seasoned than at PPQ's. But PPQ's garlic noodles are less salty, giving it a more subtle flavor, which I like.
author: Starla L.

description:
being vietnamese I should know better...

A fancy Vietnamese restaurant is oxymoron.  I have always been tempted to try one but never been able to convince myself of laying down good hard earned green for food I KNOW I can find at a friend's house or  otherwise hole in the wall both cheaper and better.

But alas came an opportunity to prove my theory on someone else's dime... a dinner of my choice (paid for by a bunch of Losers) for winning my fantasy football league!

Food was blah, decent at best and portions were small, typical of upscale restaurants.

The only saving grace was the desserts. We ordered six different ones and tasted each round robin style. yum. 

Would I dine here again? nope. I'd rather skip the fancy decor, spare the wallet and find some place in San Jose where the food is authentic and not gussied up with an illusion of fancy.
author: Long N.

description:
I still can't believe it had taken me this long to finally check this restaurant out.  If you're a fan of crab this is the place for you. I went with a group of 5 and we each ordered a whole garlic crab and garlic noodles. 

*Here's a tip for you- ask for it pre-cracked. You'll still have to do a lil work to pry the crab out from the shell but not as much. 

**Another tip- don't order these two things then go out afterwards. The five of us were burping up garlic the whole night...NOT CUTE. 

Regardless, that rich, garlicky, buttery crab was so delish it was well worth it! Plus, once you see the stripped carcass of a crab on your plate don't you feel so accomplished? Like you actually really worked for your meal? Now that's satisfaction!
author: Melanie G.

description:
I had dinner here last Thursday with a friend and really enjoyed it. I had a hell of a time finding it though because it's really on California Street.

Calamari: 4/5 - lightly battered
Royal Tiger Prawns: 4.5/5 - It's served with An's Garlic Noodles which is very good.
The Roast Crab: 4.5/5
Service: 4/5
Ambience: 4/5
author: Khoi L.

description:
My parents absolutely LOVE love love this place!

I came here with them a couple of years ago and I will never forget the Crab and garlic noodles.  So tasty, just delicious, yes pricey.  Yay for coming here with parents!!
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I've been going to Crustacean's for 10 years... This was MY favorite restaurant of all times. But on my last couple of visits, the food was not the same. The only reason I continued to go was to see if it was just me or the kitchen had an off nite... but no.. the food is no longer the same. It's different.  I know they would say they had a secret to their food, i wonder if the chef left with the secret, because it's simply not the same.  The crab is still good, love the garlic noddles, but it got greaser... and my favorite dish is not the same....I'm bummed.
I would of gave this place a 5 but, the taste is no longer there....  good, but not the same.
author: Gladys P.

description:
This is one of my all time favorite places to dine for a special occasion.  The roasted crab and tiger prawns are amazing as well as the secret garlic noodles!  Even if people say the famous crab is frozen, the way that they prepare the dish is what makes it so famous.  Although after eating there you may not feel quite as gross as eating at the Stinking Rose, but you definitely feel the need to shower!  
All in all what makes this place great is the service, the excellent wine list, romantic decor and consistent standards for well prepared seafood.
author: Katie G.

description:
OMG.  If you guys think this restaurant is good, think again!  I was craving crab, but after I ate only then did I realizes this: 

TOO MUCH MSG (MONOSODIUM GLUTAMATE)  

If you don't know what that is, it is very bad for you!  I went here waiting for a long time to take my parents, but after we left we all had cottonmouth!  MSG tends to dry out your lips and tongue.  But this is the worst case I've had meaning there was just too much MSG!  That is very disappointing for a high-end Vietnamese restaurant!  Yuck!

Next time I'll just have my crab at an ordinary Chinese restaurant.
author: Ringo L.

description:
Doesn't get any better, clearly the best roasted garlic crab in the Bay Area, maybe all of California for that matter. You cant go to Crustacean's and not order the crab. Most people have the garlic noodles with it, but Ill pass on the noodles, the chicken fried rice is always on point. 

The service is always great, and the restaurant is always clean which makes for a pleasant experience each and every time I go. The prices on the crabs vary, but are always upward of $30. They don't have fountain drinks which mean no refills, so get your drink with the meal or just drink water. 

I am not a big dessert but they have great deserts, the fried banana's with vanilla ice cream is divine. Also they have an assortment of sherbet that are extremely good.

They have valet which I highly recommend because parking is horrible. With that being said go to CRUSTACEANS, your life will never be the same!
author: Kenny C.

description:
I am really surprised to give this rating to such a highly regarded restaurant by the yelpers.  Anyways here we go, my thoughts...

Who: The lady and I
When: Saturday evening, actually got seated quick even though there were people waiting without a reservation...
Ambiance: Asian themed, very nice, dimmed lighting

First Course: Seared Ahi Tuna - Best dish of the evening!
Yellow Corn Bisque with crab meat - Pretty good, not bad and on the sweeter side
Garlic Bread - More like Garlic crackers, small and crunchy with a good garlic taste.

Second Course: The Roast Crab that's roasted to perfection with garlic and spices - It was crab, the seasonings were good but they were not mind blowing for the price.
An's famous garlic noodles - what made this so famous?  It was okay, good hints of garlic but nothing that I would make famous.
Shaken Beef flambeed in Chardonnay, sauteed green beans, cherry tomatoes, and red onions - Egh, I've definitely had better!  The beef was slightly over-cooked and the green beans were rubbery!  
Jasmine White Rice - Good with the crab and the beef.
Bottle of Dr. Loosen's Riesling - Excellent!
Dessert: Mango Cheesecake! - Superb!  Especially after our Second Course!

Bill: $150 and some change and we left a $25 tip.

Thoughts: The service was cool, just cool but nothing outstanding.  Anyways, I agree with yelpers who left 2 stars for this place; Way overpriced and overrated!  I would of rather gone to Bix!!!  Anyways, I did make a good crab sandwich with the left over crab the next day and it did taste better than what it was previously, I should charge "Quoted Price" for my sandwich.
author: Limzer L.

description:
We went with friends  here to celebrate their wedding anniversary. One of our friends had dined at the Crustacean's in Beverly Hills and thought that this would be a great place for fine dining. 

First let me say this is NOT fine dining!

Location - Great! Nob Hill neighborhood, historic and picturesque.

Ambience - Nice decor, table by the window was very nice as well.

Parking - We used valet parking ($12 plus tip). The others parked down the street which was very inconvenient. My suggestion is to use the valet parking. 

Food - OK, most of us ordered the famous "roasted crab" and "garlic noodles" - while this tasted OK, it was not good or even great, just OK. The crab was tasty but seemed to be overcooked. We wore bibs to keep the butter and grease from getting on our clothes. While this was an interesting part of the experience I really don't expect to wear a bib while enjoying a fine meal. Also, why do they require a jacket at this place, if you have to wear a bib! Jeans and a T-shirt would be perfect for cracking crab, and spraying butter all over the place. 

The garlic noodles were very soft and I didn't really taste much garlic (I've had Ramen Noodles that tasted better). 

One person in our ordered the shimp and noodles and he stated that it was very good.

Calamari - Very good and well prepared. I particularly liked the cut up vegetables that were part of this dish.

Service - The service was good. Our waitress was very knowledgeable and friendly. She made very good suggestions for both our meal and drinks. One person in our party decided to pay extra to have the crab extracted from the shell by the restaurant (afraid that the butter or crab would ruin her dress). We had to pay extra for this service and it took a very long time to complete.

Price - very over priced.
author: Garry B.

description: Lets see if this crab is a good as they say!.   The crab was a good as any I have ever had.  So was the ravioli and the garlic noodles.
author: Scott D.

description:
I can't believe this is the first time I've eaten here. It's unreasonable... DAT is going on, yes. We didn't order it... 2 crabs, garlic noodles, a glass of wine, dumpling appetizers, and a coke... I think that came to like $120 with tip. Kind of a lot, don't you think?

Would have been three starts if the crab wasn't so DAMN GOOD...garlic noodles. I feel like my heart is a little happier today because of it.
author: Annie T.

description:
Wow this place had so much hype. Always heard about how great the crab and garlic noodles are. 
My husband finally got around to taking me here for my birthday. We started out with appetizers salt & pepper fried calamari and muscles. The muscles were really good. I think it was my favorite dish of the night, which is ironic, since it was just an appetizer. It was buttery and flavorful. The calamari was good too, but a little too greasy. Nothing special. 
I ordered the garlic noodles and crab of course. Oooh, disappointment upon my first bite. What's so special about the noodles again? It didn't taste like something from a "secret kitchen." I enjoyed it, but I thought it was more greasy than it was buttery. The crab had too much fried onions in it. Again, more greasy than it was buttery. I'd rather have Boiling Crab.
It's basically overpriced, unauthentic Vietnamese fusion food. 
It's a nice place, but way overrated and overpriced. In fact, I prefer the garlic noodles and crab I make at home. I was hoping this place would live up to its hype, but unfortunately, it disappointed.
author: Linda P.

description:
I LOVE CRUSTACEAN's crab and garlic noodles.  yum yum yum.  However, I went to the Beverly Hills Crustacean before I went to the SF one, and the Beverly Hills restaurant was way nicer with it's aquarium walkway, mini bridge, and much more open-concept floorplan.  The SF one felt like we were sitting in a hallway.  

Other than that, the food was just as good. mmmm.  My mouth waters just thinking about it.
author: Sandy C.

description: AMAZING MEAL! I love crab and we ordered 1 crab for 2 ppl and we were stuffed. It was delicious. The garlic noodles were EPIC. Everything about this place was awesome. My boyfriend took me for my 24th birthday and it was such a great experience. RECOMMENDED for sure.
author: Azita A.

description: I love the concept and presentation of this place. The drunken crab is the thing to order. The one caveat of the place is the somewhat pretentious receptionist who asks you fr your reservation when the place is 2/3rd empty. Aside from that, never a bad time at this joint...
author: Jim B.

description: Im a fan of Crustaceans but after eating here a couple nights ago I must say it's not as good as it use to be, the portions is not as big the garlic noodles and prawns were'nt that bad but the crab could of been a bit more better tasting. Ive been hearing alot about this restaurant that's suppose to be better called PPQ so I'll be trying them out real soon.....
author: Jeniece H.

description:
Crustacean has _decent_ food NOT GREAT. but for the price you gotta wonder why some people post such positive reviews. 

First of all, I've had much better crab although it's been in a lot of foreign countries. I haven't had a lot of crab here in the U.S. so maybe it's just hard to get good crab here.

We had the roasted crab, garlic noodles, and halibut. The halibut I thought was pretty good if we were paying $12 for it. The sauce was nice although a bit sweet. The crab was also sort of good but for the price it's kind of a bad deal.

Oh we also had the paper shrimp appetizers which were excellent.

Anyway, I gotta say this place is pretty over rated if you factor in price. divide price by 3 and I may give it another star.

The service we found to be pretty sketchy. We had to wait 15 minutes for our reservation which we would understand if the restaurant were busy and they sort of forgot about us. They seated another party of 2 ahead of us which was kind of irritating.

Finally, a mystery about this restaurant to ponder... why is everyone so unhappy? This is not a happy place. Every single person that works there has a very sad look on their face. You will not find a single waiter or host/hostess with a smile. It's almost like a funeral.

Anyway, if you're ok with eating overpriced food that's pretty good but not great in a funeral like atmosphere than this is your place.
author: Joseph K.

description:
Finger lickin' good - and I mean that literally - you will be licking your fingers! Order garlic noodles and crab. 

Wear the bib with pride ... this place is top notch eatin' 

Not a fancy looking place but the food quality and 5-star price make it an excellent choice for a special occasion.
author: Colleen J.

description:
Weaksauce!!!!

I've been to better hole in the wall places better than this place.  Very over rated.  The only reason i would choose to come back would be for the ambiance.
author: Mike V.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate here on our trip to San Francisco. 

I think they need to relocate because the surrounding area and the building they were in didn't match the kind of atmosphere they were trying to create inside. When we got in, the host was very friendly and did not hesitate to show us where the bar was. We waited about 10 minutes for a table and they seated us very quickly. While at the bar, we had a couple of drinks. I loved their malibu sunrise.  very good. After we were seated, we got introduced to the menu and our waiter was very helpful with all of our questions and he even made some suggestions. But instead of doing what everyone else recommended(garlic noodles & crab), we went for something different. I had the crab cakes, they were just ok. The crab cakes were a little bland and in every other bite, had pieces of crab shell in it. My boyfriend got the stuffed calimari. He said it was just "Ok" too. 

Next time we eat here, we will definitely try what everyone was and is still suggesting.
author: ROCKKSTARR h.

description:
Food - 4 stars
Service - 2 stars

This place is pretentious.  We had reservations for 8pm and didn't get seated for 15 minutes.  After being seated, we waited another 10 for our waiter.  By that time, we were STARVING and ordered more than we should/would have.  For appetizers, we got the crispy rice paper roll, calamari, lobster roll, and crab puffs.  We were only 5 girls but we devoured it all.  Oh, I also got a lychee martini, which was perfect, but the pear martini that someone else ordered was crap.

On to dinner!  We ordered the drunken crab, shaken beef, royal tiger prawns (which comes with garlic noodles), and the panko crab cake.  Oh yeah, and three side orders of the garlic noodles.  What say you?  How can 5 mostly skinny girls eat all that?   Well, we ate all that - and then ordered dessert!  We got the fried banana with ice cream for the birthday girl and also got creme brulee and the baked alaska.  The desserts were ok, nothing special.

Oh.  Did you want me to comment on why this place only gets three stars when we obviously ate everything on our plates?  Our waiter, Paul, wasn't attentive.  Well, that's not entirely true.  He was attentive whenever he came around, which wasn't very often.  We had to flag him down to order.  We flagged him down when a server brought the food out because he had taken our utencils after the appetizers and didn't bring us new ones.  We flagged him down after dinner was over and we had been sitting at a cleared table for 10 minutes.  (That was to ask him for dessert menus)  When we were ordering dessert, we also ordered cups of hot tea to have with dessert.  After we finished dessert, we had to flag him down to get our check and to tell him to not bother bringing the tea.  He gave us a blank stare, then said, "Oh."  He had completely forgotten about the tea.  Hmmm.

The food was good, yes, but the service was so very bad.  I don't think I will come here again unless someone else is paying.
author: Lynnie P.

description:
Yes it's pricey but....it delicious! How can you put  a price tag on good food?

My husband and I drive to SF at least once a month just to dine at Crustaceans. We drive up, eat, and drive back home and it's worth every moment being stuck in traffic.

The food is delicious! We always order the same thing: Appetizer -salt and pepper calamari, Entree- 1 Roasted crab to share (I'm a light eater) 2-orders of garlic noodles.
author: Denise A.

description:
I've only come here for one purpose and one purpose only: crab.

I was told I had to come here..and this was the place that I had my first decent Bay Area meal...

I was lucky enough to come with family and therefore did not have to pay.  Otherwise, I think the prices are a bit high.  

First timers have to get the roasted crab, but if you do not feel like watching all the butter coagulate in front of you as you eat...try the tamarind or drunken crab.  All are delicious.  I wish they did not take all the "good stuff" from the inside of the main shell though..I guess its done for presentation, but bums out us Asians :(

Garlic noodles are crazy good and I haven't found anywhere else that does it better....yet....

If you want your meal to be cheaper, go to Thanh Long...although, quality of food can be not as good...and service is crapola there.  Crustaceans has way better service in my past experiences here and the decor is much fancier (if you are going for that sort of thing.)

Dress appropriately or you will be scowled at...

Bonus: I know it sounds weird, but I love the aroma of the finger bowls they give you at the end of your main course :P
author: Jay P.

description:
Oh, wow.  I used to LOOOOOOOOVE this place and would recommend it to tons and tons of people!

The first time I went was about 10yrs ago.  I went for a work function.  Oh gosh, it was sooooooooooooo good. There were over a dozen of us, and we could not stop asking for more bowls of garlic noodles!  MMMMMMMM!  I had the tiger prawns...and mmmmm so good!

Throughout the late nineties, I frequented often...always super good!  Moved out of state and came back to the Bay.  Early, 2000...took my mom for her bday.  Good, but not quite as good as I remember.

February 2007, went with a bunch of friends.  Have my tastebuds changed through the years??  Not only was it not-so-great, but everything tasted drenched in grease...it was like I was eating tablespoons of oil per bite!!!  I wanted to gag, as my friends exclaimed "Oh, my god!  This is soooooooo good!  So much butter!!"

Um, no.  I like butter, but this was an even heavier consistency...like too much peanut oil or sesame oil...really thick...really *gag* greasy!

Don't get me wrong, I enjoy greasy food...but this was so greasy that the oil was floating in oil...the noodles glistened like a cheap wh0re doing round 8 of an oil wrestling competion at a grimey beer house.  It was just wrong...and cost me $$$ to boot.  =(

5 stars for my good ole memories of the place...minus 2 stars for the last experience.  I am hoping that I just went on an off-night!
author: Ladi Da A.

description:
Um, like a way nicer Thanh Long or PPQ.  But imagine it with a nice, once upon a time atmosphere, but now that is older and a little more lived in.  

And to clarify, I think that it Crustacean shares the same owner as Thanh Long but not PPQ.  

That said onto the food: shrimp toast: yummy but not as good as it used to be.  Either that or my taste buds have matured and moved on.  But I remember at 21, 10 years ago, I loved this shrimp toast dish more than anything besides the garlic noodles.  

OK, then of course, the garlic noodles- amazing!  I ate the whole bowl myself.  And I never for even a second regretted all the carbs I was eating.  I think it was enough for 2 days.  

And of course the crab it self is always to die for.  If comparing this crab to the one at the other places, I think it was unanimous that the crab here won, but by a slim margin.  

For dessert we had the baked Alaska, which is not torched in front of you like it was when I was a little girl, but still tasted good, had it thawed out a little more before they brought it out to us.  

With this place, the third factor (besides the garlic noodles and the crab) that made this place so worth the parking issue, was the service.  The waiter was as incredible as you would find if you were Justin Timberlake dining at the Ivy in Beverly Hills- super attentive, catered to your every whim.  He laughed, stroked our egos, and kept the champagne flowing and never once judged that we were drinking straight champagne on a Saturday before noon.   

Yup: noodles, crab and celebrity like treatment.
author: Denise B.

description:
This place is a trip.
It looks like a hip hop convention! Maybe there was a rap concert that night. 
Great atmosphere, and everybody in the restaurant seems to share one great love. The roasted crab. Very impressed. Try the drunken crab too. 
Now to the garlic noodles. Very good, don't get me wrong, but I can make them at home for one tenth the price. G-a-r-l-i-c and N-o-o-d-l-e-s. Not that difficult. 
Overall great place to take a date in the city.
author: Randall S.

description:
If you want a nice place to have dinner in the city, this would be one of my top choices.  I've been here for Valentine's Day, Birthday parties, and just for a nice dinner with my friends and it's one of those places where you're never disappointed.  It's easy to find and they do have valet out in the front.

I would recommend the Royal Tiger Prawns,The Drunken Crab or the Roast Crab (both are good).  An's Garlic Noodles are a must!!  I also had a bit of my friends Garlic Rice and that was just as good.  Make sure to save room for dessert as well because the Fried Banana with Gelato is what I really crave for from there.  

Make sure to pace yourself though, the food is really rich and you'll definitely feel a food coma afterward.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Get the Garlic Noodles and Roasted Garlic crab.

- The Garlic Noodles use a buttery, cheesy, secret family recipe that many have attempted, and failed to duplicate.

- The Roasted Garlic Crab is ginormous and will require messy eating. As a bonus - combine salt, pepper and lemon to form a perfect crab-dipping sauce.


Also worth trying:
- Tiger Prawns: a less overwhelming dish that comes with a side of Garlic Noodles.. get this if you can't handle the giant Roasted Garlic Crab

Crustacean is a little pricey (~$40-50 for the garlic noodles + crab alone), but the food + intimate ambience make for a nice place to splurge.
author: Tim N.

description:
My experience at this restaurant started well,  Our original reservations were for 6 ppl on a Friday night and they were able to accomodate an extra 2 at the last minute but five minutes after walking through the door my experience went downhill.  Even though we made reservations, we still had to wait about 30 minutes and they wouldn't let my friend into the restaurant because he didnt have a collared shirt (yet throughout the night, we saw other people in more casual attire than my friend).  

Our waitress was a lot nicer.  She recommended wines to pair with our crab-the pinot bianco that she recommended was awesome! 

Overall, food is mediocre.  I've had better crab and garlic noodles.
author: Jen L.

description: Garlic noodles, and garlic crab, dee-lish. The service there was excellent. would go again.
author: Kit M.

description: I go to Crustacean every time I go to San Francisco!  Always get the garlic roasted crab and the garlic noodles.  Grilled calamari is also awesome.  One word of advice, get over yourselves and your snooty dress code (minus one star).  Why get all dressed up to go eat crab with your fingers and have butter running down to your elbows?  Sheesh!  Funny thing, whenever I go there, why do I usually see Hawaii pee-poh?  It's like the California Hotel in Vegas!
author: George E.

description:
Definitely a great place to go.  It's been around ages and I haven't gone in a few years, but decided to bring my girl here.  From then and now, the quality has remained top notch.  

We had the Vietnamese salad.  It was excellent--I highly recommend it.

The roasted crab is definitely a winner.  Since I ordered that for my girl, I wanted to try something else.  The waiter suggested the drunken crab.
Both were good--I liked the roasted crab more (and my girl liked the drunken one more) so in the end we switched plates..problem solved :D.   However, the roasted crab is definitely very very oily, just to warn those who are watching their oil intake.

The garlic noodle is to die for.  We ordered one to share but it was not enough...had to get the waiter to bring another serving!  At another table, I saw they were wise--everyone had their own bowl of the garlic noodles from the start!

In terms of service, they seem a bit snobbish, esp. at the reception.  However, the waiter provided excellent service.  

Reservations were easy. Just be warned--guys need to dress decently (no baseball caps, ripped jeans, T-shirts).  It's a good third-date place (when you both aren't afraid of getting your hands dirty to crack the crab shells and get at the crab meat),
author: Sonny W.

description:
Garlic noodles are a must.  As I read about others experiences (because I ate there numerous times long ago) I am not to sure about the food as of lately.  I am eating there on the 5th of August to celebrate my Anniversary and hope that it hasn't changed too much. I usually order the chicken medallion and garlic noodles but if you want a true experience order the garlic noodles and roasted crab. (I am allergic to shellfish but I have tried it and had no reaction and it was great).  I had great experiences when I ate there, so I hope it's still a great one when I go there next week.
 
Next week has past and everything I ordered there was fantastic.   I truly should make an effort to eat here at least 2 times in 3 months or even more. It was great.  I recommend this place.
author: Jun O.

description: My hubby and I ate here for my b'day once.  We ordered the roasted crab, garlic noodles, vegetables, and for dessert the fried banana with ice cream.  I loved the crab and garlic noodles, they were soooo tasty and delicious.  The restaurant was noisy and crowded, but we were too busy eating our crab to even care.
author: Racquel E.

description:
Terribly overrated. The food was nothing spectacular (I ordered the catch of the day and had some of friend's crab). The fish I ordered had no taste and by no means their garlic noodles are anything of a gem. They were soggy and quite greasy (not in a good way). The crab, glistening with their 'family recipe' and oil (all over the shell?), didn't seem like anything special that I would pay the ridiculous seasonal prices for...
At least our server was nice.
author: Mike S.

description: Food is good as usual, but the valet becomes not available until further notice.
author: Ken M.

description:
4 1/2 stars really...

After reading a bunch of these reviews, I counted myself lucky to have gone here on a normal Tuesday night before closing. No wait, and we even had a baby...no problem!! 
Minus 1/2 star for the "Corn Bisque with Crab" being nothing more than a can of creamed corn with VERY little crab meat...yuck! That was definitely the only down side to the food that night!! Everything else was DELISH!! The 4 of us ordered 5 small plates, 2 crabs, and 2 desserts, and left there fuller than a dog tick in August...pardon my southern roots coming out in form of analogies.

Would HIGHLY recommend:   (Prices are what I can remember)
Lobster Rolls ($10)
Roasted Crab ($35)
"Milky" Chocolate Bread Pudding ($9)
Lobster Toast ($10)

Items that were great, but may not order next time:
Baked Alaska ($9)
Coconut Shrimp ($10)
Drunken Crab ($35)
Crab Puffs ($10)
Garlic Noodles - ($10) *they really are good, but $10 for chow mein noodles, really?! Come on! Even I have my limits. With all the other good stuff, they didn't even get eaten.

ITEM I HATED!
Corn Bisque crap ($7)

Minus 1/2 star for being so darn pricey!! It was a great experience with AWESOME food, and we'll definitely be back! (right after pay-day)

VEGAN NOTE: 
NOT a great place to come if you're sticking with it. Only 1 or 2 menu items that were possibilities.
author: Lydia V.

description: My first time here was for a friends bday! There garlic noodles are really good, but the price is just too expensive, ill rather go to PPQ.
author: Vanessa B.

description:
First and foremost: There's a bloody dress code.

My BF and I arrived, at 8pm on a Saturday night with a reservation. We got a table right away, however, they told us about their dress code. He was wearing a white v-neck tee and black cardigan. Luckily, they DO offer dry cleaned collared shirts for customers to borrow while dining. Nice shirts too, we were tempted to leave with it. haha (don't worry we returned it). However, half way through our dining experience, a table was seated behind us, the guy was wearing: A WHITE T-SHIRT AND GREY CARDIGAN. Where the hell was his collared shirt.. HMMMM??? If you're going to make one patron change his shirt.. sorry you gotta hold it true for EVERYONE. 

Anyway. We ordered:
Salt & Pepper Calamari: Decent. Fresh calamari, came with some stir fried onions & bell peppers. Good, but had better.
Tiger Prawns w/ the famous Garlic Noodles: eh. I was really looking forward to the FAMOUS GARLIC NOODLES. I've been hearing about it on TV and from friends. First, it wasn't fresh.. it was actually kinda soggy, and it was obvious it was made from a large batch and then portioned out. Honestly, I've had way better noodles. Prawns were delicious though.
Roasted Crab: The main reason we came here. It was good. Not OMG good, but good. You really can't go wrong roasting crab in garlic. I should've tried their tamarind crab, maybe if i ever go again. I'd rather  save the $40 for the crab, buy fresh and make it at home. 
Creme Brulee: Good, lots of vanilla. 
Lemon Cheesecake with mango & strawberries, and a mango sauce: Mangoes were WAY to sour (still green) to pair well with this tart cake. Kind of dry too. 

All in all.. 
Food was OK
Service was good, although it took our water a little while to realize my BF was completely out of water. Highpoint: The food came out pretty damn fast. I was very surprised about that. 
I probably won't go out of my way to come back though.
author: Chi N.

description:
Can we say, YUM!

Simply THE BEST GARLIC CRAB out there!

The garlic rice, garlic noodles and the Helene's Ravioli are just a few of my favorites, but the garlic grab, is to die for!

There are other places that claim that they have the best garlic crab, but it is not the same compared to Crustacean's. This is the An's family secret.

I love the food, the wine list and the service. Simply the best for a casual dinner amongst friends. Take out is good and left overs are always good as well. Just remember, this restaurant requires a dress code and it gets really busy, so make sure you have a reservations!
author: Amy T.

description:
Wow!  Crab and seafood lovers come HITHER!  The salt and pepper calamari was to DIE for.  I could stop eating it! Also, you HAVE to try the butter garlic noodles!!! Holy Moly, I could probably eat that for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

Fantastic!  

I will definitely be coming back to Crustaceans!
author: Candice M.

description:
Wow, so expensive...but so good!

Corn bisque soup, amazing.
Drunken Beef, amazing.
Roast Crab, amazing. 
Mixed Vegatables, amazing.
Garlic Noodles, amazing.
Bar Cocktails, average.
Total Cost: $160. 

As stated in all these other posts, get the garlic noodles, they're ridiculously good and serve as the perfect compliment to everything. If you don't order the garlic noodles, you're wasting your time, and you should be eating at Carl's Jr. instead.

The service and environment is a little cramped for my taste, but if you're looking to take that fine lady out to dinner. You can't go wrong with the Crustacean.
author: Mitchell H.

description:
For the price point, I think this restaurant is a little pricy.  The problem with this Vietnamese/Euro fusion is that Vietnamese food is really never meant to be upscale.

I mean in the history of the cuisine, an 'elitest' type food set never emerged.  So when you are paying top price for Vietnamese food, I think it's something that isn't mind blowing or extradioary.

I ordered the halibut and the garlic noodles.  The garlic noodles were good, but not GREAT.  The halibut was a bit overcooked, but the flavors were bold, reminiscent of the cuisine.

I guess the problem with the restaurant for me was expectation.  I think I simply expected more.
author: Dan Q.

description:
Ex took me here for one of my birthdays eons ago. 

What I remember:  

5.Unforgettable Garlic Noodles!! So simple yet hard to copy at home. (My friends and I tried to cook them at home but we were never able to duplicate the taste.)
                                   
4. Really delicious crabs

3. Nice ambiance
                                   
2. Not a good for first time date unless you can work your crab without ending up with crab pieces all over your face and you don't mind smelling like a fish market for the rest of the night.

1.  Generous ex paid $150.00 for 2 crabs, 2 garlic noodles and a dessert!
This is where I deducted one star.  $150 for a crab dinner, are you kidding me?!!!

I like eating crab in the privacy of my own home where I can eat it like a true island girl. So, it is unlikely that I will go back.
author: Leah E.

description: This is my favorite spot of all time. Garlic roasted crab and garlic noodles have been the best ever since I "stepped off the boat" in 1996!
author: Vanessa G.

description:
Went here for a girlfriend's birthday dinner.

I don't eat crab so I ordered the shaken beef and garlic noodles. Both was delicious. usually shaken beef is dried but this place made it tasty and flavorful.

All the staff there were nice and friendly. Got all of our orders down and pure group had more then 10 people. 

The food came out quickly and we all dug in and ate.
author: Helen S.

description:
After I won a bid of a Crustacean coupon at a school auction, I and my hubby plus his friends planned our dinner out at there.  We called to make reservation and were told that we must dress up, no jeans, no tennis shoes, man needs a jacket....It made our expectation high for Crustacean BUT here're the facts....

When we arrived, we needed to wait for almost 30 minutes because there's no table for us and we must have everybody there before we would be seated.  OK, it's not something that a restaurant can control.  Then, we saw some people walked in with their shorts, sandals and sundresses and the front desk said nothing about it.  If a restaurant would like to implement some rules, it must be universal.  I made me feel like that I're fooled; why couldn't I wear my favorite T-shirt and jeans while someone sat near to be wearing shorts and sandals?

OK, after we settled down in a table of 6, we "studied" the menu and tried to decide what to go for.  The waitresses and waiters were so enthusastic to sell their expensive wine to us.  One of my friends like to try different wines and my hubby knows quite a bit of wines.  He knew that the ones they tried to sell to us not worth that much.  We totally understood that restaurant needs to make a profit but the charge was really a ripoff.

Then, talk about the food.  The garlic noodle were quite good but not rated as high as so many yelpers mentioned here.  I tried the lobster linguine which was quite fresh but definitely overpriced.  My friend shared a crab with his wife who wanted to try something different, sweet and sour crab.  They were disappointed, the taste was just not right and they regreted that they should just go for the normal crab.  My hubby went for the steak which was OK but not outstanding, again it's overpriced.  Another friend and his girlfriend tried the tiger prawns and they really liked it.

Finally, the desserts were just so and so, not impressed.

With the coupon plus the tip, we spent around $100 per head.  Thanks for our silly friend to order that kind of expensive but yackky wine.  We all consider Crustacean just being overrated and overpriced.  My hubby said that he would rather go to Thanh Long which should be better in quality.

One more thing, parking is hard.  Also, it's so windy at night and ladies who wear dresses made of light fabrics should pay attention.  My friend just played Marilyn Morroe when she walked on the staircases.  And, it's not sexy or fun to see her embrassingly grab her dress.
author: Roserrele W.

description: Our large party didn't order the crab for fear of making a mess before our night out at the clubs, but that was a HUGE mistake.  Everything was lackluster, crabcakes were dry and the fish plates were overcooked.  Presentation of the food was unimpressive and the interior looked like a seedy Chinese restaurant.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
My friends and I go here a few times a year for the Roast Crab and Garlic noodles. Its one of the best places if your a crab lover like I am. The service is good too. 
I only gave it four stars because if you order the crab, there isn't much time to socialize with your friends. If you do the butter will coagulate and its just not the same taste. 
People also rave about Thanh Long but to me it doesn't taste as fresh, but I have some friends that swear by it so as long as I get crab I'm happy.
author: Just J.

description: Food was great! But overpriced. Be prepared to spend some $$$.
author: Leigh M.

description:
It's ok.   A bit overrated in my opinion.   You will have a better experience at PPQ and Thanh Long.  Sure, those places aren't as nice inside, but who the heck cares when the food is so much better???

Next.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Sooooo i went on a Crustaceans/Thanh Long sabbatical for roughly 4 years and ate at PPQ for a while and raved to everyone about how much cheaper it is and how much better the roasted crab and garlic noodles were. THEN, went to Crustaceans cuz payday had me feelin myself and boy did i feel like a punk ass hypocrite afterwards. To me, in my opinion, the An family got the roasted crab and garlic noodle scene on LOCK DOWN. Despite having to work out twice before eating here and making sure i parked 8 blocks away for the walk back after the meal, all that roasted, garlicky, dungenessy, aromatic and oily goodness is well worth it. Man i'll lick the shit outta the plate and clean up my hands without a wet hot towel. I think thats all there is to get. Garlic noodles and roasted crab. DONE! 

p.s. best surprise of the night, finding a lil lump of crab meat left over in the back of my molar 2 hours later. damn it was soooo good.
author: Nick V.

description:
Not the usual city dwellers, we got lost in San Francisco looking for "clam chowder" and restroom, like moths to fire, hungry Berkeley hikers, trippers converge to The Crustaceans. 

First. The entrance was a fun puzzle. The restaurant is located above ground level, the reception area completely secludes you away from the main dinning area as the fragrant smell tempts your Yelpy tastebuds. There is a dress code, beware, but we got in with plaid shirts. 

The quality of the food was superb. We family-styled, co-op styled:
lobster mango salad, this really amazing white fish that I forgot the name, miso-glazed beef, shrimp chowder, crab appetizer, Helen's Ravioli. My favorite one is Helen's ravioli. The nutty, gasping taste of it makes me want more, and more!

Time for dessert. I had "Baked Alaska", Creme Buele, Strawberry/mango cheesecake with house coffee and cappuccino. The Baked Alaska wasn't so hot, just ice cream on a not so moist fudge, the cheesecake was my favorite out of the 3. 

I'd say, at Grustacean, you are eating both the experience and the delicate food. Be ready to stop at Popeyes or Church's chicken if you're hungry later, poorer too, this place....ain't cheap.
author: Jack C.

description: Outstanding roasted crab and garlic noodles. You don't want to order anything else. I'm a little shocked by all the low star ratings here - but can understand if you didn't dig the way the crab is cooked or the other dishes on the menu - as they are just OK. Definitely not your typical crab joint.  If you love butter and spice on your crab - you'll love it here....
author: Lor B.

description: My husband & I have visited this restaurant a couple of times.  The wait staff is friendly and efficient.  The tamarind crab is delicious and goes well with the garlic noodles.  The drinks are a bit pricey, but good.  We will definitely keep coming back!
author: Carol S.

description:
The location was a bit random, and finding the entrance was kind of like going through a maze.

The Vietnamese carpaccio was tender, fresh, and an interesting combination of flavors and textures.  Wok egg noodles and garden vegetables were pretty ordinary and overpriced for what they are.  The garlic noodles were flavorful but pretty buttery and heavy.  Just skip straight to the roast crab, which is priced depending on the season.  It's more expensive than at PPQ, but I think the quality is better, and the dishes are more refined in execution.

I'm a bit amused by how they make the servers dress, but I guess it goes along with the theme.  Service is pretty polished and much better than you'd expect at any other Asian restaurant. 

Overall, it wasn't as amazing as I'd hoped, and now there are so many other crab/seafood options around, so it's harder to bring myself to rush back there.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
THE BEST CRAB EVER! .. but pricey...

It's been a while since I have been back, but as I recall the dish to order is the garlic crab and/or garlic noodles.
author: Somala A.

description:
I know, I know, why would a vegan go to a seafood restaurant? Well, boo boo's auntie was visiting from Japan and wanted to try it. I couldn't say no, the woman is a tiny little package of scary!

I told the waiter I'm vegan and despite being in San Francisco, even explained what that means. He didn't know what was in the dishes - isn't that like restaurant service 101? He was nice enough to check with the kitchen and came back to tell me that the vegetables were meat free.
So that's what I ordered, a bowl of vegetables. What I got was a night of diarrhea thanks to a big bowl of (expensive) veggies swimming in a soup of butter fat. Obachan would've been very offended if I didn't eat.

Their signature dish is crab. Just like their noodles, it came soaked in garlic butter with cracked pepper. I thought this was supposed to be Vietnamese style. The food is uninspired and overpriced.

My grandma cooks 100x's better and she doesn't pretend to be descended from royalty.

BTW, I don't know who gave the wheelchair vote, but I can tell you that my disabled MIL had a really hard time maneuvering around in the crawlspace that lead to the elevator. I don't know how that excuse for a hallway passed any handicapped codes.
author: JaM W.

description:
Ambiance: Absurdly pretentious. Don't go without a dress shirt, or else they'll give you a freshly laundered one themselves (which may or may not fit at all). The decor tries too hard - I'm not really sure what they're going for. I think of it as a two-sectional restaurant, one of which is "meh.." and one of which is "zomg wtf?!" 

Food: Makes up for the ambiance. The roasted crab is the best in the city (price is market, but averages around $40), and the garlic noodles are fantastic. Starters are all average-above average, but really just stick with the crab and the garlic noodles. You won't regret it (unless you hate crabs and/or garlic noodles). 

Dessert: Don't bother. Nothing is above average, and the baked Alaska  is barely teetering on the line of belowaverage/average. 

Drinks: Also don't bother. You're eating crabs, people - drink beer!
author: Kevin L.

description:
The few times I have been to Crustaceans has been really good. 

 It has been some time since my last visit but i sounds like maybe the quality has gone down hill. I have been really excited to take my GF here.  I remember it being very tasty.

We started off with some saigon beef and garlic noodles both of which were really good.

Then put in a nice order of the peppered dungeness crab.  I loved this Crab and look forward to having this dish once again.

We polished it off with a creme brule and some dessert wine.

The food was very delicious but it is very expensive and easily will cost $200 or more for full appetizer, dinner, dessert, drinks and all for two.

Give it a try if you like Crab.
author: Robert S.

description:
GREAT garlic noodles
GREAT roasted crabs
GREAT prawns & noodles
GREAT location on Polk St
GREAT fast & quick service
GOOD decor & ambiance
author: Wendy H.

description:
Talk about an odd location. 
I liked the Garlic Noodles, their specialty, and the sea bass entree was okay. 
I did feel somewhat like a prisoner in the tight table that they squeezed 7 adults into. I don't  like meals where i am forced to monitor my fluid consumption so I don't have to disrupt the meals of my fellow diners  to use the facilities. 
The wait staff was on top of it and I liked how quiet it was even though it was a pretty full restaurant on a Monday night.
Would I go back? maybe
author: Roxane S.

description:
Always a treat  here you have to try the HUGE Roast Crab.  The garlic butter sauce will dry up if you do not focus and eat.  You can have conversations before and after dinner but once that crab hits enjoy it while it is hot.  I always get the garlic noodles and garlic fried rice to cap it off.  I stick to what I know and I know this is some goooood CRAB!

Do not wear a top or shirt that you do not want to get butter or crab on.  I made that mistake a few times but well worth it.  Even with the bib it can happen.

They are open for dinner and I think Friday's for lunch.  Changing jobs so this will definitely be a Friday spot for me from time to time.

I miss it :-)
author: David F.

description:
Crustaceans is an ok place. Not as good as thanh long. But Crustaceans is more dressy and casual than Thanh Long. I can bring a date here because of the ambiance it has. But Thanh Long is more of a family or friends type place..

But just like thanh long, the crab and garlic noodles here is a must!
author: jay d.

description: Service was excellent. Food was wonderful. The restaurant was cold we were freezing in there for the money we paid we should get heat included. That the only reason I gav 4 stars and not 5. Had roast crab and garlic noodles and garlic bread. Great!
author: Vj S.

description: My favorite restaurant. The original crustacean... Must have the garlic noodles and the cracked crab. Without drinks, can get out of here for $60/person which is well worth it!!!
author: Sean S.

description:
If awesome crab and garlic noodles that cause clogged arteries aren't what you are about, then you should avoid this place like the plague.  If it is, you gotta try Crustacean with the neon crab that goes up and down on the side of the building!

Friday night.  8 pm reservations.  Parking was not too tough.  Circled three times and found a spot in front of Walgreens 1/2 a block away on Polk.  Got seated and ordered the following:  Lychee Martini, and a Hanoi Sunrise, Vietnamese Carpaccio, PEI Mussels, Roasted Crab, Garlic Noodles, and for dessert, the Baked Alaskan.  Total tab, $104 (before gratuity).

Just for every Yelper to know, the Hanoi Sunrise is a drink they serve at Thanh Long, and not here.  Yet Anhnie T. remembered she enjoyed it and wanted to know if they made it at Crustacean.  Here's how good the service was.  The Captain (I'm assuming head waiter b/c he had on a suit), offered and called Thanh Long to ask for the drink recipe.  The Hanoi Sunrise was at our table within 7 minutes!  Just for that, they deserve 5 stars!

Everyone should get the idea with their Roasted Crab (sitting in a plate of tasty butter, salt, and garlic...lots of garlic!) and Garlic Noodles.  It's their specialty.  You can't go wrong.  And if you don't order it, you'll look dumb.  Simply put.  For example, who goes to San Tung and doesn't order their Chicken Wings?  Exactly.  

Usually one crab will feed one person, but if you're a small eater like Anhie T., then you can get by with sharing one crab.  Maybe order more appetizers or another order of Garlic Noodles.  

Believe the hype.  This place is well deserving of 5 stars!
author: Daniel M.

description: Extremely disappointed. To my disbelief, I was actually recommended to this restaurant by a friend. If you are looking for over-priced anemic shrimp spring rolls and wilted salads, you've found your spot. I value flavor in each bite of my food, and this place was simply lacking. In their defense, I do hear the crab and garlic noodles are good (which we, regrettably, did not order). If you do decide to go here, I highly recommend not deviating from that order.
author: Djamila D.

description: Roasted Crab + Garlic Noodles the best thing to get here. Great luxurious environment and great service.
author: Julio P.

description:
OMFG! My first time was just this weekend & I wasn't expecting much from the food.

We ordered the Roasted Crab & Garlic Noodles! I took my time, but devoured everything. Never had anything like it before.

Also, has the Lychee Martini...awesome drink.

And since we were celebrating my birthday, desert was a fried banana with a side of ice cream...good way to top off dinner.

Friendly server & waitstaff! Always good.

Although pricey, I'd go again.
author: Christopher B.

description: Roast crab and garlic noodles.  I go here or to Thanh Long every chance I get.  Some might think that the crab is expensive, but i think it's reasonably priced ($38 for a huge dungeness crab).  The garlic noodles are rather pricey for what you get ($10 for a bowl of noodles?)...but it's true: to some people it's the best thing that you'll ever eat...and it's what they're known for.  Desserts are ok.  The waitress recommended the fried banana which was just ok in my opinion...I would skip dessert here.  The most common thing I hear is that they're overpriced, but again...$38 for a whole crab is quite reasonable, especially when markets are selling them for $10/lb.  I'm a fan, and I'll keep going back when I have a chance.  Skip the drunken crab or tamarind crab...just go with the roast crab.
author: Jimmy W.

description: I am still swooning over the awesome roasted crab! The service was great and the garlic noodles were amazing! I have added this to my 'must revisit when in SF again' list. The BF had the miso short ribs and that was just as good.  I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!
author: AJ D.

description:
Despite some of the lackluster reviews below, I continue to be a big fan of Crustacean.  I've been to Than Long and PPQ as well, but I prefer Crustacean.  Than Long is out in the middle of nowhere, so unless you live in the Sunset, it's a hike with nothing else nearby.  PPQ is fine for the price, but, as noted above, I prefer Crustacean.  Don't get me wrong...it IS on the spendy side, but the expense is worth it in my opinion.  The garlic roasted crab and garlic noodles are quite possibly the perfect meal.  After my first visit to Crustacean a few years ago, I was so excited about my crab experience that I would literally stop strangers on the street and encourage them to try Crustacean for themselves.

In January a large group of my friends (15 people) and I went to Crustacean for my birthday.  I heard some gripes from people who didn't order the crab, BUT everyone who had the crab couldn't stop talking about it!  I'm not so bothered that the crab is frozen because, fresh or frozen, I know I couldn't make crab like this at home.  If you can and you like to entertain, invite me over!  I'll even do the dishes!

Two thumbs up for Crustacean!  It's expensive, but worth it!
author: Nicole R.

description:
I'd been here before but showing up at 9pm after a movie preview at the Lumiere, I'd forgotten how dingy the elevator area looked under the glare of the street lamps. Arriving upstairs the faux bamboo lends the entryway a seediness that's a bit too appropriate for the neighborhood. The Maitre 'd was discussing the need for a shirt with a collar for entrance with the couple in front of us. Inauspicious entrance.

One inside, however things took a turn for the better. The first thing I noticed was the decibel level...very low. The quietest place I been to since the Majestic Cafe. We could talk. The waiter came by and without shouting took our orders. We both ordered a Chimay Red and they went down easy. We continued with the Crispy Rice Paper Roll filled with chicken, mushrooms, carrots, mint and  vermicelli, served with daikon cole-slaw and " nuoc mam" dipping sauce. Very hot, crisp and delicious. We followed with the Skewered Beef  or Chicken tender slices of beef or chicken breast marinated with lemongrass, sesame and Asian herbs then grilled. Again, melt in your mouth tenderness. 

After our small plates we split a large plate and we decided on the Halibut, which I guess must be running given the ubiquity in restaurants about now. We also ordered the Fried Rice with chicken and a couple more chimays. All excellent. I was actually pretty surprised by the quality of the preparations. I was anticipating something a bit....less refined, I suppose. The service was fine...the house was half full. We were told the kitchen was closing at 9:30 and given the opportunity to order more. All good.

Given the location I suppose one couldn't complain about the condition of the periphery. I'll have to come back to try the crab, the specialty of the house. And yes, I will be back.

3.5 stars.
author: Gary C.

description:
I really don't know what the rave is about this place. I went there one year for my birthday since everyone says it is so good, but was quite disappointed. The wait was super long even though we had reservations. It took them a while before they even came by to give us some water and take our order. I thought the food was alright. Nothing special. The only items I would recommend if you do decide to go there is the crab and the garlic noodles. Those are the only two items I really liked there, but the garlic noodles is a bit pricey. I'm sure you can get garlic noodles somewhere else for a lot cheaper. 

I doubt I will go there again anytime soon. The wait was horrible, the service was bad, and the food was ok except for the delicous over priced crab and garlic noodles. The worst part of my experience was the wood divider they had up by their plants near our table fell on my best friends head. They didn't even comp us for that issue.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
Never Again!!!

I went there last night with my gf  and I was disgusted. First of all, the building which it is located smells like PEE! The host told us that there is a dress code and that my gf can't wear her hoodie.. (so she took it off.) The food is uhmm... blah. theres really nothing exciting/special about this place. It's also expensive. We could have eaten somewhere else.. Also.. the plates/utensils that theyre using looks like the ones bought at a cheap asian market. TSK TSK TSK.
author: Emcy G.

description:
So... after having to absorb some stuff at a conference for work all day, we decided to let some steam off by treating ourselves to something yummy! I've been to Crustacean's 10 years ago. Yes, you read that right, 10 years ago. And it's just as delicious as I remembered it. I think it says something if a restaurant has made it so long in a town like SF. Who can forget the garlic noodles (buttery, with good chew, and of course, garlicky - so not a first date food, wink wink) and the roasted crab. They do have 2 other types - tamarind and drunken but when I asked our waiter, which crab he said without hesitation, "It's been 10 years? Yeah, roasted bec/ you'll wish it was if you order something else". He was right. Was fantastic - finger lickin' good! I mean, I'm dabbing my fingers to catch some more bits of garlic, salt and pepper off the plate. Not good for the blood pressure. Anyway, we also had the following:

- I had the Pear Martini (tasty, not in a big glass so I had to have another beverage)... and the Bellini Martini (also tasty)...
- my friend had the Lychee martini (very good) and the caipirinha (true to form and I've had them in Rio and it was close)!
- seafood cakes (comes with 5 and it's like golden fried fish cake)  with pickled beverages
- grilled calamari with mustard sauce (several small squid grilled with nice char on the outside and nice and tender center) - very good. 

Too full for dessert... wish they had mango and sticky rice - my friend said they had it at their sister restaurant Thanh Long. 

Overall we were very satisfied and will surely go again someday (and I won't wait so long)! I was reminded bec/ I watch "Best Thing I Ever Ate" and the chef was featured for the crab and the noodles. 

(Oh, the street parking is a bit tough) We got lucky but it could be challenging if we hadn't.   :(
author: Kuishingal F.

description:
Garlic noodles and the roasted garlic was good. Service was great too!

I do have to say you have to pay everytime you order refills for soft drink. I know this restuarant is all fancy but they didnt have to charge me for every cup of soda I drank!!!! It is too pricey for everything too....
author: Joce B.

description:
Wonderful Place I would have to say!

My Boyfriend took me here for our anniversary. The service was extremely nice and the food was great.

I must admit, I did not realize it was a fusion vietnamese restaurant.  I was quite interested in their history and asked the waitress.  Surprisingly enough, she knew a little about the restaurant's history.

That was extremely impressive I must admit.  Well the food was excellent, I had the garlic roast crab with the famous Anh's Garlic noodles.  Topped off with a bottle of Riesling (my favorite)!!!

wonderful atmosphere, great service, pricey.. but you pay for what you get

Cheers!
author: Laurie H.

description: All the crab is frozen, and there is no butter in the garlic crab or noodles.  Methinks margarine and or shortening.  Butter does not congeal in to a white, greasy haze.  The secret of this kitchen is how they get people to pay $40 per frozen crab and fake butter.
author: Darin D.

description:
I was expecting an uppity like restaurant. There were a lot of random dates where the men were trying too hard to impress their dates. The food was decent so I guess the ladies should be quite impressed. The price was about right for seafood and the menu sounded very appetizing.

I managed to try a few things. The crab cakes were wonderful. It had an excellent flavor and texture. Not quite sure if I was impressed with the plating though. It was a little too messy. I also tried the rice paper shrimp rolls. There was nothing too special about it. If you want a bigger portion, I suggest going to your favorite Vietnamese joint for it. I tried the garlic noodles and they were great. Instead of the normal kind where they season it with garlic...the egg noodle itself was made with garlic.

The temperature in the restaurant was extremely cold. Minus one star for that because it made the food cold almost immediately after it was served.
author: Jacinta H.

description:
This is a Vietnamese/American fusion restaurant.  The roasted crab was delicious.  I had a whole crab and some garlic noodles but I wasn't satiated.  

It's a bit overpriced but the food was very good.  And there's a dress code.   

Try PPQ on Clement st. if you like roasted crab for a better price.
author: Phuong H.

description:
Last night was my first experience and will be my last experience here, EVER! I came here with some friends of mine. We were seated and immediately one of my friends was asked what kind of shirt was on underneath his jacket. My friend realized he wasn't wearing the proper attire so he did not have a problem keeping his coat on.

The waitress was very friendly, went over the options on the menu. All three of us ordered the roasted crab and we got two sides of garlic noodles. OK....the crab already costs 37$ pp and then they charge you another 5$ to crack it? Ridiculous!!!!! We brought two nice bottles of wine in which our waitress couldn't even open one of them. My friend had to actually open one of the bottles for her. Inexperienced?
Yes. Plus on top of that she asked us not to tell anyone but charged us for the corkage. LAME!

As we started eating our crab one of my friends was scared he was going to get grease on his Prada sweater so he took it off with no complaints from management. My other friend decided what the heck I am going to take my jacket off then. Out of no where this lady came up that worked there and said he either had to put on his jacket or she would bring out a button down long sleeve for him. I think she was F*%&(#@g with him because she brought out the most heinous shirt I have ever seen. He refused to put it on and lemme tell ya I would of too. She went and got management and this douche manager Mathew came over and spoke to us as if we were not about to spend 300$
He refused to stop serving us only because my friends would not put on their nasty smelling of cheap cologne generic shirts. At least let someone enjoy their dinner when they are dropping some money!
How does this place even have a dress code? It's not a 4 or 5 star restaurant because you NEVER have to walk up a flight of stairs to get to anything in that caliber.
I am done with this place and I make sure to go out of my way to tell everyone what horrible customer service they provide.
author: Kehaulani K.

description:
They're good but I've had better. They're VERY pricey for what you get. The service is superb, the ambience is quiet but nice. The roasted crab ($48) was decent - not full of flavor. You have to dip each crab meat piece in the butter sauce to taste the seasoning. The crab was fresh and a decent size though. The garlic noodles ($5) were okay, just a tiny bit over done. It surprisingly tasted more flavorful when it was colder. Maybe because the garlic and seasonings really infused in the noodles. *shrug* The (4) tiger prawns over the garlic noodles ($43) were good.  P.S. The photo of the crabs is helpful but you have to order TWO to get TWO. lol

Try Art's Crabshak, the crab is tastier and it's cheaper. Trust me.
author: Mayana P.

description: I was told "their thing" is the roast Dungeness crab and that it would be the best crab of my life. But truth be told, the crab was far from that... the meat was virtually tasteless - no nutty-sweet crab flavor at all. I suspect the crab was old or had been previously frozen to get a result like that. This was not fresh crab and shelling out $38 for that dish makes this place a pitiful trap for tourists or food ignorants... crab - zero stars. Two stars because appetizer was good.
author: M R.

description:
My husband and I have loved this restaurant since the day it opened 16 years ago.  The ambiance is lovely and upscale; the service is impeccable, and the food is really incredible.  If you want a cheap hole-in-the-wall, this is definitely not the place for you, but I don't like cockroaches, and most of the other Vietnamese and Wharf places I've been to have them.  UGH.

I've never found any flaws in the food.  The crab is tender and succulent, and the butter/garlic/pepper sauce Crustacean serves it in is perfect for dipping.  The garlic noodles are done al dente, with butter and a lot of garlic, and they're a must for any dinner, no matter what else you order.  If you don't want crab, Helene's Ravioli, delicate rice noodle packets stuffed with shrimp and garlic in a fantastic beurre-blanc sauce, is a great choice.  (I always have the crab puffs, which are creamy and crunchy, in a delicious honey-mustard dip, as an appetizer.)

Drinks can be wonderfully inventive.  If you give the bartender a list of ingredients or just generally describe what you want, he can make it for you.  The chocolate raspberry martini is my favorite, and I've had it with Bailey's, ice cream, Schmidt powdered chocolate, and many other ingredients, depending on my mood.

For dessert, I usually choose the bread pudding with a glass of Bonny Doon's Vin de Glaciere.

I always ask the wait staff to keep me supplied with hot wet towels and lemon water during the meal and they do.  Shell bowls for the crab are removed and replaced quickly and often.  Our waiter checks frequently to make sure everything is all right and we're OK with drinks and water.

Crustacean is a great place to bring guests to, and the people my husband and I have taken have all enjoyed it immensely.  We continue to celebrate holidays and big events in our lives here.  It's more than worth every penny we spend.
author: Giovanna M.

description:
GARLIC NOODLE is the winner !!! just by writing it down already stimulates my saliva =P~~   *drool*

Most of their cuisine are tasty and mouthwatering, the roasted crab, lobster, ahi tuna, calamari salad, and AGAIN garlic noodlessssss ! I've tried garlic noodles in another Vietnamese restaurant and they always came up different.

Some people says that Thanh Long is better than Crustacean but I can't find the difference (esp. seeing that they have the same owner). The place is slightly (just slightly) 'darker' than Thanh Long though, make it more like fusion restaurant. Overall, both are good...satisfy your tongue and stomach, but not really your wallet.
author: Jazzleen H.

description:
Alright, we know that everyone goes to Crustacean's for the fantastic crab and garlic noodle meals. For many years I did the same thing but wouldn't you know it, two years ago I developed an allergy to shellfish. 

Who in the hell develops an allergy to shellfish when they are 38 years old? Well, I did and when my aunt decided that she was going to have her 60th Birthday dinner there what could I do. There was no way that I would say no, I did what I had to do. Popped a couple of Benedryl's, braved the messy weather and headed up the stairs. 

It's hard to go into the establishment and not order the crab but our waiter Wil was very informative on all the other menu items and suggested the Roast Chicken Breast and it was wonderful. The curry sauce was delicate and not overwhelming and the serving size of chicken was more than enough to fill me up. I ordered the chicken fried rice with my order and really had enough to share with my nephew. 

I did catch a whiff of all the other crab at the table and yes, I did have a slight reaction but it was fine knowing that if the situation arises again there are things on the menu for the Shellfish impaired to order. 

Will was fantastic and handled our large party extremely well.
author: Shonna H.

description:
My boyfriend was dying for crab when we were in san fran and the concierge recommended Crustacean. His crab was awesome! I had corn chowder the steamed sea bass with asparagus. Everything I ordered was under salted so that was a disappointment. Also, my entree could have used something else, maybe a pilaf or risotto or something. the plate was ugly and empty. 

the server was nice, but absent. Also there was a table of Europeans who wanted to split their check evenly across 3 credit cards but the restaurant refused which I thought was odd for restaurant of this price range. That is a very common and relatively easy to do. She eventually (after about ten minutes) offered to try to get them as close to even as as possible. Why didn't she just to that from the beginning? It was complicated by the fact that they did not understand anything she was saying. I have worked at many restaurants and while at some it is difficult to split checks, its always possible. That whole thing annoyed me. 

The other problem I had was ugly decor, layout and building. yuck. I would probably have given two stars if it wasn't for that crab. its only saving grace.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I crave the garlic noodles!

Went here with a friend during lunch time. Luckily he drove because I can't stand parking in SF. He also ordered everything on the menu and I couldn't complain about any one dish. Will be dining here again.
author: Coral W.

description: Just had dinner here with friends and the lab kiddies (interns) last Friday. One of the kiddies hyped the garlic noodles as "the best noodles ever!" so of course we had to incorporate this into our end of summer blast.  At Crustacean, we all had the garlic noodles and the reason why they are so good is because of the butter that just overwhelms your mouth ... They really can lighten that part up. I had the shaking beef and hubby had the shrimp - both were delicious. We all shared the baked alaska , which was okay.  For the food and the outrageous pricing, I give this 3 stars.  Our waiter who was funny (even joked about my Yelping - is it that obvious?) and who gave the kiddies an extra dessert, he throws the restaurant into 4 stars!  Tip on parking - you can definitely find street parking, even if you have to walk a block or two.
author: Wendy A.

description:
I can't stop thinking about their Roast Crab and Anh Noodles. What is the recipe to those damn noodles??? 

My gf and I come here for our anniversaries and birthdays.  We really should try other places, but we keep craving their crabs and noodles.  

One time our waitress accidentally threw out our leftovers after we requested it to be boxed.  To make up for it,  they made us a fresh whole crab to take home! It was the best present ever. I hope they throw our leftovers again and again.   It makes up for the price you pay.

Parking here sucks...like most places in the city. You'll probably have to give in to valet.  boooo
author: Jay M.

description:
Crustacean Haikus for all to enjoy!

Steamy burning juice
Crabs!  Crabs!  All over the place...
They're not in my pubes!


High priced Viet food
Lice infested Tenderloin
Hello Crustacean!


Large bowl of pho please
Isn't this a Viet place?
Ninety bucks my ass!
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
Crustacean haiku
Roasted crab, garlic noodles
Good service, not cheap
author: Shawn U.

description:
Couldn't say it better than Percival N.  

SERIOUSLY PEOPLE!!!  VIETNAMESE FOOD SHOULD NOT COST THIS MUCH!!!  It's not even close to being authentic.  Garlic noodles?  Lemme tell you --- if I took my Momma here to grub --- I'd be disowned. 

The crab?  Being the sister restaurant to Thanh Long --- let's just say --- this stuff is what fiction is made of. 

SO NOT TRUE and IN YOUR DREAMS... fun to entertain the thought of it being somewhat decent --- but when the reality check comes, you're gonna find out you're BROKE.  For no better reason than you've been SERVED a really great bunch of wannabe foodies attempt at writing lame ass reviews about food I grew up on... that SHOULD NOT COST THIS MUCH!!!

Whew... 

Now about the service...
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
The roasted Garlic Crab and the Garlic Noodles are the things to eat here.  I've tried some of the appetizers and starters, and although they are good, I found that just eating the crab and the noodles are more than enough to satisfy your appetite.

A bit pricey, and it seems like you have to make a reservation or else eat after 9 PM.
author: Yoonsang Y.

description: Overpriced and not that great. Will not be returning.
author: Marco M.

description: crustacean has its unique niche in the bay area, an upscaled vietnamese style seafood restaurant serves probably the best crab dishes i have ever eaten , i had the opportunity to sample its drunken crab and roasted crab dishes during restaurant's early years , even though we were just a couple of poor students back then sharing the tap ,determined to sample helene An's culinary creation, now that i looked back, crustacean might not be an ideal place for romantic occasions since extracting crab meat can be a messy business , but it's ok to forget the purpose of the dinner when the dishes are awesome!!
author: Jerry S.

description:
Bib me!  Yes, you will have to wear a plastic bib to truly enjoy the best dish that they serve here - ROASTED CRAB.  The menu here is identical to their sister restaurant ,Thanh Long, in the Sunset.  So, if you want the same great meal without as much hoity-toityness, go there.  (Although, on comparing the garlic noodles, they were not as greasy here as they were at Thanh Long.)

Started things off with the Ohio Punch drink.  It came out looking pretty with its 3 different layers of alcohol, but I had to stir it... and afterwards, it looked gross.  Oh well.
