The small plates are terrific - order the "steamed seafood dumplings," "grilled calamari," and either of the rolls (I prefer the crispy rice paper ones but the soft ones are good and minty too).  We also ordered the Yuzu chicken and that was quite good as well, for chicken.

And then of course there was our crab and garlic noodles.  Both were perfect.  The only complaint was that one of the wait staff cleared away everything while I was obviously still eating.  That's a pet peeve of mine, as I like to eat every single thing - even those last 5 garlic noodles that were clinging to the side of the bowl!  He didn't give me that opportunity.  Grrrr.

The bathrooms are cleverly disguised along the walls (cool), but I was disappointed when there was only one stall and there was a lady getting sick in there (uncool).  I decided that I could wait until later and left.

Didn't try dessert... we were way too full.
author: Adrienne P.

description:
If you know what truly good Vietnamese food is supposed to taste like, do yourself a favor and don't go to Crustacean hoping for authenticity. You won't get it. Do, however, go in with an open palate (and an equally open wallet) because as far as fusion food goes, the An family reigns supreme. They have a true understanding of Vietnamese flavors and how to arrange them in ways that tantalize the American palate by making the dishes familiar yet exotic at the same time. 

The giant neon crab outside is sort of off putting but the inside is tasteful with a decor that harkens back to French colonial Vietnam. The wait can be long (even with reservations) and the waiting area is cramped.

Once inside, prepare your tastebuds for a feast. This is a great place to take rich people who are unfamiliar with Vietnamese food to experience Vietnamese flavors. (You may also want to get the rich people to PAY for dinner too because the prices aren't easy on the wallet.) $8 for spring rolls is way too much for my cheap ass but hey, if someone else is paying...

One thing you have to try if you make the trek is the roast crab. My husband and I agree that there's nothing authentic about it but damn if it isn't freakishly delicious. Must be the butter. It's also freakishly expensive so if you've got rich buddies, try and get them to pay for your plate. HA! And be sure to order the garlic noodles. Or do yourself a favor and order a double order (on your rich friend's tab, of course,) because the garlic noodles are really, really good.

This place gets four stars for the food but I'll take away one star for the prices and the fact that the neighborhood is kind of... well... not so great. Definitely get the valet parking -- it'll save you more than a few headaches and maybe a mugging.
author: Michelle N.

description:
I usually go to Thanh Long (TL) for my crabs but Crustacean is much closer and they practically serve the same food so I thought I'd give it a try.  The restaurant have a valet service but it appear to be much easier to find street parking around the neighborhood compared to TL.  The restaurant itself was pretty empty for a 6:30pm Sunday dinner and by around 8:30pm was about half full.  

Service was good and our servers/waitresses were pretty attentive with menu questions/refilling waters/exchanging bowls filled with crab shells/etc.  For anyone who goes to Crustacean or Thanh Long, the only thing they should really order are probably 1 of the 3 varieties of crab and garlic noodles.  Although the other items on the menu are decent, it's probably not worth the $20-$30 they charge per entree.  The garlic noodle is still one of the best (comparable to TL).  However, the roast crabs and drunken crabs we ordered were pretty much under-seasoned and my drunken crab was also rubbery and didn't taste fresh.  At $40 each, the quality of the crabs at Crustacean is no where close to what you can get for the same price at TL.  One person in our group ordered a Prawn entree which turned out to be 4 prawns and some garlic noodle for $40 also.  Lastly, the restaurant does not seem to provide free refill for soda as 2 refills of skinny tall glass (8-10oz?) with more than 60% ice came to around $9.  

It is unfortunate the quality of the food did not live up to the price they charged for our meal.  Although Crustacean appears to be a more convenient location (compared to TL) to get your crab fix, I'd recommend driving the extra miles to Thanh Long and get much better crabs if you're going to pay $40-$50 for your crab.  Although I'd give the service a 3-4 star, the food itself is probably worth 2 stars based on the price you'd end up paying.  If you want to enjoy really awesome crab, drive to Thanh Long!
author: Jack L.

description: Everyone has already said the same thing. So I'm going to just confirm that the roast crab is huge and full of awesomeness (that's what she said right? j/k). The garlic noodles were okay and for some reason Thanh Long's noodles seem to be more flavorful. Maybe I went on a bad day. They also have some special appetizers like calamari and lobster salad. We got the lobster salad and it was very flavorful. I might have liked it just as much as the crab if they didn't leave a sticker in my salad. Anyway, they actually had huge chunks of lobster in there. For dessert we ordered the Alaskan something (can't really remember the name). There was toffee ice cream, caramel, and banana slices in it. It was like a classy version of the It's It ice-cream sandwiches. Just get the ROAST CRAB, you will not be disappointed.
author: Frank L.

description:
I'm torn when I have to choose between the two An Family sister restaurants: Crustacean or Thanh Long. Both are almost identical in my favorite selections- crab puffs, roast crab and garlic noodles. The crab puffs are like crispy treasures with a smooth creamy filling that melts in your mouth. The roast crab, fragrant from butter and garlic is delicious and definitely worthy of me getting down and dirty with a bib and a crab cracker. The garlic noodles are tasty and perfect for any garlic lover.

Thanh Long feels more spacious with two dining rooms (upstairs and downstairs) and more spaced out tables. Parking in the sunset is also a bit easier compared to bustling Polk Street. Overall, I enjoy everything about Thanh Long a little bit more. However, in the end, Crustacean has a Baked 'Alaska' (chocolate cake, caramel ice cream, toffee mousse, meringue with banana foster) that one cannot even come close to.
author: Sara N.

description:
BAD service, CHECKED.
CHEAP dinnerware, CHECKED.
BAD seating, CHECKED.

Decor is nice and ambience is nice, but the hustle nad bustle of the place creates such a noisy atmosphere that it kills the ambience overall.  On top of that, the service was horrible and before we can even get our check, they already gave it to us.

The garlic noodles are to DIE for, though..... not soggy, not too garlicky.  The tamarind crab... its alright.  

ALthough their appetizers might soudns like regular vietnamese norm food, but there's a twist to it.  I ordered this lobster wonton appetizers and the mustard sauce on the side was delicous.  Great menu, no flaw to it really and the staff is very knowledgeable regarding the dishes on the menu, though.

If it weren't for the food, I owuldn't come back here... honestly.
author: Linh N.

description:
For years I wondered about the neon crab outside this restaurant.  Sign of cheese?  Or of the rumored awesomeness inside?

Seven us decided to venture in and check it out.  Reservations were challenging for a large group as they require a credit card...and if people cancel with less than 24 hours notice, they'll charge you $25 per cancellation.  And we had to fax in the reservation request.  I can understand their objective, but the process just seemed awkward...

Ambiance - old and dated.  It wants to be nice, and probably was great years ago.  Now it just feels a little dingy. Not terrible...just not great.

Food - We decided to order family style.  Some tables around us were doing this, some weren't.  For the 7 of us, we ordered 5 appetizers, 3 crabs and 5 garlic noodles.  

When we were trying to ask the waitress for assistance with quantities, we said that we were going to do family style because we all wanted the crab but didn't think we needed a full dish per person. She started saying - "Well...maybe 2 roasted crabs, 1 drunken crab, 1 of the other crab, 2 shrimp dishes, 1 this, 1 that..."  Uh...you just suggested we order MORE than 1 dish per person. Hmm...

The garlic noodles were definitely the hit of the group.  They are good and worth the visit.  I can see why some people might not be impressed...they were awesome when hot, but just so-so after sitting around.  We actually ordered 3 orders, then 2 more later in the meal.  

The roasted crab was good.  Messy. Fun as a group.  Probably awkward as a date.  The drunken crab was fine, but nothing special.  The appetizers were fine, but nothing amazing.  

We discussed that had the same food been served in some sort of hip modern room, we probably would have enjoyed the experience more.

All in all, I think this place is best for a group doing family style.  With a few bottles of wine, it ended up being $60 per person.  Not as pricey as some of these review had indicated, and worth it for the experience.  But it's clear that without the "volume" of people to split the dishes, we would have over-ordered and over-paid.

Glad I did it but probably won't be back for a while.
author: Todd S.

description:
Man I love me some crab.  There really isn't anything as wonderful to me as Dungeness Crab...well except maybe oysters, or caviar, or chocolate souffle, but you get the point...I like it, a LOT.  The experience here can be a little startling, I mean the crab is so garlicy and peppery that those of you that are used to adding your OWN flavor to the crab might be a bit offended.  I mean, this is NOT your usual lemon butter, however I found the experience to be quite enjoyable.  I enjoyed the addition of the garlic noodles on the side as well...I'm glad that the BF was with me or BOY would he have kicked me outta bed later. 

So, this is not the experience to have on a first date, cause you're gonna get messy.  This IS an experience to have with 12 of your closest friends for a merry holiday dinner with some decent, cheap chardonnary (they have got some good deals on the list) and piles of napkins.  This was great fun and I will definitely return with another group in tow.
author: Claire C.

description: I ended up here with a party of Taiwanese acupuncturists. Maybe it was the jolly mood of our inebriation, maybe it was sheer hunger, but once the crabs came it was a feast like no other. Anything tastes good with this much butter, but I did admire the fellow with the Druken Crab--easier on the stomach. Then again, the alcohol in our systems dissolved any build-up. Again, the crab was tender, large and cooked el dente. The garlic noodles were a perfect companion. The bill was a bit harsh, but hey, you gotta pay to play.
author: Brian J.

description:
I like it a lot actually. The food was excellent but it's toooooo expensive for me.
Because of the price wise, that's why I gave 3 stars only.
author: Mara B.

description:
If you have a special occassion or just want to spend some serious bucks when dining, this is one place to go ! Its garlic noodles and various crab selection are awesome ! Great flavors and definitely worth every penny. Save room for desserts too !

If you are on a budget. Stay away from this place !
author: Alvin M.

description:
like all the others said, this place is all about the garlic noodles and the crab.  period.  there really isn't any point in ordering anything else on their menu.  it's a nice restaurant, so if you want the same food with a more casual environment, head to their sister restaurant, thanh long.  

the only negative is that the garlic noodles aren't made consistently.  sometimes it's super galicky, sometimes there's not enough flavor, sometimes it doesn't come out hot.  otherwise, you won't regret coming here.   **i've come up with a recipe that comes pretty close to theirs, so haven't come back as often since, but i still get a craving every now and then.
author: Norma B.

description:
Get the Garlic Crab and Garlic Butter Noodles.  You will regret it if you are the only one not chowing down on this combination.

The best part is when they take the noodles and crab back to heat it up for you after 10-15 minutes of heaven.
author: Lewis C.

description: I love and enjoy going to Crustacean for birthday and anniversary dinners! Their ambiance is very elegant and their seafood is delicious! I usually like to order their garlic noodles and a roast crab all to myself! Service is great and is always offering to empty your bowls of shells.  Price is a little steep but it's well worth it!
author: Geraldine C.

description: Do I dare say 'garlic noodles'? :) We used to dine here all the time before my husband left the city. Great seafood and great service. Love Love this place, pricey but worth every penny!
author: Ava G.

description:
Located in what looks like an abandoned strip mall is this little gem of a restaurant.  As the name implies, if you are a fan of crab then you should try house specialty, garlic roasted crab.  Be ready to do a little work and getting a little messy cracking the shell to get to the meat.  You will be well rewarded for the effort since you will enjoy some nicely seasoned crab meat inside.  Don't worry about the mess.  They give you a bib, empty bowls for the discared shells, and plenty of napkins.  Combine that dish with a side of garlic noodles and a glass of wine and you will have a satisfying meal.

Some people found the garlic roasted crab to be a little salty and overpowering so just keep in mind that not everyone loves the crab.  As other people noticed, the decor is a little old and dated.  But the attitude of the servers and the quality of the food makes up for it.
author: Brent V.

description: Needs a Face-lift ,evident by the broken neon "Shea Stadium" inspired Crab out-front and a Food-lift, evident by the menu. Only thing that's up-to-date are the inflated prices. Wait aren't we in a recession??? I say take some of the Money that they are overcharging their guests and clean the place up a bit!!!
author: JAson T.

description:
worth the dinero. lobster w angel hair, the sauce blew my mind. thankfully paid for by my roommate's parents and otherwise never would have had an opportunity to afford more than a few drinks and appetizers.

Service was awesome, back table people watching was fun... LOOOOTS of tourists, but worth it worth it worth it.
author: Tyler A.

description: Way overpriced for what it is today (had great memories of the resto from 10 years ago and was sorry I went back).  The noodles literally tasted like garlic and oil on processed wheat.
author: K K.

description:
The crab may have been a touch dry, but the garlic sauce on top was amazing.  We also had the tasty garlic noodles, which I hadn't had anything like it before!  I also had a decent martini prior to dinner.

Overall, Crustacean was very good.  The waitress was attentive and the portions were plentiful.  I would love to go again, but the high prices left me saving my ducks for some time before I can dine there again.
author: Leigh S.

description:
I've been to this place twice and I have to say, damn, that's some good stuff!  Both times my friend and I ordered the same thing, the shrimp toast, papaya salad, garlic noodles and the crab.  I don't know what they put in that stuff, but its damn addicting!  

Now I just need a rich, generous person to take my ass there, cuz I'm a broke starving law student!
author: Jaime P.

description:
Completely over rated.
The food was a little better than basic, but it totally wasn't really worth the dollars.
I've made better garlic noodles in my sleep.
Coconut Shrimp. Eh.
The Roasted Crab was decent, but nothing to go back twice for.
Even after the whole 2 week planning, making reservations, and driving around in circles for about 20 minutes, looking for parking. And even going so far as to having a light lunch. I was starving like a dog when we got there. The menu conjured up the imagination of tasty delights. Sadly for me, that's about as far as it went.
I was really disappointed with the whole meal.
I didn't even want to stay for any dessert. Sigh.
The bill came. I felt sick with despair.
Oh well....sigh. It wasn't even worth this many words.
author: Kione E.

description:
Been here 3 times and had terrible experiences with the host/hostess staff each time. What's with the attitude these days? I just want to eat lady, quit eyeballing my outfit and point me to my table. My ribbed, lime green wifebeater fits me just fine (j/k... but close).

I love Thanh Long (sister restaurant on Judah St.) but I kind of hate this place, purely because of the snooty atmosphere.

If you need a roast crab and garlic noodle fix in a hurry and can't drive the 20 minutes to the other side of SF then drop by (don't forget your reservation), but otherwise make the trip across the city for much better experience.
author: Sangorama s.

description:
Three because you can't go 3.5.

Crustacean lives up to the reviews.  The good things on the menu are amazing.  The dress code is silly.  The drinks ... get the special drinks, but don't get a normal one.

The mussels are to die for.  Worth just going for the mussels.  Everyone else is talking about the crab and the garlic noodles.  They were good, but I'll go back for the mussels.  

One of my most used bio pictures, in fact, is a picture of their mussels.

So I'm saying Mussels.  They have a goofy dress code, so have a collar on your shirt.  It's important to them.
author: Jim B.

description:
So, what I gather from the other reviews is that "Crustacean Restaurant is good because it serves crab!?  Now, this may shock some of you but in fact, I have prepared crab (at my own home even) many times before - it's not that difficult.  

I could keep going, but instead let's focus on Crustacean's biggest problem: trying to enforce a dress-code in the TenderNob.  Let's be realistic, dress code must equal atmosphere and between the rough neighborhood and the discount furnishings inside the restaurant they've missed all around.

For the record, some of the food was ok, I remember the appetizers being pretty good but there are too many things wrong with this place and so many better restaurants in SF for me to ever waste my time eating here again.
author: Ryan P.

description:
If you love crab, you absolutely have to eat here! Have the roasted crab and garlic noodles, and you'll leave satisfied no matter what. Be prepared to be covered in butter, though, and don't let your crab get cold. As soon as the food arrived, almost all conversation stopped as everyone focused intently on eating every tiny bit of crab they could crack out. 

The service was top-notch - nice, professional, even funny. Our waiter told us 90% of the customers get the crab, but his other recommendation was for the sea bass which is marinated for 3 days! They also had as a special, salt and pepper calamari. It was the perfect crispiness without oiliness and seasoning. 

There is a dress code, but it's reasonable. No sweats or caps, but jeans and tennis shoes are allowed. The only major downside is that it is a bit pricey, but that's to be expected when almost everyone at the table orders an entire crab for himself!
author: Hannah C.

description:
i tried the crab and the garlic noodle, and both are delicious. both are very buttery. the crab is not as sweet as boiled crabs, but they are very soft and buttery.

I also tried a few appetizers, and they were all pretty good.

What i didn't like about the place is the formality. I just don't think that the food itself is that formal.
author: Jurgen J.

description:
Tourists and locals alike flock to San Francisco for the seafood, and one of the top things on the list is always crab. THE place for crab in San Francisco is Crustacean. I have yet to find a roasted crab that can beat theirs. And paired with garlic noodles? Let me just say... bring your buffet pants and some mints because you're in for some great grubbing. 

But nowhere is perfect... be sure to make reservations and come dressed nicely. (The wait can be long, and they don't allow guys without collared shirts.) And don't get the Drunken Crab. As good as it sounds, stick to the standard Roasted Crab. I promise you won't regret it.
author: eileen b.

description:
If it weren't for the garlic noodles, this restaurant would be average. But, because of the garlic noodles, this restaurant has become one of my favorites. While everyone raves about the roast crab, I found it to be good, but towards the end of the meal, the butter and the garlic became too much for me. 

However, a dish that many people don't try, which I highly recommend, is the Tiger Prawns. This is my favorite dish there - the prawns are also sauteed in garlic and served on top of the garlic noodles, providing some more flavor to the already good garlic noodles. The parking is difficult in this area - and everytime I have gone there, I have used their valet. Overall, a decent restaurant with average desserts, but with exceptional garlic noodles and tiger prawns.

PS - Make sure you come knowing about their strict dress code; while jeans are acceptable, all guys must wear a collared shirt to be seated in the main dining room.
author: Brian D.

description:
Two words: Quite pricey.

So I came here about a month ago on a double date for my 1 year anniversary with my boyfriend. Lucky for us we dressed less casual though I still had jeans on.  My friends were not so lucky... since we all didn't know it was a formal place... meaning you need a collared shirt to enter otherwise you'll be wearing an oversize yellow collar shirt that they provide you.

The food was good but in small portions.  I forget what exactly we had but I remember we both (both couples) loved dessert.  Our waiter service was really good but the price was very pricey.  About $200 in the end for four people.
author: Natalie G.

description:
Food: 5 stars
Price is pricey
Service: Excellent (better be for the price you pay.)
Decor: Fancy but then why o why o why?  You see ppl in suits digging in to crab.  That's just awkward.

So My hubbie took me to this place and seriously we both thought how good can garlic noodles be?  OMG it was the best garlic noodles EVER.  The Tiger prawns were excellent too!

We ordered 2 appetizers, 2 main dishes, couple of drinks, bill came out to be over $200.... yeah....
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Hummm... I don't know about this place. My first visit to Crustacean was the Beverly Hills location about 5 years ago. The restaurant was nice, the service was good, and the tiger prawns and garlic noodles were great. Yesterday, my girlfriends and I visited the San Francisco branch and I was NOT impressed. 

It was like stepping into restaurant not even affiliated with the Beverly Hills restaurant. I hate to say it, but the San Francisco branch is ghetto (and they have the nerve to have a dress code). My friends and I were seated outside on the top floor. The decor was terribly dated, the table clothes were not as clean as they could be, the windows were down right filthy, and I saw a waiter stuff a bunch of napkins under the leg of a table in order to keep it balanced. Mind you, this place is supposed to be fine dinning.

The food seemed a bit mediocre as well. It was good, but not as good as I remembered it. The garlic noodles are nothing more than chow mein noodles with a TON of butter and bits of garlic dispersed through out. Good, but not worth $9.50 for a side bowl. The tiger prawns were still tasty but I could of sworn that they were larger the last time I ate them. 

This restaurant's only redeeming quality was the service. My party was almost 20 minutes late, but we were still seated in about 10 minutes. Our waiter was great. He was very attentive and our glasses stayed full. We never once had to call him over.

All in all this place has okay food and excellent service, but it's not worth the price. There are plenty of other seafood restaurants in the Bay Area that taste much better and offer the same service.
author: Mia H.

description:
I went with my gf to do the dine about town here. First of all, the location of the place probably isnt the most ideal place to be in if they are trying to be a high class restaurant. They are located in a small 4 or 5 level strip mall. The very first floor is very dirty and it smells. We parked not too far from the mall and lets just say there are bums asking for money and what not. 

I heard there's a dress code for this place so I was somewhat dressed up and walking around that location is probably not a good idea at night. To my surprise the decor of the restaurant is actually pretty classy and really nice. The whole restaurant has great ambiance, definitely that asian feel. Our waitress was also very polite and friendly. She even offered to get me another type of wine since the one I choose didn't taste that good. The entries for dine about town didnt have a lot of selection so I got the beef and my gf got the prawns dish. The garlic noodle is very tasty. The beef was pretty good too.

All in all, I think I wouldnt mind going back but would probably be dress down a bit however given how far this place is to Freakmont I think that was our last visit. Overall, the restuarant is pretty decent but has very nice decor.
author: Christian T.

description:
I love crab!! So, my experience at this restaurant has been great so far. If you love crab, then I'd suggest you try this restaurant because they are known for their tasty "Roasted Crab." It's market price so the price depends on the actual day you go. The garlic butter seasoning makes the crab more finger-lickin' delicious. I love how they give you the whole crab! The "Garllic noodles" are recommended with your crab, but I suggest you order small plates as appetizers instead because the noodles are fairly normal (nothing special) and you'll be busy picking at your crab anyways. I would suggest the mussels in pesto sauce...yum.

Keep in mind that there is a dress code. For the men: if you forget to wear a button-up dress shirt, then no need to worry because they offer you one to wear during your stay (haha!). Overall, I've been here twice and ordered the crab both times. Next time, it'll be crab for me again! :)
author: Angellica Y.

description:
Dungeness crab season means a visit to Crustacean. The roasted crab and garlic noodles are fantastic! I've been here a few times and will not order anything else. I also love the bar, I've waited for my table a few times at the bar and our bartender made us "special drinks" which were quite tasty too. 
I did have one bad experience with the valet during one visit. Apparently they illegally parked the car and I received a ticket in the mail a few weeks later. A simple call to the valet service though and it was fixed.
author: Mani R.

description: Food is great. The Roasted Crab and Garlic Noodles is a must have. I felt that the manager was pretty rude. We just asked him a simple question and he said "oh please don't tell me how to do my job".  Poor way to handle customers.
author: Daven B.

description:
This place is pretty good i really have no complaints the food is kinda pricey but you know what you are gonna get when u come here. The food is good not to die for but is a good place to go with a group a people and be sure to get food that wont disappoint. 

Best thing on the menu, pretty much anything with garlic on the means is the best
author: Maurice H.

description:
I definitely think I'm a biased diner when it comes to fancy Vietnamese. I have superb homecooked Vietnamese food at my disposal (Mom) so I'm especially watchful of overpricing (even on the expense of my company).

My entree of shaken beef cost over $25 - which, in my opinion, is just too much - even though it was deliciously tender meat. We started with the lobster corn soup (this, I may give 4 stars to), beef carpaccio, and 2 other seafood dishes. They were all pretty good, just not worth the money.

So that's also where my review may be biased. I joined my team at work to dinner at a crab place even though I don't eat seafood. I didn't try the crab (my coworkers said it was good but PPQ in the Avenues is a cheaper, better option) and only ate the meat/veggie dishes. 

Overall, though, I can see why Crustacean is popular. It sits in a cute space and the service is pretty good. They don't allow casual tshirts and tennis shoes, though, so be careful!

Just 3 stars for me :)
author: Han C.

description:
DISAPPOINTED WITH THE FOOD GIVEN THE PRICE TAG - NOT NEARLY AS GOOD AS ITS SISTER RESTAURANT IN LOS ANGELES. 

My partner took me to Crustacean on Sunday night as a treat for cancelling our weekend plans and working all weekend.  I have been looking forward to going to Crustacean since I moved back to the bay area from Los Angeles because the one in Beverly Hills is divine.  

Unfortunately, I was rather disappointed with the food, especially given the price tag.  The restaurant was in a run down area of downtown SF, and the interior wasn't remotely as nice as the one in Beverly Hills - it's rather dingy and dark.  We ordered the seafood dumpling, roasted grab, tamarine crab, and garlic noodles.  The seafood dumpling had hardly any seafood.  It was mostly dough and wasn't worth the price for five small pieces.  The garlic noodles were good, but not really different from the garlic noodles at my neighborhood Vietnamese restaurant (Sunflower) or as good as the dish at the Beverly Hills restaurant.  Finally, the roasted crab was very flavorful, but again, didn't compare to the dish in BH, which cracks the shell so that the crab meat seems to just peel off without much effort.  (I didn't finish my crab because I just got tired of cracking the shell).  My partner ordered the Tamarine crab, and he said it was not good at all.  He was hoping for sometime spicy, but got a tomato-based sauce.  

The price was about $150 (including tip).   Too bad it doesn't live up to the sister restaurant in Los Angeles.  We left the restaurant disappointed, thinking that our visit would be our first and last.
author: Chegi P.

description:
Crustaceans is known for their garlic crab and  garlic noodles.  Been there twice and to the Beverly Hills restaurant once.  The only reason I go back if for their garlic noodles.  I know, sounds crazy huh...

The garlic butter crab is roasted well, but the seasoning is overly done which doesn't allow you to enjoy the flavor of the actualycrab meat.  Not only that, it is too salty.   Also not a good pick if you are on a date because it is messy and your breath will be smelling like garlic the whole night...unless she gets it too...LOL. 

My first choice of entrees would be the chilean seabass in citrus.  The fish is prefectly cooked to melt in your mouth and the amount of citrus used was perfect.

The decor is nice, with dimmed lights which create a romantic atmosphere.  Try not to get a table by the window because you will be constantly bumping into the party behind you.  You are pretty much crammed and packed like sardines.  

The service is a 6 out of 10.  If you must and happen to be in LA, try the one in Bevery Hills.
author: Joe T.

description:
Crab is totally over-rated and the clientele is interesting. However I do love their garlic noodles. They are to die for! 

I used to get garlic noodles to go!
author: K T.

description:
Their one saving grace is the garlic noodles.  Other than that, it's eh.  I hear Thanh Long is better and cheaper.  Although, the fact that they serve Fiji water in its own little metal container is kinda cool.  They don't have Grey Goose, but the Hanger Orange was pretty good.

Just get ready to get good and messy when enjoying the crab.  Oh, and put the bib on even if you think you look like a dork.  You do, but it'll save your clothes.
author: Alison N.

description:
My boyfriend and I just spent our nine year anniversary here on Monday...I had ranted and raved about this place, but prior to Monday, I hadn't been there in about eight years...

The service was crazy good. We ordered our appetizers and they were out in a couple minutes. Our drinks came with a quickness...the ONLY unexpected wait time was for our main entree, but we ordered an appetizer--so, the timing was just right.

Yes. It is a bit pricey, but it's not like I eat here on a daily/weekly/monthly basis. Once in a while, it's okay to splurge.

If I were to deduct a star, it would be for the annoying family that sat next to us...on the lower level on the other side of the glass. They had a major staring problem--and watched us get our bibs tied on and spoke in Vietnamese. (Duh. I know you're talking about us dumbass.)

The food was good...the dessert was great...and I can't wait to go here again.

P.S. HOW THE HELL DO THEY MAKE THOSE GARLIC NOODLES!??!?! THEY'RE THE BOMB!!!
author: Monica B.

description:
My ex bf and one of my best friends introduced me to this place.  I like the roasted or drunken crab, the garlic noodles are a bit on the greasy side, and the tiger prawns are OK too..  

I just can't believe the price!  Geez!  I love roasted crab but my hunger pains and then my patience starts to run thin with the enormous wait..  Then a few minutes later that roasted, drenched, and buttery crab gets cold..  Urrrrgggh!  =(

Not cool!
author: Kris A.

description:
I mean the garlic noodles were hella good, but $32 for four regular-sized prawns served over said noodles? Ridiculous. And why  waste a perfectly good crab by drenching it in butter and spices? I'm a purist when it comes to crab, so just couldn't get down with that.

Also, something about this place wasn't right. It felt a little, well, crusty. The old dim lighting trick couldn't cover it up.
author: Megan S.

description:
- Surprisingly good garlic noodles (overpriced)
- Decent crabs (decently priced)
- Not-so-creative appetizers (overpriced)
- Horrible soup (overpriced)
- Horrible champagne selection (overpriced)
- Horrible horrible service

Not sure why this place is so expensive.  They try to make this place like one of those high-end restaurants, but doesn't even come close to being one.  Save your money and go to Crab Shack...

Crab is better when you can get your hands dirty and wear comfortable jeans and T-shirts...
author: Min K.

description:
I've been here twice now and it's a great place when you're in the mood for their roasted crab...SOOO GOOOD!  Definitely a little pricey which is why I don't go all the time, but worth it for me every once in a while.

I was very happy with the service.  We had a party of six and I was running late due to work.  The hostess said they wouldn't sit our party until of course our entire party was there.  I felt bad since everyone was there but me.  My friends asked if they could sit down anyway and order for me and that I would be there shortly, and they said it was okay.  Turns out it worked great for me and my friends....they got to sit down, start with appetizers, and as soon as I got there, my entree was served.  I appreciate their accomodation!

We ended up staying there for 3 hours eating and chatting it up.  Not once did we feel rushed in any way.  I hate that when you go to restaurants....especially when the server doesn't offer you desert and just hands you the check.

So, the service was great, food was great!  I will definitely go back....it doesn't seem like the best neighborhood, but nothing happened to my car so I guess it's okay.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I cam here for may birthday  with my boyfriend and parents. It was pricey but oh so good!
the staff was supper nice and friendly and the atmosphere was nice also, which is a big part of dining experience! we all had the crab...AMAZING!!! and the noddles FABULOUS! i also had the salmon.. it was good, but i could have got the same salmon someplace else for cheaper. They even have valet woot woot! Basically if you come here the crab and noodles you will leave happy even if  you did spend part of your mortgage on dinner!
author: Kristina S.

description:
Was very surprised at the location and state of this restaurant since the restaurant in Beverly Hills is so inviting and well put together. 
Anyway, I had the crab (of course!) and the noodles. Crab and cocktails were excellent but noodles tasted over cooked/gummy....not edible at all.
author: Coco M.

description:
more like 3.5 stars.

I liked this restaurant. The location is very convenient, but parking can be hard. You can do the valet parking, but at 10 bucks, it's kind of steep! The restaurant itself is decent. It's not too fancy inside, but you can definitely dress nicely for this place. They have awesome service, very attentive and the food came out pretty fast. Now...onto the food. We got the...you guessed it, roasted crab and garlic noodles. Nothing too special. I also got the baked alaska, which was yummy! This place is good, but I'm not dying to go back anytime soon.
author: Christiana R.

description:
I understand that Crustacean did the upscale Vietnamese seafood thing first, but I don't know if they're still doing it best. With places like PPQ, Ana Mandara, Le Cheval, Slanted Door, The House, and Straits Cafe offering similar dishes at lower prices, Crustacean is now just one of many. With all that having been said, I loved the food and thought the service was good. The wine was good and not too overpriced. Our appetizers were just okay: the fried starters were very ordinary, but the vietnamese seafood salad was really good. For entrees we had a crab, shaking beef and sea bass. All were delicious, fresh, and worth checking out.
While the giant neon crab outside is anything but classy and interesting, the food is good albeit somewhat expensive.
author: Damian S.

description:
This place is yummy :)  But the price is kind of high :(  
I love the garic noodles (problem laden with butter) and the crabs are great - very flavorful.  I'm sure there is stuff just as good for less in Chinese restaurants, but haven't had the chance to look yet.
author: Piggy S.

description:
Their roasted crab and garlic noodles are delicious, though pricey.
Excellent place to bring non-locals (for the crab), and also very good for business dinners unless you really want to spend a lot of time talking with your customers (people tend to become quiet when eating crab).

Honestly the crab meat itself tastes better when you get them off the boat in winter at Half Moon Bay and boil them at home, but the way they prepare them with garlic is pretty amazing.
author: Durif M.

description:
There's not much that I can add that everyone else hasn't said already.  Their crab is amazing.  Get the roasted crab; it's infused with the most amazing spices and garlic flavor.  The garlic noodles.  It's a wonder how they make noodles taste so delicious.  I would pay to discover their secret ingredient and recipes.  

I always tell myself that the next time I come here, each person orders their own bowl of noodle and own crab.  I think this is the best place to go if you're not planning on ordering anything else.  On my most recent trip, I brought the entire family plus one to enjoy a meal here.  We sprung for appetizers and side dishes.  We ordered the calamari, beef carpaccio, and chicken skewers.  I have not been a fan of calamari for the longest time but the one here was really good.  We also got a tamarind crab.  In retrospect, I would have stuck with all roasted crabs but I wanted my family to try a different flavor so they would have something to compare it to.  They loved it all!

The service is great every time we go. It is a little bit pricier considering you can never get full off of seafood but oh so worth it to me.  Yum!
author: Jess C.

description:
The garlic noodles are amazing. I could have eaten another bowl if my stomach allowed... The crab is delicious as well. It's very messy, so I wouldn't recommend this place as a first date venue... The lobster salad appetizer is also very tasty and fresh.

I wasn't a huge fan of the decor. The restaurant opened in the 90's and it doesn't look like it has been updated since then. The carpeting on the floor and heavy drapery soaked in a lot of the grease over the years.

I'd definitely go back again for the crab and bib :)
author: Theresa L.

description: Tried Tamarind Crab, Rare Steak, Seared Ahi Tuna.  Great decor with great presentation.  Dinner for 6 ran up to $250.
author: Tuan N.

description: Crusty's is one of my favorites! The garlic noodles are almost as good as...just kidding, but the noodles are a must. The salt& pepper calamari and the beef skewers, yum. For those that say it's over priced or too expensive, stick to Red Lobster than!
author: Chris L.

description:
The food was good and so was the service. The ambience was not so good. I can't believe they were charging us a high price meal and have us drinking out of Ikea glasses! 

When my girlfriend made the reservations they made it clear to her that there was a strict dress code. When we arrived there were people in fleece sweatshirts and basketball jerseys. The location of the place looks like a frigging strip mall. 

Did I mention the food and service was good?
author: Manny C.

description:
You never know by the looks outside the restaurant that it is quite a good place to eat.  I haven't tried much of anything else other than my favorite meal which is the drunken crab and the garlic noodles.  I mean why try anything else when that meal is the best?

If you eat the crab you have a choice of the plastic bib and you get to have your hands get dirty.  Not for people who don't like to work to eat their food or much less not get dirty while eating their food.
author: Joy S.

description:
From reading the reviews of Crustacean on this site i was a bit skeptical, but overall, I left happy and fully.

First of all, you don't have to really dress up for this place, you can, but it's definitely not a requirement. I didn't at all feel that there was a pretentious or snobby factor. The hosts were nice and friendly as was our waiter and the clientele didn't seem pretentious either--I don't see how anyone can be too pretentious while wearing a bib.

Our crab puffs were excellent, though the calamari was a bit bland. The crab was yummy--I don't know weather or not it was frozen as some here complain--I don't care, it was delicious. And the best part was a fried banana with vanilla ice cream--yum.

It was a little pricey for two, maybe a once-a-month kind of place instead of a once-a-week, but it's a fun, nice place for a meal.
author: Lara L.

description:
Last night, my actual bday, Mr surprised me and took me to Crustacean. It was first for both of us. I was a bit weary because of some of my fellow yelpers review. 

I like the decor, it's elegant. 
Within 5 mins. our hostess took us to our table. Our waiter is awesome. He's prompt, courteous and fast. The other service staff is great too. 

We had a bottle of Navarro 2005 $38.00. It's fruity and perfect for our food and it's cheap. We were buzzed by end of dinner.

Appetizers: we had Salmon Carpaccio (OMG, it's sooo good)

Main entree:
I had Roast Crab ($36 average price) and Mr had Seabass. Of course, garlic noodles.

For desserts:
I had my free bday fried banaba with ice cream and Mr had some baked Alaska.

Total bill, $143 not including tips (not bad) pretty good price. (thanks to Mr) Oh for my bday gift "he got me smart technlogy furniture at Pottery Barn which my babe design". ^_^
author: jubi l.

description:
Sketch area, beautiful decor, and omg roasted dungeness crab. 

We dined here for a company dinner and what breaks the ice even more than alcohol, breaking into a dozen crabs with your fingers. Simply delicious and literally finger licking goodness.
author: Sara D.

description:
Asian-fusion and Vietnamese. Must try their famous crab! It is simmered in butter and topped with black peppercorn. Every piece of crab meat bitten will meat in your mouth leaving your mouth watering for more. Great garlic noodles! Oh..did I also mention, expensive BUT worth it?

No cell phone use. Casual/ formal wear required. They actually ask to not wear jeans. 

Great place to bring a date. Family friendly also. Their whole restaurant is dimmed and has candles lighted on every table. My server was attentive and very, very nice.
author: Chunky P.

description:
Came here once to celebrate the Bf's bday.

We ordered the typical garlic crab, garlic noodles, and some drinks.

the crab here was pretty good, and the garlic noodles here was better than PPQ.

We also ordered steak, or beef wraps, and was alittle disappointed because it was literally beef wrapped with something.....didn't really excite my palette.....

Not bad overall, but i prefer thanh long.
author: Shirley H.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE AND I LOVE CRAB! Me and my parents go every year for my birthday and we always get the whole roasted crab (sometime dad gets the tiger prawns over garlic noodles instead of the crab which he said is wonderful as well) ,2 orders of garlic noodles and garlic rice and a creme burlee to finish it off! Yea,it is kinda pricey, my parents spend about 1$50 to $180 but it's so f'in worth it! We only got once a year because of the prices ( when we go we like to get everything,we can't just go and stay on a budget :) ) but i always look forward to it. I'd so recommend this place. Yea, the crab is messy but um..duh! crab is messy in general,at least it's pre cracked so you don't have to really do to much work. 

Despite what others say, the staff is nice to us every time we go (we've been goin for the last 6 years) and our food is ALWAYS served to us fast,hot and fresh and the waiters are never hella slow, they do a wonderful job!

Overall, this is the best place in the world. Spending $120+ is worth it! I wish I could go more often but since we can't, my mom makes garlic crab at home :)
author: Fayla J.

description:
3 3/4 stars.

We went here for the first time to celebrate my father's birthday.  We started out with the Salmon Carpaccio and the Crab Puffs.  Not bad.  The Salmon Carpaccio was drizzled with a olive oil/balsamic vinegar mixture with thin-sliced onions, capers, and greens and was served with pieces of sliced garlic-butter baguette.  The Crab Puffs okay, sort of reminded me of Crab Rangoon and was served with a peanut/mustard sauce which I'm not quite sure complemented the puffs properly.

The roasted crab and garlic noodles were pretty good, although I wasn't completely blown away.  Maybe it's because I'm Vietnamese and the crab is a pretty standard recipe that most viet families know how to make, with slight variations among different families.  And like the crab, the garlic noodles were good, but this isn't the first time I've had asian-style garlic noodles.  

I had the flourless chocolate cake with amaretto whipped cream which was absolutely delicious!  The cake was warm and soft and along with the amaretto whipped cream made for a sublime flavor experience.  I also tried the creme brulee.  This may sound strange, but it tasted like old houses.  Let me explain.  You know that musty scent when you walk into an antique shop or old house that hasn't been inhabited for years?  That's what the creme brulee tastes like if that smell had a taste.  It's really weird.  My mom and dad appeared to enjoy the fried banana which the restaurant served on the house when they found out it was his birthday, which was a nice touch.

The decor was nice and the waitstaff was amicable and diligent.  The view wasn't that great...overlooking a couple of thrift stores.  However I did appreciate the option of valet parking since I'm not a huge fan of wasting 30 minutes worth of gas to find parking in SF.

I'd say that one experience here is enough for me since I can, more or less, get this kind of fare at home.  Crustacean would be a pretty fun place to take friends who aren't familiar with this kind of cuisine since the atmosphere and presentation would be a little more impressive than my kitchen.
author: Nana K.

description:
I'm sorry to say, Crustacean has gone downhill from what it used to be. My husband and I have celebrated our wedding anniversary there every year for ten years running. This last time the service was slow, they brought my husband the wrong dish, the interior where we sat was crowded (not because of people, but because of the layout) and the glass behind the bar was noticeably spotted. I wouldn't mind if we hadn't payed $150 for dinner, but when prices are that high, you expect better. The crab is still delicious (drunken is my favorite) and of course the garlic noodles are spectacular.

Oh, and valet parking is now $10 instead of $8. Oh well.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
My first time at the famous Crustacean. This family has been in business for along time and they have their schtick down pretty well. We had:

Garlic roasted crab - Yum!
Garlic noodles - Yum!
Lobster salad - Yum!
Shrimp rolls - Good!
Seared ahi tuna - Good!

Its definitely a very rich meal. We know the manager and he says that there are some people that come in every week for the crab and garlic noodles. That's a little much because its very very rich. But I'd definitely go back for more.

They DO need to change locations, they are in a really really weird building. Good thing the food is good.
author: Cat B.

description:
I have eaten here a number of times and also the other family restaurant, Thanh Long. They are exactly similar in food but the only difference is this restaurant is FINE DINING, meaning you need to dress up to eat here. I did not like the neighborhood it was surrounded by but the food was excellent. Parking also was a downer but they do have valet parking. I did not valet because I figured I would find a parking spot nearby, buI forgot I was in San Francisco and it is always hard to find a place nearby. I parked about four blocks away but I did need the exercise. 
I consumed the dungeness crab with the garlic noodles. The restaurant is known fort his and there was no disappointment. The service was good and I found it quite comicall when the waiter placed a bib on my date and myself. Price wise it is very expensive but I would go again due to the quality of the food.
author: Pete N.

description:
The drunken crab was really good.. and big.  It better be big considering it was $45!  I also had the corn and crab bisque for an appetizer.  It was pretty watery and only had a little tiny bit of crab in it.  Disappointing ;(  If I wasn't having crab for my main dish I would be totally bummed.  We also had the seared tuna appetizer, which was really bad.  The fish was obviously not fresh - tough and fishy...  eek!
The valet parking service was awesome.  They even went out of their way to fetch birthday cards that we left in the car. Elevator was slow and the ventilation in the place was awful. We were like "oh man, we're gonna have to dry clean our clothes after this."  The entire restaurant really needs a face lift.  
Overall, the crab was awesome... I would come back on a special occasion and will probably just order the crab and the garlic noodles.
author: Kat L.

description:
i've been craving crab lately and didn't feel like driving to thanh long.

sure, the decor could use some freshening up but this place still gets packed on the weekend.

the mixed salad was so-so.  not overly impressed with the dressing.
i did like the asian pear slices though.  gave it a nice crisp.

still loved the crab and corn bisque so that was a must order.  

this time, we went for the roast crab and garlic rice.

my, my, my.  def better than the drunken one.  it was so funny to see people dressed up and wearing plastic bibs but very practical.

while one shared was not enough (we arrived with rumbling tummies) but the second one arrived immediately.  it was as if they had the crabs lined up and ready to go.

it's probably the most unsophisticated thing but i almost wished i had a straw for my wine.  i hated grabbing the glass for a sip with "crab hands."  

the hot wet towel was a nice welcome.   mmmmmm...love crab.
author: Anh V.

description:
Wow, this is the most overrated and overpriced restaurant I have ever been to. 

We had the salt and pepper calamari as an appetizer - it was decently good. We also had the crab puffs as an appetizer - also decently good and the sauce that comes with it was excellent. So I thought we were off to a good start.

But then the main dishes came. We had the tiger prawns (one of the house specials) - no flavor whatsoever. They were accompanied by the famous garlic noodles, which were OK, but I can name at least 2 other places in the Bay Area you should go to that have 100 times better garlic noodles (and that are also way way way less expensive). We also tried the catch of the day, which is cooked in turmeric but didn't taste like anything, and was accompanied by these noodles that literally looked like they were boiled in water and thrown on a plate and had zero taste.

Finally, we tried the ever so famous roasted crab - what a disappointment. It just tasted like normal crab, with some garlic flavor added. Nothing special. And the whole rest of the evening and the next day I just sort of felt sick from the garliciness of it. Certainly not worth $37. And the overall dinner was most definitely not worth the $175ish that we paid for 2 people. I expect much better food for that price.

Also, the service was pretty crappy. And the chairs are unbelievably uncomfortable. The table was way too small - with all the main courses on our table, we could only each fit an appetizer plate on our table which we had to put on the corner of the table and eat at an uncomfortable angle.

Waste of my time, money and calories.

Go elsewhere. I can recommend much better Asian, and Asian fusion, restaurants for those interested.
author: nawabzadi h.

description: this place is the best crab hands down.  Get it ROASTED.  I have had it all three ways and roasted is the best.  Rich and flavorful and messy and yummy.  Get the garlic noodles and any of the appetizers.  The place is a bit funky and old school inside.  But always consistently excellent on the crab!!!
author: Daisy B.

description:
Like the previous reviewer, I finally had a chance to go dine at Crustacean for some seafood this past weekend. I must say the food there was quite good. We started off with some grilled calamari along with some lobster salad. Ordered a bottle of white wine to wash it down with the seabass. I did not try the crab this time since I did not feel like wearing a bib. Overall it was good, not great. A little pricier than I expected. Oh well, you have to try a place at least once to find out.

P.S. The host asked me to wear proper attire to the place, however I saw some guys there wearing a T-shirt. Go figure.
author: Mike C.

description:
after reading the fellow yelp reviews, we were hesitant to check out the crabs - but our craving for the roasted crab and the garlic noodles won us over and we are very glad that we followed our crab needs. here are few things you should consider when checking out crustacean:

1. kallista martini is perfect - not too sweet, not too sour, just right
2. coconut prawns are way better then the dumplings - hands down
3. if you come to dinner late, do not devour the crab too fast
4. butter is good - garlic butter is even better - even more better surrounding a huge ass crab
5. garlic noodles - do they have it to go? it's so much better then a slice of pizza for a late night snack
6. it's a lot of money for a dinner on tuesday night, but it's definitely worth trying once in a while
7. will be back for that fried banana!
author: Dot K.

description:
First time there, loved the food and the service.

Their garlic noodles were the best I've had in a long time, Taramid Crab was a first for me, and I must say I enjoyed it.  Just sitting there with smell of roasted crab in the air made my mouth water.  It is a must for a return.

Only four stars because they actually gave us the wrong crab to begin with.  We had like 2 waiters, the person who brought our crab actually brought the wrong one, so our primary waiter had to go track down the crab we ordered from a different table.
author: Clifford C.

description:
The only thing upscale about this place was the service, the food and ambiance, unfortunately, were mediocre. 

Everyone at the table did enjoy the garlic noodles, but I think the ones at Poleng are much, much better. The rest of our food was so-so, a beef dish was luke-warm and under seasoned, the crab dishes were good, but overpriced. If I'm going to eat crab I more often than not just want to pick one  up at the market, steam it with artichokes, and serve it with butter and sourdough. To justify spending upwards of $30 on a crab I'd hope that it would be unusual and spectacular. Crustacean just didn't cut  it.

I hear that their other location is much better.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description:
I came here maybe about a month ago.  I've driven past the area quite a few times, and never noticed the restaurant.  Finding our way up was interesting.  We had to take this really sketchy looking elevator to the restaurant....which was nicer inside.

My boyfriend introduced me to the restaurant.  I didn't know what to order, so he did the honors.  We had the prawn cocktail, garlic noodles, angel hair pasta with lobster, and some sort of fennel ravioli pasta thing with shrimp.  
-The prawns were HUGE and juicy...yum.
-Garlic noodles were tasty.
-Angel hair pasta w/ lobster was pretty good.  Could have been a bit more flavorful....
-Fennel ravioli thing was...interesting.  It was like an asian fusion thing with like rice noodle on the outside rather than the typical ravioli dough.  

We had a small table in the corner..and it felt a bit claustrophobic.  They seriously crammed as many tables as possible into the restaurant.  

Overall...I wanted to give 3.5 stars...but decided to round up.  I didn't get to try the crab...so I definitely want to try that next time...
author: Jenny K.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE. i would go here once every two weeks if i lived closer. it is pricey but well worth your money! im craving it just sitting here writing a review on it.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Our waiter was excellent...if I'm not mistaken, his name's Paul.  He made our dinner much more appetizing.  The roasted crab was tres delicious.  The truth is, I'm not a fan of crabs.  However, I was totally another person when the roasted crab was placed in front of my friend.  I was hoping and wishing she would have offered me at least half of it.  It was wishful thinking, of course!
author: Sarra L.

description: I had dinner there with my girlfriends on Monday.  Every year we celebrate our birthdays at either Crustaceans or Thanh Long.  It's been over 10 years no.  We do not share...one roasted crab and one garlic noodles each.
author: Sandy L.

description:
Okay so this is how my night started out. Hey friends lets go enjoy some really good Crab. Friends" okay lets go". So we pile up and head out for our hour drive to the city to Thanh Longs our originally destination, unfortunately that was ruined by some misc. fight that broke out. Glass, plates, chairs, noodles and crab were hurled across the restaurant. 

So friends and I decided this was not the place to be, but still determined to get crab, we drove to Crustaceans the sister Restaurant to Thanh Long. We call immediately after the fight and make a reservation for 10 pm. We get there and we wait until 10:25pm we were seated and immediately greeted by our rude waitress who advised us that the kitchen was closing in 15 minutes so she needed to take our order now. blah blah blah other people were late for there reservations so we suffer. Yeah whatever. 

So friends and I are like okay no problem we are ready we know what we want we just came from your sister Restaurant due to an altercation that took place. Her response " oh, what would you like to order?" Orders are placed. Then she returns to take our drink orders, she returns with drinks setting them on the table she states "we don't do free refills" as if we couldn't pay for more than one cup of soda. Geez rude strike 3. We order appetizers, she says oh they will be out with your food because the kitchen is closing. Okay we get the point the kitchen is closing. We have already had a horrible experience now we are being like children. okay whatever we are hungry. The food arrives finally, only for us to realize that it is room temperature Crab at room temp gross the flavor was great but it was cold, not cool. Hard crunchy rice, cold noodles and filmy spinach. We are not happy. She never returns, I ask another waitress for a fork, she never returns. We complete our luke warm meal and without seeing our waitress ever again. Friend #1 speaks with Restaurant manager who is awesome he sends over Joel who we now love and adore with excellent customer service. Thank you Joel for rescuing us from the "kitchen is closed hurry up and order waitress". Joel and his manager rolled out the red carpet for us, which is the treatment we should have received when we walked through the door. 

Please note if you go to Crustaceans and anyone tells you the kitchen is going to close just politely grab your things and leave because you will regret your experience and it will leave a sour cold crab taste in your mouth I guarantee it.
author: Sonya W.

description: This is one of the best crab restaurants in the bay area. Every other place I've been to is a distant second (Fishermans wharf, Alimango, etc.). The roast garlic crab and garlic noodles are awesome. As a garlic lover and crab lover, I was in heaven. We ordered 2 large crabs and left a leg. I think I ate most of it. This is one of the better restaurants I've been to. Worth the money, nice ambiance and I didn't have to dress up at all. Jeans and sneakers is fine here.  Highly recommended and I'll go back again!
author: Ryan A.

description: Made a reservation about 2weeks ago for Mar 23 @ 7:30pm for my bday dinner. The morning of Mar 23 we get a phone call from the restaurant asking me to confirm our reservation at 8:15pm. Told them that I made reservation for 7:30pm. Long story short...they pretty much told me the reservation is at 8:15pm and no apology given. What a disappointing customer service.
author: Jocelyn M.

description: Incredible roasted crab! Goes amazing well with the garlic noodles. Yummmmmy!
author: Shao H.

description: Not sure what all the hype is about.  Their Dungeness crab is way over priced... and nothing to write home about.  Their garlic noodles was mushy and blah.... thought they overcooked it so sent it back... but they brought back the same. And I couldn't believe how salty their roast halibut was.  I took 2-3 bites and just had to set it aside.  Seriously... what's the big deal?  I was sadly disappointed and honestly quite angry that they charge so much for such below-average food.  I definitely don't plan to return any time soon.
author: M T.

description:
Service was good, but the meal left something to be desired. Entrees were greasy and lacked flavor. Of all the restaurants in San Francisco I would not waste time on this place. Decor is dated and the area seems like a ghetto...not the best setting for a "fine dining" establishment.

Drinks were well prepared and the dessert was tasty, but overall a disappointing experience.
author: Mike M.

description:
My friend and I checked out this place and didn't even get the crab, though this seems to be the clear favorite among the rest of the guests.  My friend had the seabass which I would give 3-stars as decent.

I think I had the winner with the Vietnamese "fish of the day", I wasn't even sure on the exact fish but was described as "a softer white fish similar to halibut".  The sauce was A-M-A-Z-I-N-G.  I'm not even a big fan of seafood   but this dish has given me hope for future considerations.

As a heads up, there is a dress code (jeans and sneakers okay)
author: Ken S.

description:
The food was wonderful!
we went with a rather large group (10 or more..) and the waiter was more than accomadtating with all our requests. i ordered the crab and didn't even get to finish it. it was needless to say HUGE. we sat outside on the deck (but it was enclosed with umbrellas and heating lamps. it was awesome and would go back.
author: maria a.

description: I had a celebration dinner here a while back.  Drop a lot of $dough.  We were seated in a private little corner, which was okay with me, but donr forget that you seated us here.  Anyways, the food is practically the same as Thanh Long.  In fact, I believe they are the same owners.  I'd prefer Thanh Long over this place any day.  Again,  it's ashame that I'm not a crab fan.  I Lobster!
author: S F.

description: Love the prawns and garlic noodles. Something about the sauce from the prawns drenched over the noodles adds a little more zip to the noodles. The various roasted crabs are devine! The prices for this establishment are expected due to the location and ambiance. Reading the other reviews who are taken back at the prices, this isn't your standard Vietnamese pho house! The service was great and they have a full bar.
author: Ready To Be S.

description: Outstanding!   The garlic noodles and the roasted crab were heavenly. Only wish they would have served some french bread to sop up the butter.
author: Carol A.

description:
It's a dressy/ fancy restaurant located in a not so classy area. I mean it's literally across a discount thrift store. Also their entrance, elevator and stairs is not what you'd expect when entering a formal dining restaurant.

However, the food is just superb! Their roasted crab is just flavored PERFECTLY for you to enjoy all its seasonings! I mean everyone who hasn't tried their crab is missing out big time! It is worth the price! Their garlic noodles are aslo very yummy! Overall we went home feeling very happy and satisfied!
author: Sharon D.

description: Very pricey and not the best of locations. I went here for my boyfriend at the time's birthday and I was not overly impressed.
author: Laura K.

description: LOVE this restaurant.  Have been going for years and consistently have friendly service and quality food.  Love the roasted crab, garlic noodles and salt and pepper calamari.  Don't try and order anything else or you will be disappointed.
author: Allison U.

description:
Great food, great service, nice ambience, just do it!

Recommendations: Roasted Crab and Tiger Prawns on a bed of garlic noodles.
author: Michael C.

description:
I head to Crustacean when I have a hankering for crab.  I did just that yesterday night.  Things haven't changed much at this place but it's a sure hit for steamed crab and yummy garlic noodles.

I've had the tamarind crab on a prior trip and though the sauce was tasty, but a bit too sweet and messy.  The drunken crab, simmered in a broth of three wines hit the spot.  Their fried calamari appetizer is perfectly done.  Oh, and you can't have crab without the garlic noodles.  

This place is slightly overpriced but a great place for seafood.  The decor is pleasant but could use an update.  

The place tends to be packed on any given night, even a Tuesday, so make sure to call in for a reservation.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Definitely not a "first date" place but a must whenever you are in the area.    A lot of oil and garlic go a long way to make you drool - none of which would be helpful on a first date!  The atmosphere is pretty good in the restaurant but upon entering the location it is a little dirty - but that may just be the city.

This restaurant is a stop I make whenever I am in the area!
author: Jen D.

description: This is my FAVORITE seafood restaurant without a doubt!  My husband and I come annually for our anniversary... Roasted Crab with Garlic Noodles... man there's no place like it!!!
author: Taylor T.

description: Crustacean is one of those upscale restaurants where you are paying more for the decor than the food.  The food is good, especially the roasted crab and garlic noodles, but pretty expensive.  For a cheaper alternative I rather go to PPQ.
author: Katherine C.

description: I didn't really enjoy the crab here unfortunately.  I was really looking forward to eating here since I've always heard such rave reviews on the crab.  The crab I had wasn't very flavorful and the other foods I had weren't as well.  The garlic noodles were okay, but very light on the garlic.  We had some noodle dish the waitress suggested, but it didn't taste like anything at all...just like a plain bowl of noodles.  The service was great overall and that's what made the experience better.
author: Peggy C.

description:
The food are very good but nothing fantastic to write back home about.
We started off with the grilled calamari, crab puffs, seared ahi tuna and the salmon carpaccio. Of the 4, only the grilled calamaris' really got my attention, it was really good. The crab puffs was a waste of money, oh well, my daughter ordered it. Nothing but minced crabmeat on wonton wrappers then fried or at least it looks like it. The seared ahi tuna was ok too, a little too cold but ok. The salmon carpaccio was quite tasty as well but what did they use to slice it? Razor blades? Man those were super thin. So thin the slices that my wife joked about it that it looked like the plate was garnished with some sauce but where's the salmon! But it's good. 
My mom-inlaw and I had the lobsters, the wife, daughter and the dad-inlaw all each had the roasted crabs and the son had the crabs with the tamarind and wine thingy on it.
I guess I got used to having lobsters back in the east coast that my expectation here was a bit maliced. The meat was really soft, again maybe it's just me, otherwise it was quite tasty. Everyone else seemed to like the crabs they ordered. The garlic noodle was way over hyped! It's just pasta, lots a garlic and boat load of butter. We all know that you can drop a couple of dozens of butter sticks to anything and that would be divine. Nuff said.
For desserts, we ordered 4 fried banana ala mode, it was nothing new but still pleasant to have. The daughter had the lemon sorbet that she said was good, I believe her.
We also got a cream brûlée, I'm sorry but I had better ones from a cruise ship. The cream stuff inside was too soft and the caramelized sugar cover was too thick. I love sugar, anything sweet and all but man the glazing on these should be thin and they still should have that "break like glass" properties.
A little pricey but all-in-all the family liked it and that's all that matters.
Stay away from the crab puffs!
author: AV V.

description:
Food was yummy, so I give it 3 stars.  Enjoyed the roast crab and garlic noodles.  The crab seemed fresher at Crustacean than Thanh Long.  I tried the green papaya salad and calamari but did not like the flavor.  The food service staff service was good.  

But for a so called upscale restaurant, I was not impressed.  And if they enforce a dress code, I expected a very nice restaurant.  At least fix up the bathroom.  To me, the restaurant looked a little dated.  Maybe it's just preference, I like the more simple, modern look.  My experience at Thanh Long was far better, much more relaxed.  I especially liked the no dress code part.  From the host to the food service staff, all friendlier there than Crustacean.  The food was basically the same.  I think the crab was fresher at Crustacean, but I tasted more of the garlic butter flavor in the crab at Thanh Long.    

I would definitely return to Thanh Long when I crave the roast crab and garlic noodles again.
author: Little one C.

description:
When I'm craving their delicious garlic roasted crab and don't feel like dressing up to dine in the restaurant, I place a takeout order.

You can't order takeout over the phone, but have to actually go there in person to place an order.  It actually is pretty fast, I only waited about 10 - 15 minutes for my order.

The garlic roasted crab takeout is put in a rectangular foil box with a paper lid.  Then they wrap it up in a plastic bag and put it in a nice quality brown paper bag with handle, which makes it easy to carry, especially since I was walking.

The takeout garlic roasted crab is just as good as eating in the restaurant, but at home, I don't have to feel silly in a white plastic bib.
author: Cathy A.

description: The food at Crustacean Restaurant was as good as it has always been for the past 8 years. However, the service was simply horrible. We went there recently for dinner with a company of 6 people and the waiter was inattentive and simply ignorant of our group. The service means a lot especially to our group and it simply lacked this time. I strongly encourage the owners to provide additional training to their staff.
author: richard p.

description: I've been to the one in San Francisco and Beverly Hills.  The ambience was soooo cool in Beverly Hills.  They have a glass pathway through the downstairs and what's cool is that there's a Koi pond underneath the glass so you can see the fish swimming around down there.  Lighting is a little too dark but not bad for a romantic evening.  In SF, I had to wear a coat but in Beverly Hills I didn't.  I'd still dress up a little for this place though.  Roasted garlic dungeness crab with garlic noodles...awesome!!  One of the best meals I've ever had.  Be prepared for the bill though.  Think the bill came out to ~$150 for me and my wife, but it was a special occasion and well worth the cost.
author: Fred K.

description:
If you love dungeoness crab and don't mind digging in like real crab eaters like me do (I host about 6 crab boils/feasts every year)) then this place is heaven.  Don't bother with anything except the roasted garlic crab and garlic noodles.

I brought a bunch of European collegues (and their chi-chi European dining ways) here for dinner once and even they got into it and were messily cracking away at their crabs and licking hteir fingers.

Only four stars cuz price is on the high side.  Normally about $35-40 per crab so about $60-100/person depending on how much you drink.  I also find the setting a bit of a misfit - not that Crustacean isn't nicely decked out - but simply that crabs is messy eating better suited for a dive joint (if they could only make garlic crab like Crustacean does)!
author: Q S.

description:
November 7, 2010
Crustacean closes at 3 for break I guess. End of Daylight savings. We got there at 2:19 PM. "Table for two please." "I'm sorry, but we close at 3 and re-open at 5." "But it's only 2?" "No it's 3." OMG!!!!! IDIOTS!
author: Soukii A.

description:
Heard many times about its garlic noodle and roast crab. Give it a try........but disappointed.

I have been to the PPQ ( the clement one) for the lower end version of these. I would say they taste about the same but Crustacean overcharged.

We have five people. We tried 3 crabs and 5 garlic noodles. Sadly, nothing surprise. But I may say PPQ did taste better.

The services were quick and I may say "too quick". My friend's fork were taken away before she finished the garlic noodles.......

For the dessert, we have 3 orange sorbets. They look funny because the container is the real orange. I know this kind of fruit shape sorbet is common in Japaneses food. But this is the first time I see in Vietnamese restaurant.

Finally, the bill came. Guess what, it is almost $270 with tax and tips for five of us with only 3 crabs, 5 noodles and 3 sorbets.

OK, fine. We have tried the famous Crustacean and we are done with this. Nice for try but not for return.
author: Pod l.

description: Discovered this precious little gem on the Food Network, and oh my lordy it is the absolutely stunning. I love the ambiance, the service is fantastic, and the crab and garlic noodles practically melt in your mouth. If you think you don't have room for dessert, find it! Because they have a delicious banana's foster and chocolate cake that is absolutely to die for. My mom and I make sure to dine here every time she is in town because she is from The OC and is deprived of this fabulous slice of heaven.
author: Amanda H.

description: i really dont like spending too much in one spot, but i had NO REMORSE when i paid for my food! everything was amazing! cant wait to go back
author: Shaunte A.

description: Didn't realize that there is a dress code for dining here but lucky for me, I was dress well enough. Not sure why anyone would want to wear a shirt and tie when you are about to dive into some crab. It's definitely messy the way I eat! The food was good, but not worth the price IMO. It's a nice restaurant but felt a little bit stuffy to me. I like to dine where I feel relaxed and not sure if I'll be returning any time soon.
author: Hieu D.

description: Took the girlfriend to this place after a trip through chinatown for lunch this past Sunday.  I wanted to let her try the garlic noodles and roasted crab. The other two dishes we tried: salmon on crisp shrimp chips  and the ahi tuna were disappointing. I didn't even want to finish the tuna it was so bad but we were paying $14 bucks so I had to suck it up and finish. Pretty much the only reason to come here is for the roasted crab and garlic noodles.  And the  thing is, if I want to get roast crab and garlic noodles, I could just go to Thanh Long which is cheaper (both places are owned by the same family).  The girlfriend loved the grab especially the salt and pepper outside, she kept on licking it.  That was the highlight of the meal. Price with tip was $45 per person, not worth it.  Just go to Thanh Long!
author: Andy B.

description:
omg, will you guys please listen to me on this????  this place is totally overrated & overpriced!!!  like totally!

food was alright....i mean, it didn't suck, but i was not impressed - especially for the price we paid. 

my friend joked and said crustacean is one of those...."cheat the white folk asian restaurants" hahaha!!! i almost died! delivering mediocre, asian gourmet food and charging an arm and a leg (maybe even 2) for it is a crime!  i definitely felt cheated and i ain't even white!  

satisfy your crab cravings somewhere else, such as a reputable restaurant in the richmond neighborhood for 3/4 the price. go to singapore for their peppa crab if you're feelin' adventurous.  i bet your plane ticket will be less than your final tab at crustacean.  

i can't even imagine how their beverly hills location is playin' it off like it's haute cuisine.  spare me!

bottom line, just go somewhere else.  you've been warned.
author: Kevin W.

description:
All I have to say is that I've died and gone to heaven...

Every time we have a visitor from out of state we bring them here.  The Roasted Dungeness Crab is the BEEEEST!
author: Valerie C.

description: The Roasted Crab is fantastic. In my opinion, the garlic noodles are way over-rated.
author: Rachel A.

description: There are 2 "Secret Kitchen Specialties" you must try - The Roasted Crab and the Garlic Noodles. The crab is roasted in what seems like an entire stick of butter, garlic, salt, cracked black pepper and other spices.
