This buttery, salty sauce is so good that you will find yourself licking your fingers. In addition to the crabs, Crustacean's is famed for their Garlic Noodles. The noodles taste as if they have been marinating in a garlic sauce with little hints of garlic. The sweetness of the roasted crab complemented the garlic noodles perfectly. I can eat an entire roasted crab and bowl of noodles to myself.
author: Kepi M.

description: Very expensive for not very good food.  The "famous" garlic noodles were just ok.  The crab was pretty good, if a little too buttery.  The lobster dish I got was not good at all.  It had some sort of tomato sauce on it that made it taste like lobster spaghetti...ew.  Bottom line: there is better food for much less money just about anywhere.
author: John S.

description: Despite them claiming to be a Vietnamese restaurant, the food tastes NOTHING like Vietnamese cuisine.  However, that doesn't change the fact that their food is savory and D'Lish!  The ambiance is to-die-for...but then again, you pay for what you get!  This is a great place to take and impress a date =)  Everyone must try the infamous Garlic Noodle and their dessert (I don't remember the name but it had chocolate cake with caramel and ice cream).
author: T. T.

description:
Love this place just a tad less than Thanh Long, simply because of the parking situation and the lack of ordering over the phone.  The noodles and crab are just as good here, and there are actually more items on their menu.

The atmosphere in this one is definitely unique, and makes for an interesting dining experience.

Overall, this place makes my top list of places to eat in the city.
author: B F.

description: Every October when my good friends come over to visit we make it a point to go to our favorite Crab restaurant and that's crustacean in SF.  We look forward to the great tasting garlic roasted crabs and garlic noodles.  The service and the food have always been consistent and I usually give it a 5 star rating.  However yesterday when we went for our yearly visit we were greeted by an unfriendly receptionist.  Since we had a reservation for 9 and six were already sited in the lobby we requested to be sited at our reserved table and he seemed annoyed at this request and told us in a stern voice to wait for the other 3 instead.  First of all I don't see the logic in it , we could have sat at our table and ordered drinks while waiting and second we are customers and shouldn't be spoken to in a rude manner.  If the food weren't so good we would have walked out of there.  But next year we are seriously thinking of looking for another venue.
author: edwin N.

description: Everytime I come here I try not to get the Crab but I allways do...hahaha I love it but the people that work there could be a lot better .... and the Garlic Noodles are allways a 10 .....
author: Trevor R.

description: Unfortunately, I had a bad experience on my second visit as the food was severely delayed and unfortunately, our server did not even offer an explanation to the reason of the delay.  Our food was getting cold and so was our appetite so we just headed out and had it "to go."  The only thing they offered to appease us was a free dessert...huh? Too bad, the food I admit, is good and even worth the price to pay but customer service is 50% of dining experience.
author: Grace D.

description: This used to be my go to for out of town guests, but I think the last dining experience killed it for me. The food is tasty, but when paying as much as we did, I would have expected much better service! They kept trying to take away our plates before we were even finished with our meal, then we couldn't decide if we wanted dessert so we ordered two teas, and asked for a menu. The waiter dropped off the menus, 5 min later dropped off tea for ONE person, then disappeared for a good 15 min. When he finally did return, he didn't say anything and just dropped our bill on the table. The tea was nasty so we didn't want two cups anyway(we didn't drink the first) but to not even ask us what we decided for dessert (which was 3 different ones) was absimal. We decided to just pay the check instead of even bothering to order dessert. You would think with a $300 bill the service would have been much much better. Left the evening with a sour taste in my mouth, and definitely ruined dinner. I don't care how good your garlic noodles and roast crab is, service like that was unacceptable and I won't be back. Take your money elsewhere for a much better dining experience!
author: Felecia M.

description: I don't get to the city too often but when I do I have to get good food and how can you turn down garlic crab and garlic noodles. They have a great balance of garlic and are delicious. Always get your crab cracked to make it easier to pig out! Service is okay but then again we had a large party so the tip was factored in...usually service is not up to par when they know they are getting an 18% tip. Overall I absolutely love their delicious garlic noodles and crab, garlic breath and all.
author: Courtney R.

description:
Oh my god! Coming from Sacramento, we heard so much rave reviews about this place. At the time (about 6 months ago) this place think it had 4 stars.

All I have to say is "Why?"

The $10 "Garlic Nooodle" was just noodle and garlic mixed together. It look like crap and it taste like $3 noodle plate worth.

The almost $30 Sea Bass taste like crap. 

Geez! Are people insane to give this place such a high rating?

This place is way overrated and overprice.

Oh..and the furniture was dirty.

we couldn't even finished the sea bass nor the garlic noodle.

It's all hype.

Hey, if you have money and feel stupid, give it a try.

YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED

Service? 3 stars

You Bay Area people are insane giving this place anything over 3 stars.
author: Nikita B.

description:
Roasted Garlic Crab: Good worth $38
Garlic Noodles: Good. worth $10
Fried banana w/icecream: OK (got it for free as a bday)
Pepper Calamari: OK, reminded me of the kind you get at normal chinese places though.
Waiter service: EXCELLENT
Ambiance: OK
Restaurant location: area is Eh...not the best to take out of town guests to if you want to impress them.

Not sure I'll go back but it was a fun place to have a birthday party, esp if you go early (say at 5:30)
author: Win H.

description: If you want to go here and don't know what to try, you must try the garlic noodles and Roasted Garlic Crab.  That is what they are known for!  I've been going here for many years but it seems like their food has gone down hill a bit and there is no longer a wait when you come to eat here...However, Crustaceans will always have a place in my heart for the garlic noodles!  Others try to imitate but this place is the real deal!
author: Jessica C.

description: The roasted crab is what drew us to this place. We all had our own crab and needless to say we were in garlic buttery heaven. The garlic noodles weren't as impressive as everyone says but none the less the crab is what what will keep me coming back.
author: Mizzie C.

description:
I'm not sure what it is about Thanh Long and Crustacean's owners;  they just so happen to pick locations of their two fine SF restaurants that coincidentally are within mere feet (walking distance that is) to utter skankiness and/or crime and grime. If you read my review of Thanh Long below, that restaurant is in a neighborhood that suffers from periodic Asian gang violence and shootings (not covered by your favorite media of course). 

As far as the more upscale Crustacean restaurant goes, within mere moments you can have easy access to Skank Francisco, aka tenderloin, dirty streets, homeless pestering you for anything, and then some. If you forego valet parking, you might have to drive further down to some really nasty ass places for street metered parking. Hopefully you don't have to pay the homeless guy to "watch your car for you" while you eat. 

When Crustacean first opened, family insisted on coming here instead over Thanh Long numerous times due to more comfortable surroundings, at the time newer settings, and if I remember correctly valet parking which was something you'd never see in Outer Sunset.
But all that trouble for paying more, forcing men to put on a collared shirt with pants (no jeans) and in the beginning not clearly stating whether a tie was needed? Doh. I've seen respectable older mofo's come in here with a Hawaiian shirt and shorts, and they are wisked right in without problems, while I flabberghastedly screamed silently upon witnessing this, garbed smart and casually, but not metrosexually. Maybe the dude's a regular? Who knows.

My last visit here was 7 years ago, and that meal was quite good and definitely better than Thanh Long. The tiger prawn with garlic noodle dish here however was not that stellar, but still decent. The best item however was their rather overpriced but really strong and well done Vietnamese espresso with condensed milk on ice (aka cafe sua na), served in a fancy frou frou like hard liquor glass. And the best part? They gave me those two tiny black stirrers that also functioned as straws. Not quite Jimmy Bond Vodka Martini, shaken not stirred (wait isn't that bubble/tapioca milk tea??), but it made me feel like a high roller. I'm glad that I can get the same very well done coffee at Vung Tau in the South or East Bay, for less attitude and money, but if you happen to be here, at least that won't disappoint. The beef or was it salmon carpaccio appetizer was decent, but nothing really mindblowing.

7 years ago this was still a good place to impress a date as I have done in the past. But given the numerous restaurants and cuisines (similar to that effect) competing for your dollar, the magic seems to have flown the coop.
author: Ken K.

description:
My review averaged almost 2 stars:

1 star - PARKING:  Valet parking if you're not a veteran at finding street parking in this area.  No attendants on arrival.
1 star - AMBIANCE:  In broad daylight, you can clearly see the condition of this restaurant's interior.  The décor needs to be refreshed.  It's showing signs of wear.
0 star(s)  - CLEANLINESS:  Darkly stained carpet everywhere.  Stained waiting couch.  So grossed out I was afraid to use the restroom. 
2 stars - FOOD :  CHEWY lobster in my lobster salad (the mango was a nice touch and the dressing was good).  Other persons in my party liked the corn bisque.   We all ordered the signature roasted crab served without the shells ($15 extra charge).  They were unable to provide crab without the shells due to lack of kitchen staff.   The crab was good but not great and there is too much butter.  The Baked Alaska was good.
3 stars - BEVERAGES:  Mixed drinks, alcoholic & non-alcoholic + cappuccinos were good.
4 stars - SERVICE:  Host and wait staff were all attentive.  Waiter offered 1 free dessert as an apology for lack of kitchen staff and inability to provide signature roasted crab unshelled.  Bibs were offered.  
1 star - COST:  I am happy to pay for great food, no snobbery intended here, but the San Francisco Crustaceans restaurant, given all of the factors above, charges 5 star prices for a subpar dining experience.
author: L L.

description: Rude valet. Slippery stairs when wet. Worn furnishings. OK service. Yummy-sounding menu. Okay shrimp toast...a little overcooked. Overcooked crab...very crumbly. Not impressed with the infamous garlic noodles. Even the flourless cake dessert tasted a little...off. Dunno....just wasn't good. The next time I want crab, I'm going back to the Franciscan at Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Karen Z.

description:
Crustacean has been my top favorite restaurant in San Francisco. I always order their super delicious Roasted Crab and their "to-die-for" garlic noodle!!!! Recently dined there, and tried their shaken beef and it was great too.. After dining here for tons of times, I've found my new favorite in this restaurant, their special LOBSTER SALAD!!! omg!!! it is to die forrrrr... i love you, crustacean!! and yes, I prefer crustacean than Thanhlong!! Not because of it's atmosphere, but after trying thanh long for few times, I can conclude that the garlic noodle in Crustaceans taste better, and the crab is more flavorful.. :)

Dont forget, wear dressy clothes!! Ive seen some people got rejected to come in cause they were wearing sporty hoodie and tshirts..
author: Cherish S.

description: My sisters and I took our mom here for her birthday last Monday. I've been to this location once before and it was as good as my first time! We started with the Crab Puffs...YUM! Then, Tiger Prawns and Garlic Noodles for me. Seriously, I cleared my plate! Mom ordered the Garlic Crab and Garlic Noodles and LOVED it! I will starve myself for a day and go to the gym everyday the following week to eat here again! Service was great. Yes, a bit pricey but it is Crustaceans. Save your money to eat here. It's so worth it!
author: Grace B.

description: To tell you the truth i was Little disappointed.. people compared Crustacean to Thanh Long.. no comparison... i love Thanh Long.. they dont have the salt and pepper calamari, or salmon carpacio, or even there Thanh long mussels... sorry it was just ok for me.
author: Shirl C.

description: The roasted crab is awesome!!! So flavorful!! The whole crab was roasted in butter, salt and pepper. Absolutely delicious. Garlic noodles is a must! My friend and I shared the whole crab and two small plates. We ordered prawns wrapped in pancetta. Great appetizers. We also had the asian bouillabaisse made with sea bass and a spicy tamarind broth. Really delicious. For dessert, we had the banana wontons with vanilla ice cream and chocolate bread pudding with vanilla ice cream and poach pears. The bread pudding with okay, but the banana wontons were a winner. The decor is pretty romantic: dim lights and a view of polk street. I would definitely go back to try another type of crab.
author: Denise L.

description: We celebrated a birthday over the weekend and had a rather large party. We were seated quickly after calling and asking at the hostess desk to add one additional seat to the table. Our head server had our table and one other table that seated 4 people. Once she took our drink and food order that was the last we saw of her. We had to continue to wave the bus staff down to ask for beverage refills. The head waiter returned 20 minutes after taking our order to let us know that something was not available, however did not offer a menu for alternative options. The bus staff spilled water all over one of the tables and attempted to drop a napkin in an effort to soak up the water. We asked for a new table cloth and in the process an entire pitcher of water was spilled behind us on two people. Still no sign of the head waitress. When the food arrived, half of it was ice cold. At this point, we wanted to get the management involved. "Sean" comes over and says "someone asked to speak to me" with a major attitude. We proceed to tell him our challenges and he ask "what do you want from me". The worse service I have EVER experienced, especially for paying 700.00. I will never visit this establishment under any circumdtances.
author: Kay C.

description: this will always be one of my favorite places to eat. you cannot go wrong with the roasted crab, garlic noodles, and a glass of riesling. i dont even like to eat crab but i get so excited to eat at crustacean b/c their crab is AMAZING! i always want to try new restaurants, but crustacean always seems to be my first true love -- they never fail to keep my tummy satisfied.
author: Stella C.

description:
For a party of six girls, we ordered a traditional vietnamese salad, a salad of seafood, pan roasted halibut,  three garlic noodles, and two roasted crab. 
The salads were smaller than expected and was good but not so "traditional". We were very disappointed about the roasted halibut. The fish was so small and had a lot more mashed potatoes than fish. The fish was okay, not as fresh and the mashed potatoes tasted better!  I would probably not order this again. 
The last two dishes were the best and goes well together. 
Noodles were perfectly cooked with a garlic-butter-parmasean seasoning. The crab( 2-2.5 lbs each) was delicious! Usually there is more flavor on the outside, but maybe roasted crab help penetrates the flavors into the crab meat. Yummy! It seems like the roasted crab with salt and pepper was the popular crab choice, but next time I would like to try the tamarind or drunken crab. 
And make reservations because it was so packed on a saturday night. Although we had made reservations, we still waited about an hr. It was pretty busy and took an hour for our food to come out.
author: Hanh H.

description: The Dine About Town prefix dinner at Crustacean wasn't a good deal imo. Garlic noodles and prawns for my entree? What was I thinking. $20 corkage fee if you bring your own wine. Service and ambiance was pleasant. I should've gone with my instinct to go for the crab instead.
author: Teddy B.

description:
so my BFF calls me on sunday and says, surprise, i'm coming to town for one day and that day is tomorrow!  oh, and i need to eat at crustacean.

well, thanks lady, i miss you too!  anyways, we usually prefer thanh long bc of the slightly more relaxed atmosphere but of course they're closed on mondays so we made do w/ reservations here.  because we are nice girls, we decide to bring our boys along too.

however, my boy is filipino and he is workin' hard for the money so he says he'll be late.  for those unfamiliar w/ folks operating on "filipino time", that means that there is a 1-1.5 hour window of time he's alloted himself to arrive after the scheduled meeting time and not consider himself, in fact, "late".

originally, he thought he'd be working super late so he declined the request to join us for dinner.  however, the more he thought about it, the more he realized he couldn't pass up an opportunity to clog his arteries a little w/ crustacean's wonderful garlic noodles and roast crab.  of course, he showed up about a half hour after we were served (very promptly, btw) and my two guests were already polishing off their last crab legs and eyeing the dessert menu.  no worries, as our waiter immediately served my husband his crab w/in minutes of him sitting down.

so, this four star review is mostly in part to the outstanding service we received from our waiter and his complete understanding and accomodation of "filipino time".  we made it out of there five minutes before the next party for our table was due and were completely satisfied.

i'd give a fifth star if a) there were better street parking options, b) there were more than just four measly (but tasty) tiger prawns on my meal and c) if they'd lose the dress code.  let's face it, guys in collared shirts lose all that class once they have to don the plastic bib to grub on crab legs.
author: Carol O.

description: THE BEST CRAB I'VE HAD IN MY LIFE!!!!!  My friends all know me as a craboholic.  I started weeping tears of joy with my first bite.  It took me over an hour to finish it, but there wasn't a morsel left.  I told the waiter I could eat another one! Well, I would have to only have crab, and skip the appetizer and dessert.  OK, maybe just 2 crabs and 1 bowl of garlic noodles.  I want to go back now!
author: Kristen K.

description:
Okay, if you come to SF, you heard about this place.  Try it anyways?  well, I tell you it will not be a great experience.    
Crabs are prepared much better in some other Chinese or Vietnamese restaurants.   Garlic noodle......  out of question.
I guess only those people who enjoy food soaked in oil will enjoy this place.
author: Tomo S.

description: I think it was about 2 years ago that Jenniflynn R. planned a Dine about Town to Crustacean and I thoroughly enjoyed not only the company but the CRAB...the roasted crab...finger lickin' good...and the garlic noodles were just as good...BUT WOW that Roasted Crab...I could've licked the shell if it wasn't so odd
author: Karen B.

description:
best roast crab ever!!!   moreover!! hte garlic noodle is good too
however, there's dress code, so better watch out
author: Gary k.

description: I really liked the Roasted Crab here.. will have to come back to try the other flavored crab. It was sure finger-lickin-good! The crab puffs were also very interesting and surprisingly enjoyable. Can't wait to go back!
author: James D.

description:
This restaurant made me violently ill 3 nights ago, and the others in my party moderately ill.  We all ate garlic noodles.  We all at a bit of lobster roll.  I was the only one who ate mussels.  What caused the sickness?  Don't know.   But this is the first time I've been sitting at a restaurant and 2-hours into a leisurely meal had to run to the bathroom so as not to vomit on the table.  That night, I had a fever and chills.  The following day I was still nauseuos, and my dining partners started to feel ill.  I am still  not 100% better almost 72 hours later.

Food poisoning?  Maybe.  But I suspect the amounts of MSG in their food.   It is what makes the noodles so addictive to everybody.  There are many types of reactions to MSG, ranging from those that seem like food poisoning, to severe heartburn, to migraines and muscle/joint pain.  It is the only explanation that explains all of our symptoms, as most food poisoning comes with abdominal pain and cramping, vomiting, etc - but the heart burn and acid reflux are particular to MSG reactions, and that was one of the symptoms we shared.

Shame on Crustacean for saying they don't use MSG on their menu, and yet putting it in their signature dishes.

I will not be dining here again.    I am seriously bummed, too, because I had been looking forward to the experience.  The only saving grace is that my friend had a gift certificate, so we only had to pay for the tax and the tip but not the food that did us all in.
author: Nikole P.

description: Crustacean is highly over-rated. Sure, the crab is tasty and so is the garlic noodles, but then again, almost all the upper end Chinese restaurants serve delicious crab at a fraction of what Crustacean charges you (close to $40 each when we were there -- maybe more now). Everyone in our party ordered a crab and the other two, fish. I am a slow eater when it comes to crab so half way through my crab, the butter on my plate had congealed. I waved the server over and suggested that perhaps they could serve this dish with tea candles under the plate to keep it from congealing. The congealed butter completely put me off the crab which is why I give this 3 stars. Compared to crabs around the Bay Area, this is definitely among the top 10 in flavor, but the price does not justify what you get. Take into consideration the location, the valet parking and now, the celebrity hype and there you have the reasons why your crab comes to 40% more than other restaurants.
author: Anita L.

description: Great good here, but I was very upset with the service. I made a reservation and arrived 20 minutes ahead of time. I was told to wait until the appointed time, yet when it was the time of the reservation many other guest with out reservations were seated before me.  The waiters were rude and I was not compensated for the wait. The whole reason of a reservation is to be seated on time, yet they let others walk in and are given seats. What horrible service!
author: Nicholas L.

description:
Choose another restaurant!  There are so many great places to eat in San Francisco and this is not one of them.  First, the atmosphere is terrible.  It's on the third floor of a rundown shopping center.  The inside hasn't been updated in years.  Second, the food is just so-so....especially for the price.  The corn and crab bisque is bland and has about 3 pieces of crab in it.  My husband got the catch of the day which was nothing special...the rice noodles that it came with had no flavor.  I got the roast crab (which is supposed to be their specialty).  It wasn't terrible, but I certainly wasn't full afterwards, and you pay $37 for just crab...nothing else!  People seem to like the garlic noodles, so we ordered some...they were okay.  My husband and I love good food and got a recommendation to go here, but I feel the need to let everyone know that it's not worth it!  If you are someone who likes Red Lobster a lot, this place may be for you.  

By the way, I use yelp a lot, but have never written a review, but knew I had to go home right away and write one for this place simply because I want locals and visitors to look elsewhere!
author: Julia G.

description:
I hated the cold hostess with the scat-a-tude,
then found this item!!! hahaaha....servants of the betrayers...yes, sounds as if the scatology continues amongst this family dynasty.

Not really worth the price versus the low grade palate...BUT go if you want to experience the 'tude.

From: L.N.
Subject: RE: [VWF] VN 

Date: Sat, 28 Jul 2001 13:07:57 -0700
There aren't any good VN banquet places in Oakland/East Bay (maybe the new May Hong on webster/14th would be okay, but haven't checked it out yet). I've eaten at Le Cheval for a banquet once with the Huong Viet folks. We all vowed never to eat there again. Other than some of the staff, we were the only Vietnamese people in there. The service was bad, bad, bad. Waiter was a white guy who spoke no Vietnamese and got our order wrong several times and we ordered in ENGLISH! (why they would give us a white waiter when there were several other VN ones is beyond me). Basically we had to send the VN busboy to go fix our order. They gave us a scoop of mango ice cream as free service since he messed up our order so much when we should have gotten the courses themselves free. The food was binh thuong. Not very special. It reminded me of fast food generic Asian/Chinese food rather than being VN; Cam Huong the VN deli on Webster is better by comparison. The vegetables weren't very gio`n, and everything was drowning in corn starchy sauce (oyster or soy). ;oP Le petit Cheval is better and cheaper too (more Asian clientele since it's right by UC Berkeley campus), but it's still very fast food like.

Crustacean's is another bourgie colonialist "Eurasian" restaurant in SF and Beverly Hills. Don't have anything to say about the one in SF, never having been there, but the one in Beverly Hills is a trip. My bro used to wait at the one in BH, which was very trendy for Mr. & Mrs. Melanie Griffith, FranDrescher and the hollywoodites to dine. It has very beautiful decorated. French colonial style fans, mosquito nets, bamboo/wicker. The biggest draw was the glass covered koi pond that ran through the entire restaurant. It is admittedly very beautiful, but most definitely not Vietnamese style or authentic Vietnamese food. The snooty An family who run the restaurants claim to be the glorified hereditary chefs to the emperor. Or as my mom says, that just means they were lowly servants to an insufferable, petty, in-bred monarchy. She can't figure out why people love to claim connections to the Nguyen dynasty since they sold out Viet Nam to the French colonizers in the first place. Anyways, so they have a "secret kitchen" where the An's prepare their special secret family recipes. But their head chef down in BH isn't even a member of the family; he's a very nice Vietnamese guy who got hired after he immigrated from VN and they keep him locked in this little kitchen. And they use frozen seafood, because they know their white clientele can't Taste the difference when the food is fresh or not... and they treat the Latino & Asian staff like crap.
author: miriam b.

description: I've never thought I'd have trouble finishing a single crab, until I ordered the roast crab here.  The portion is so HUGH it's like nothing I've had before.  The garlic and spices made it really tasty.  However, the extra portion and spices also mean lots of cholesterol and sodium, not for those who have high blood pressure concern.  Also, be prepare to get really greasy and bust out your shell-cracking skill as you drive into this dish of delicacy.
author: Chad S.

description: One of my old time favorite places since 1993. Last time I was there Nov. 07, was a memorable date and   a great start  for special friendship to this day  has become a satisfying realtionshipt.  The interior((between semicasual to fine dining),cozyness, and not too fancy but food is very appealing..you would never go wrong with family or a date you really like!
author: cecille p.

description: Don't waste your time with the menu.  Go straight for the roasted crab and garlic noodles.  Oh, but you'll need the wine list.  Bon Appetit!  = )
author: Trang W.

description: Garlic noodles and roasted crabs are to die for here but it's pretty pricey. What kind of place charge $5 for a refill for each glass of soda? I think it was actually more but it was ridicules. I mean we needed the soda to wash down the grease. There's alot of other places in the city that serves crabs that are just as good for alot cheaper.
author: A. C.

description: I was taken here for my birthday one year so I have fond memories.  We had the crab, prawns and garlic noodles.  Everything was really good.  I generally don't get crab because I don't like working to get to my food like an animal but the crab here was worth it.
author: Seong P.

description: After the much hype, I went the Crustacean. I love roasted crab. The decor seemed a bit dated and cheesy to me. The food was delicious, however, I was already smitten with the orignal and parent restaurant Thanh Long. It was there that I fell in love with the menu (the garlic noodles, roasted crab, tiger prawns!), service and ambiance. If you want it all, go to Thanh Long in the Outer Sunset rather than its sibling on Polk Street.
author: Judy L.

description: Good place for a date. But I would rather go to PPQ Dungeness Island...  on Clement street.
author: Amlan S.

description: Holy expensive. The service here was really lacking but the food was definitely savory. The location is not wonderful since finding parking/surviving can be tough in the 'loin. I would consider taking an SF visitor here since we are famous for crab, but otherwise I wouldn't bother really
author: Sven S.

description: It was a while ago that I was here.  All I remember was the pinot blanc that I had it complimented our dinner quite well.  As for the food it was ok but I still got love for PPQ and its way cheaper.
author: Allison T.

description:
I love crab, I love freshly cooked Dungeness crab!  I got bored of the traditional way of steaming or boiling my crab.  So, I was more than ready for Crustacean when one of my friends suggested we should go.   I like the ambience of the restaurant.  The interior is narrow and winding but the lighting is comfortable.  The big French windows allow customers to admire the street view, the high ceiling allows the multi-levels seating to share the view even you are not sitting close to the French window.    We were seated fairly close to other tables but I do not feel crowded, just cozy.  The waiting staff are all male, friendly and polite.  We ordered a starter, but I don't remember how it taste now I just remember it's tuna.  I am still lost in the wonderful taste bud challenging garlic and pepper flavour of the Roast crab and the garlic noodles!  Even the tamarind sauce with crab are good but I am so partial to the roast crab I think I could possibly finish the whole thing all by myself.... just give me ample time!  I give 4 stars because I found the yummy garlic noodles has too much MSG than my body would like it and I was left thirsty the whole night having to drink lots of water.   Having said that, I have already planned a revisit for my birthday celebration in January :)

One more thing, they might want to see you dressing up and then get messy, but they provide a bib for you and fragranced towel to get rid of the greasiness of your fingers.  Ideally, I'd prefer a bowl of lemon tea to wash my hands in, then hot hot towel.  Still, those towels were quite efficient for us coz we did not feel the need to rush away to wash our hands!
author: Bella A.

description: Way overrated, smell of raw shellfish is noticed as soon as you walk in, waiting takes forever even if you have a reservation, our waiter was nice but his helper was an asshole, I was seated by a door with a draft, food was good but not all that for the price. Need I say more?
author: Chantie G.

description: I had a whole crab on Saturday.. I can still taste the crab, peppers and butter all over my fingers. The garlic noodles are awesome. Going with a group of friends and chatting while wearing a bib and being a total neanderthal is the best.
author: Justin L.

description:
Well, Crustacean in my opinion is a more formal version of Thanh Long. And I'm a fan of Thanh Long. So that's a good thing, if your in the mood for some Thanh Long food but your not in that part of town and you maybe want a more formal setting, this is gonna be your best bet. Its on the third floor of a shopping center and very nice on the inside. It is perfectly lit and decorated in a contemporary-asian kinda way. The service is awesome. The wait staff is very knowledgeable and on top of their stuff. The Valet, which I used to park my car cost 10 bucks and well worth the headache of trying to find a downtown parking spot in the rain at night. Remember, if your looking to dress up and eat good food in a cool setting- Crustacean, if your looking for the same thing but not in the mood for Downtown and dressin up, Thanh Long. 

I ordered the Calamari appetizer, which was fryed with onions and bell peppers and seasoned with what may have been lemon pepper. The Calamari itself was a little chewy, but still damn good, Then, of course we ordered the roasted crab and garlic noodles. And of course, they were excellent. As the four star rating goes, "Yay! I'm a fan." I wish I could come here more often, if it were cheaper I would. But its not so I cant. Just a heads up for all you that have never been to either restaurant, if you take a date and both of you both order the crab and garlic noodles your looking at a 100 dollar dinner. Just FYI for all you normal Joe's out there like myself. So do the math and add on a glass of wine for the two of you or an appetizer, and you've got yourself a dinner that you better remember for a while! But, if its in your budget or your down to splurge (DTS) then slap on that Kirkland Signature Button-up Shirt you bought at Costco and your Alfani dress shoes and make it a memorable evening.  Be sure to call and ask about their dress code before you go, because they do have one, and you dont want to be that guy.  Big Daddy Jeff- Over and out.
author: Jeff O.

description:
I went there to try the Dine About Town menu.  It seemed like everyone around us were eating the roasted crab which is not part of the DAT. 
It took a long time to get our entree and when it arrived it was lukewarm.  The only hot item was the side order of garlic rice.  I thought they had a no jean dress code but a man sitting next to us was wearing jeans.
I hope they have better service next time if and when I order roasted crab.  It seems like you need to order the more expensive entrees to get better service and hot food.
author: bisou m.

description: We had their famous roasted garlic crab and garlic noodles.  Loved them!  There was no sharing among us, each of us had our own crab, yet  we wish the crab were bigger.
author: Molly K.

description: Anyone who does not give Crustacean's 5 stars has not ordered the right thing or something is wrong with their tastebuds lol. My entire family drives from San Jose just for the roasted garlic crab (cracked) & garlic noodles. You must try the fried pineapple dessert with ice cream...to die for! The only downside is there is not enough restrooms, only one stall. You can valet in front for $20.
author: Sarah L.

description: SO BOMBdiGGity! I love it here not only because their awesome food and awesome CHEAP VALET PARKING... but the customer service topped my reservation with a cherry on top! Our waiter was super awesome and he was so well behaved, our servers were real polite too! Anyway, we had fried wonton, stuffed calamari and beef s_____ (something) and a Malibu Sunrise! So yummy. And guys, PLEASE get desert .... its so yummy! LoL
author: Marevie T.

description: I love love love this place. The Tiger Prawns over the garlic noodles is just delightful. I have dreams about that dish. The service is amazing. I do however prefer Thanh Long's but only because I don't always feel like getting dolled up to eat.
author: Ruby S.

description: Having an entire crab on your plate makes for a really fun dinner, but honestly, it's not hard to boil a crab and throw it on a plate. Now, apparently no meal's a meal without the garlic noodles at Crustacean...and I have to say, for $7 for a little bowl of spaghetti covered with garlic butter and Kraft parmesan, I'd rather skip the experience and get my dinner at Costco. The noodles were so waxy and artificial tasting, I could not have more than 2 bites without feeling queasy. Not to mention, the appetizers were so crudely made, I also might as well have picked them up from Costco's deli section. The experience was all so awful because my father was excited about coming here, and yet it was such a letdown and big expense for all my wasted food. And to think how they made us sit outside (despite our reservations) because I was wearing a "tee shirt material" DRESS that was therefore too casual for their "fancy" food.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Anti-crabmatic, I say. 

Or I could have gone with crabtastic.... hmmm. I'm going to stick to the former. Not that I didn't enjoy my meal at Crustacean, it's just that after building up the finger-lickin' crabalicious experience in my mind for a year, it just didn't live up to my expectation. Which is admittedly a little unfair. The bf did have the crab, and it WAS good, but I mean, you cook a crab and then drown it in butter, what do you expect? DO NOT ORDER THE CRAB if you're a diva, cause you gonna be there for a long while crackin away, and you are gonna have some crustaceaous fingernails after. I had the sea bass atop rich, cheesy mashed potaters, and again, you can't really go wrong there. Actually, my fish was cooked really well, and it was in a sesame sauce that was awesome with the spuds. Why did I rate this place three stars? I don't think the menu is unique, and the appetizers we had we could have eaten from a Chinese take away and would not have known the difference. Also, the ambiance was less than desirable. The internets tricked me!!!  I previewed online and it looked all nice and romantic, but inside it just felt faux. It's crowded an unromantic.  I wouldn't really recommend this place if you're looking for an upscale  dining experience or trying to impress a date. But if you're cravin' some crab and you don't mind shelling out the money for a big 'un, then check it out and let me know how it goes.
author: Lisa F.

description: Had lunch today with four of my friends to celebrate a birthday. I wonder when the last time was that the Ang family actually visited their restaurant. They should be embarrassed by how dirty the waiting area couch is. I would not sit on it, and a friend of mine made the comment that  Bart train seats was cleaner.  Once at the table, a friend had a fork which clearly had last nights meal still on the tine. The wall behind our table had old food stuck to it. This restaurant needs a revamping, and a good cleaning.  Now on to the food. Nothing special. We ordered 4 appetizers that were just so-so. For lunch we decided to eat family style and ordered a total of 5 plates. The crab was market cost, not sure what it was, but I do know that I have had just as good garlic crab at my sister-in-law's. The jumbo prawns were also market cost and there was only four on the plate. The garlic noodles were good, and to be honest the only item on the menu worth eating there. I guess dropping their dress code was a good idea, as it is not warranted for a place like this. Maybe back in the day this was the place to be, but not any longer. By the way lunch for 5 of us, with tip and tax came out to $272.00
author: Diane S.

description: I have to admit the food here is great. The roasted crab and garlic noodle is a must have. This restaurant is a bit over priced, but i would say its worth it.
author: Wilson L.

description:
Arriving at our reserved time for dinner, we were seated promptly.  It was 5:45pm, so the restaurant was maybe a quarter full.  Which meant attentive service, since the waitress and servers didn't have to split their time with other diners.

We started with the Mixed Greens, basically the "fancy" variety of salad-in-a-bag (or Kula Greens, as we call it on Maui), with candied walnuts, a few slices of orange, with an orange-ginger vinaigrette.  At $9.25, it seems overpriced to me (but everything in this restaurant does).

My wife ordered the roasted crab and I ordered the roasted salmon.  The roasted crab was as advertised, roasted to perfection in a garlic sauce.  As much as she tried, my wife couldn't finish it, even giving me a few bites of crab throughout the evening.  The roasted salmon was in a soy ginger sauce with sauteed corn and spinach.  The salmon was very delicious and cooked the way I like it, a little crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.  The soy ginger sauce complimented it well but there wasn't anything special about the accompanying corn and spinach.  We also both ordered a bowl of the garlic noodles.  I almost managed to eat my entire bowl but the garlic finally got to me and I couldn't eat another bite.  Very delicious but we should have just shared a single bowl.

We were too full for dessert so we called it a night.  We had received a gift certificate as a gift, so the meal was almost free for us.  As much as the meal was delicious, I don't think we would have dined there without the gift certificate, as it would be out of our usual price range.

As others have said, the building complex the restaurant is in, isn't very attractive but the inside of the restaurant makes you forget what's outside.  There's also an elevator that brings you into the restaurant if you don't want to walk up the stairs.
author: David H.

description:
the best greasy but satisfying crab in town!  it is expensive.  it is in a dilapidated mall.  but an interesting mall of crackhead trannys that are actually helpful.  i think this is why they have a dress code as  i've been here in jeans and have never been thrown out.  as long as you don't dress like a crackhead, you are fine.  they may as well just say no crackhead attire.

despite the negatives, if you are hungry and want a huge dungeness crab, this is the place.  what sets them apart from other crab places is that the flavor actually infuses even the inside of the crab.  a good place to send austrians too as they wont find this in vienna!  

our party of 6 was entertained by the accomodating bartender who learned a new drink from our crew.  the aviator:  maraschino liqueur, gin (or absolut citron), and fresh squeezed lemon juice.   there may have been something else but we got too plastered to remember.  

everyone is given bibs and hot towels as you will make a mess of yourself with grease flying everywhere.  i wouldnt bother with the rest of the menu -seems over-priced.  i would just go for the roast crab which is mystery-priced i guess according to season.  sop the whole thing up with the garlic rice or garlic noodles.  nothing needs seasoning -everything tastes just right.  

at the end of the meal someone ordered something that came with vanilla ice cream.  it was good enough for them to ask the waiter what ice cream they use as it had real vanilla bean in it instead of the standard grocery vanilla flavoring most places use.  they said they use bud's ice cream (which says its from here but is manufactured in bangkok!  ha!  whatever, good on them for using real vanilla beans)

fun place for once in awhile.  definately a good place for crab with flavor!  oh and the sister restaurant thanh long out on judah has the same thing, may probably be cheaper, and would be a good alternative.
author: X X.

description:
I've been going to Cruestacean and Thang Long since the the early 90's.  Even got my daughters hooked on them.  However, I havent eaten there for about 6-7 months and I must say I was a bit disappointed.  My favorite appetizers were just OK -the  beef, grilled calamari, crispy rice paper rolls and the salt & pepper calamari.  Normally, I want more but last nite...took the remaining home.  I got the Prawns and my girls got the Roasted crab.  My prawns were grilled a bit too much. I had a bit of the charocal burnt taste as I ate them. And one of the the Crabs we had, WASNT CLEANED WELL!!!!!!!!!!  It had so much green poop!!!! It was just awful.  And u know the waitress was speaking to me as if I did not know what I was talking about.  TAKE IT BACK!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  
And what happened to the service.  The bowls placed on the table for the the shells of the crab and prawns are quickly removed and replaced once they appear to be getting full. Well,  not last nite. I had to ask if this had been changed.   Maybe my expectations are bit a high based on my prior experiences and the price I pay....I just wont be back for a while!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: pamela t.

description:
Jesus Harry Christ!  If food was a sexual position....well...(fill in your favorite Kama Sutra # here) Crustacean would be # 92 for me.  Noobies, look it up.  
For like 10 years straight I have spent every birthday bathing in garlic noodles, rolling in the remnants of garlic crab in my hair and my frickin' taste buds in utter ecstasy, dancing all night like raved out 20 somethings with the thigh high fur boots, shirtless, and full of all the dopamine produced from any near by Rave in that district of SF.  I jam in more crab puffs, finish it off with amazing fresh organic greens and a slice of a tart that has the largest seasonal berries this native Californian has ever laid eyes on.  The only thing heavier than the load of the bill was the sheer mass of my ass! I needed a wheel barrel to drag me the hell outa there! Thank God for Taxis.  Damn, I have to wait for next year to allow that level of gluttony again into my life...need patience.. endurance.  can fight the cravings!
author: Mr. M.

description: I was extremely disappointed this past Saturday. I have been coming to Crustacean's for special occasion's  for  several years now & this past Saturday we went for my cousins birthday. While we were seating very quickly , the service deteriorated after that. We were a large party 14 people , so the tip is automatically placed at 16% on our bill. We saw our waitress very infrequently, we had to ask the bus boy to refill our drinks, when our food did finally arrive several meals were ice cold &  the garlic noodles were disgusting . We had water poured on our table, as well as a pitcher poured on the backs of 2 people in our party. We were still trying to have a good celebration at this point. We asked to speak to a manager to inform him of all of the issues that we were having , to let him know that he should improve his customer service. The manager that arrive came over with a VERY condescending tone, not asking how may I help you, BUT what do you want. We were thrown off by his approach & tried to inform him off all of the things that we had gone through so far & his approach was what do you want me to do about it.  He stated he would go find out what was going on, and never came back ( he did remove 1 of the 3 shrimp fried rice's that were cold , BUT not any of the other food, nor did he bother to even ask what else was cold). After that no one really wanted to finish the food that they had & we were just ready to go , asking for the bill ( from the busboy) . While waiting the busboy brought over towels to clean our hands etc , & about 15 minutes later the waitress arrived with the same towels, she really was not paying attention to our table. When the bill finally arrived I stated to the busboy that he should receive the tip ($100.00 plus) since he was the one that serviced  our table. I would not recommend going here at all !!!!! We could have spent our $700.00 else wheres & will do so in the future !!!
author: Sham P.

description:
One word sums up this restaurant.... overpriced.

I used to have a buddy that had an uncle who cooked over at this place and it was the only reason we'd ever eat the food because it was free.  Otherwise, I think you'd have to be bit on the nutsy side to want to pay the prices they're asking for.
author: Hung T.

description: Tried Crustacean for the first time last night.  It was amazing.  Everything was perfect from drinks to dessert. The pesto mussels were delish, fried bananas soo good and like all the other reviews state, the roasted grab and garlic noodles are bomb! The prices are a little steep but totally worth it for a good celebration!
author: Kat R.

description:
you only need to familiarize yourself with two items on the menu:


ROAST CRAB

GARLIC NOODLES


enough said...
author: Leon C.

description: I frequent this restaurant once a year, for the last 6-7 years now. But this year, and on Lunar New Year, I'm sorry that I have to write what has been bothering me each time I call and first step into this place. First though, I would like to say that the food is good, especially the crab and garlic noodles. However, the person who answers the phone is terribly snotty and unprofessional. And sometimes, the person at the front is the same as well. For a place that has a "dress code" one would think that the service could be a little better.
author: quynh n.

description: Wow, I'm shocked from reading all these bad reviews.  I always have a fab time at Crustacean's. I love there roasted garlic crab and garlic noodles!!!:-)
author: Teresa H.

description: Okay I've been to Crustacean's a few times but this conversation was weird after I made and confirmed the date and time of my reservations the receptionist asked me if I knew about the dressed code?  I said "Dress Code" - I've been there before and no one every mentioned that, well she said that we can't wear t-shirts and men have to wear their pants properly.  What the hell is properly????  Any ways, the roasted crab was still good but not as good as it could be and the garlic noodles was still to die for!  I deducted the one star because of my weird conversation with the receptionist and because our waitress was really slow....
author: May A.

description: Worst experience I've ever had at a restaurant.  The food and our waitress were fantastic, but the manager went out of his way to make the experience miserable.  He harassed us and his friends came in before closing and he bragged loudly to them about how he can't imagine how people would pay so much for crab, and how he enjoys kicking people out of the restaurant.  WTF?  I make plenty of money to afford their crab, I don't need to put up with this.  I will never go back, though I'd love to find another place with crab that good.
author: S D.

description: I love the garlic crab and garlic noodles! My only issue is it's hard to get a decent same day reservation so you must plan ahead. Other than that we always order the same thing and leave satisfied!
author: Dawn B.

description:
Crustacean is one of those places that you go to with high expectations, get turned off by the decor and atmosphere, sit pensively as you are greeted by the staff and don't quite know wtf to expect, get excited by the prospect of the food (crab, crab, crab), and leave wishing you had brought the club kar to motor you back to your pad.
As you walk into the dimply lit place and proceed up the stairs, there is a foul smell and you can't help but notice the filthy carpet, long stained and in need of....any other surface. Getting inside things improve, albeit remotely, as you are escorted to your table by a doting staff. Skip to the food 'cause I think that I painted the picture for you...
When you go to crustacean, you have to have the garlic broiled crab and garlic noodles. You get swaddled in bib&gloves as you are served a whole dungeness crab that is cooked to perfection. You will eat it all... The garlic noodles are another dish, like KC Masterpiece potato chips on Super Bowl Sunday (sorry, I'm not a Neck-car fan) , you will not be able to stop eating.
This restaurant is indeed an experience. The food is pretty good, not the place to impress someone with your gastronomic IQ, more like a place to go with friends who are not food snobs, but just want to have a good time. 
When you're done, walk it off to the downtown and have a great 'tail someplace snobby, like.....you know
author: George M.

description:
This is a cool place.  I think the set up is well done for such an oddly shaped restaurant.  I like the tiers of tables that allow for views of all the patrons.  This place seems to have a draw.  Everyone is eating crab and noodles.
I found the food to be pretty average in general.  Nothing I haven't had before.  Seafood soup was sweeter that expected, no spice whatsoever.  The salmon carpaccio was good but oily and served with buttered toast.
The entrees- Crab, of course, and prawns w/ garlic noodles were good sized and tasty, but over salted, peppered and no citrus at all.  The service was too stiff at times, unknowledgeable about wine changes and sold out items.  The waitress was good, just too corporate...yes sir...no sir.  I never got to know her or her personality which is what I like.  
The bussers and foodrunners were great, very friendly, helpful, and conversational.
I look for a little more at restaurants that charge 60-75 dollars per person.
Probably won't go back, but good for one time.
author: sadao n.

description: Probably my favorite restaurant of all time. We have eaten at this location many times and have even been to the Beverly Hills a couple times as well. Service is always superb. Best of all Crustacean's garlic crab and garlic noodle is like no other. An absolute MUST TRY for crab lovers!
author: Veena C.

description: We stopped here on our way home from the beach and thought it was good- their infamous garlic noodles were really tasty as well as their crab cakes.
author: KareBear x.

description: From the time i step foot in northern california, I'd heard mad reviews about this place, "that's its fingure licking good" so good you'll wanna "slap yo mamma" Okay folks here's my opinion the food: is highly over rated. The appetizers- dont waste your money on them, except the soup that was listed on the bottom of the menu flavorful. I ordered the signature roasted crab and garlic noodles, to say the least, most food that are drenched with oil and garlic tastes good. but i think my arteries were screaming that night. that's all it is is the crab seasoned wtih garlic and pepper with maybe some light olive oil, not sure the oil. The service from my experience was absolutley wonderful. the food so-so for the price.
author: Dorcas S.

description:
This place is my favorite favorite restaurant to go for The Best Crab!!! I mean the Best!!!! The same owners have Thanh Long same menu too. I  go back and forth from SF to New York but I'm a fan of CRAB YUM!!!!! There is no place like this !!! I send clients to dine here they all have fallen in Love with this place! 
The Pan Roasted Crab with Garlic and the Special butter sauce is unlike no other on this Planet!!!!! I really mean that. Huge Garlic Prawns with the Garlic noodles to die for as well. If your a huge foodie and absolutely love crab 
prepare to have the Best Meal you'll ever have here!!!!
P.S. Don't forget to try the Pesto Mussels great app!!!!
author: Sera h.

description: roasted crab is good...and buttery garlic noodles are excellent.....appetizers are bit overpriced and small...but most have been satisfying..turn cellphone ringers off...and keep the conversations low......the atmosphere tries to be overly sophisticated..(beverly hills crustacean...little more toned down and casual)......
author: Hen A.

description: Garlic Crab is pretty good, but the Garlic Noodles are so yummy... Kinda messy but it's ALL GOOD...remember that parking is valet cause its hard to find parking in the neighborhood.
author: Rachelle C.

description: Garlic noodles and roasted crab were delish! Very attentive service too. Will definitely come back!
author: Maria K.

description: The butterflied prawns on top of a bed of their famous garlic noodles is definitely one of a kind. A little over priced for what it is. I suggested going to their sister restaurant, Thanh Long. Same food cheaper prices.
author: Marco M.

description: This place is only getting 2 stars cause their food is so damn good.  They might have the worst service in san francisco (okay i am sure that there are places with worse service, but not that i have been to yet)...  anyways, i have given this place a half dozen tries and all i can say is try to get there for an early dinner because the service only gets worse the later that you are there.  Enough griping.  Their garlic noodles are one of my favorite things at any restaurant.  If you are in the mood, splurge for one of their whole roasted (or butter poached!) crabs, they are amazing.  I think that my overall favorite dish is the grilled tiger prawns, they are tasty by themselves, but they also come with a heaping portion of garlic noodles....  anyways, i highly recommend the food, but just don't expect stellar service.
author: Robert R.

description: Garlic Noodles and Roast Crab are a must have if you've never been here but I also had  ( I think it was called Shaken Beef) this beef dish with carmalized onions and green beans and tomato on the side... SOOOO good... And the environment is very Buddhist/Asian themed. Beautiful place for a birthday or any special occasion.  The velvet on the chairs are in need of cleaning though. I suggest you pay the extra 5 dollars for them to crack your crab for you because it can get really messy and can take a long time to get all that meat out of it's shell.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I have nothing but good things to say about this place, and I don't even get the crab. The dining environment is very pleasant and I've seen a pro athlete every time I've been there. It's definitely a place that I can't eat at every few weeks because of the prices, but it's a great place for a celebration dinner.

I always get the Saigon beef. I recently tried the calamari and it was honestly the best I've ever had. I agree that the garlic noodles are overrated and I didn't get why that was their popular dish. It tastes like something I could buy frozen and prepare myself. The desserts are amazing and I recommend the Baked Alaska. All in all, a great dining experience.
author: Cai L.

description: A bit overpriced but a good place to try once, if not for the food then at least for the neon crab elevator.  I heard rave reviews about the garlic noodles so I felt compelled to order them.  They are nothing special and I would never order them again.  The beef carpaccio is awesome, though.
author: Mahogany G.

description: Amazing garlic roasted crab and garlic noodles....yum yum yum!
author: Yan M.

description:
went there a couple of nights ago for their crab.. delicious!! i started with the asian bouillibase. the broth was light, and i loved how there were simple veggies and pineapple and sea bass inside.. i also ordered the veggies, garlic noodles, and the tamarind dungeness crab.. :) crab was nicely seasoned, and the sauce went excellent with the garlic noodles. 

we didn't order any dessert as the  appetizer, veggies, noodles and crab were quite filling. 
 
only complaint was our server for the night. she didn't seem at all interested in her job. she only came by to check on our table once or twice during our dinner.


will definetly visit again if i'm in the SF area.
author: S l.

description: I love the garlic butter crab...never had anything like it.  The garlic noodles are also out of this world!  Pricey and crowded.  Service at this place is alright, never had a terrible experience but you do have to wait for your food a bit long.
author: Joy R.

description: I suggested this place to my gf since she was craving some fine dining. Much to our disappoint, it is located at the top of a run down mall... I thought I was going to a 9.99 buffet. To start off, the maitre'ds think they are running Gary Dankos or work for Bobby Flay. They have a no t-shirt no sweatshirt dresscode, but messy kids, cargo pants and Thank You bag bibs are allowed. They don't know a bottle of coke from wine. I ordered the frozen roasted crab, which they should note "frozen", instead of "Quoted Price". What a disappointment. Peel after peel, crap after crap... I usually don't mind paying a gouging price for kickass food, but I felt like kicking the maitre'ds ass for not letting me walk first through the hall.
author: Wil M.

description: Good food the Crab is fantastic with the garlic noodles YUM!! The only issue is I didn't like the way the entranced smelled . A bit of a turn off for a pricey restauraunt.
author: michelle r.

description: WOW if you want to burp garlic for like a week this is the place to go!!!! but its so worth the garlic breath...I literally had to unzip by pant cause I ate sooo much food i had the garlic rice, garlic rice and the big crab..and my date had the tiger prawns. the decor is ugly but the food is soo good my man took me there for my birthday and it was soooo good i cant wait to go again. It was worth every penny! the staff is also very nice we asked for wipes because our hands got messy from the crab.
author: alessandra t.

description: Yum.  The garlic noodles....I would go back just for them.  They were SO tasty.  The crab was juicy and flavorful.  We also had the shaking beef which was tender and not overwhelmed by the soy and sugar flavors.  The service was attentive and effective.  I would have like to sample their wine selection but we opted for Sake instead, which went very well with the shellfish.  The food was worth a second trip!
author: Amy H.

description: I've been to the one in Vegas and in San Francisco. To call the food average would be an unjustified compliment. I don't mind spending a lot on a good meal, but you can get better Asian food for a lot less money just about anywhere else in the City. This is one of those places people eat at just so they can say they have been. Avoid.
author: Don H.

description: For the price, I was not impressed.  I spent $65, even after splitting a crab entree with my friend.  The crab was tasty, but was unnecessarily covered completely in butter, even the shell!  My husband and I make better crab at home.  I won't be coming back here.
author: Jaclyn M.

description: I've been wanting to visit this place for years hoping that one day I would come here on a date.  Well, that never happened and I didn't feel like waiting so Hooray for Crustaceans being one of the participating restaurants for Dine about Town.  Since I've already tried the amazing Roast Garlic Crab and Garlic Noodles at their sister restaurant, Thanh Long, I opted to order off the Dine about Town menu.  My friend and I started off with the Skewered Chicken and Rice Paper Shrimp Rolls.  For my entree, I had the Shaken Beef and my friend had the Grilled Shrimp over Garlic Noodles. For dessert, we both had the Fried Bananas with Vanilla Ice Cream.  For $34.95, the three course meal with generous portions was definitely worth it.  I highly recommend the Skewered Chicken, Shaken Beef, and Fried Bananas.  The atmosphere of the restaurant was really nice, the service was terrific, parking was easy, and I even got to sit next to some NBA players!
author: Janet P.

description: I was taken here for my Bday. The price was reasonable but it would be a lot cheaper trying to make it at home. The cost for their famous roasted crab and garlic noodles comes out about $60. I gotta say you can't eat this stuff everyday due to the high butter content involved. Eating this stuff on special ocassions is great however. If I was to compare this SF location to their Beverly Hills location, I would have to say the environment/ambiance in Beverly Hills definitely feels much more luxurious especially seeing sports stars and movie stars come in and out of the restaurant.
author: Mike L.

description: I've only had the garlic butter crab and will only ever get the garlic butter crab.  very tasty.  Lots of japanese people come here for the goods.  it must be in some guide book or something.
author: mark l.

description: Crustacean is heaven in a shell. Don't worry about reading the menu, there are only 2 entrees worth ordering - Roasted Crab or the Tiger Prawns.  Everything else you can get other places for a much better price.  Some stand out appetizers are: Shrimp Toast, Coconut Prawns, Vietnamese Salad.  Cocktails are stupendous. try the lemon drop!  a little pricey so this is a special occasion destination for most.  rember there is a dress code for both men and women... just be ready to get down & dirty.  PS...don't forget the garlic noodles
author: jim a.

description: I love going here for their tamarind crab, garlic noodle, and their huge wine selection.  Friendly service and great ambiance.
author: Hang L.

description: Pricey for the overall experience. The best part of our evening was during the initial wine pour and appetizers. The garlic noodles are a must if you end up here, but the crabs? Well... they are frozen, and I've had better crabs at home. It's almost better if you just go and focus on other items on the menu, and save yourself the semi-disappointment that comes at a $40/crab cost.
author: Pete L.

description: Very upscale, seating not the best, small tables,cramped space. Best garlic crab ever!!!!
author: Anon A.

description:
I went to Crustacean last night for the first time in many years (several). I remember I was a huge fan before, and while last night's meal was savory, I'm glad my palate has become more educated because it's not nearly the best food in the City, in my opinion. Here's why.
To begin with, the place is getting really run down. I find it tacky that they insist on their dress code when the place is old by anyone's standards, and their patio room is like a tent with its canopy roof. I also think putting tables in the hallway where people are walking through all night is also not very elegant. I was pretty shocked when I arrived to see a nearly totally empty restaurant. We were actually told to wait a few minutes or (conveniently enough) go to the bar area to wait, where we could and did buy a drink while waited for them to um...uh...prepare one of the hundred empty tables I guess. Anyway, we were promptly seated once they saw that we bought a drink. The only other diners in the room above the bar happened to be a table of a dozen LOUD Asian guys revelling in their crab...not ideal but I did ask to be seated in the restaurant and not the tent.
For dinner we started with the Salt and Pepper Calamari, per the recommendation of our friendly waiter. Nicely done. Not greasy and pretty tasty. For the main course we shared a roasted crab and the king prawn garlic noodles, seemingly what everyone goes here for. The crab was definitely good, but totally messy. I guess that can be expected when you are cracking and eating your own crab, but with all the butter it is soaked in it became quite a mess. I ended up eating the prawns from the other dish with my hands too since they were already covered with buttery slime, so in a medieval kind of way I was satisfied because it was very sublime tasting. Crab was buttery and good. Prawns were nicely grilled and buttery also. Garlic noodles, as other Yelpers have said, were not overly garlicky and were downright delicious. 
Because I just spent a weekend in Vegas staying at Wynn's Encore and dining in nice places I'm a little biased, so I think I'm being generous in giving Crustacean 4 stars. I would give 3 for the reasons above (mainly the place is run down and they shouldn't expect you to treat it like a nice steak house accordingly with steak house prices), but because the food is good and the waiter was friendly I'm giving it 4 stars...barely.
author: Matt H.

description:
Having had crab @ Alioto's in SF just a few days ago, the first comment i have is the comparison between Alioto's crab and Crustacean's.  Crustacean was much much better.  The crab I had @ Crustacean tonight was a lot bigger and much more flavorful.  I also liked the way Crustacean served the crab -- nicely laid out with its shell on a platter rather than Alioto's cracked legs in a bowl.  

I had the whole crab by myself and ordered Crustacean's famous garlic noodles.  From what I can remember, Thanh Long's garlic noodles seemed to have tasted better -- a bit thicker and less oily.  But the combination of the roasted crab and garlic noodles was very palatable!  My overall experience @ Crustacean was more enjoyable than @ Alioto's but not as great compared to Thanh Long.  With  dinner, I also had some garden vegetables -- carrots, cauliflower, water chestnuts, red peppers, soy beans and squash, tofu and shitake prepared with a sweet/lemony sauce.  Dinner for two was about $140 and that was without drinks.
author: Mika S.

description: Dude, you must experience the magic that is Crustacean. My sister and I save up to come here. It's always worth it, everything from the service on down to the atmosphere is impeccable. Anybody who's been there will tell you...it's a stone winner.
author: Amber P.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE  I was introduced to this restaurant 8 years ago (I started out at it's sister location)  and I have been back every year from Chicago to enjoy it's crab.  There is nothing like it in the Windy City .  The roasted crab is soo good i usually end up mixing my rice with what ever is left on the plate to absorb all the flavors.  Bypass the rest of the menu and go stright for the Crab and Garlic Noodles. Im not shy, even in a fine restaurant like this I found my self licking the sauce from my fingeres! Service is always attentive and excellent, I was on the fence about a Reisling they served so the wine was complimetary.  Don't pass up on the dessert!
author: shirley m.

description:
We love this place! We would make pilgramages here when the memory of garlic crab and noodles had to be relived. What a feast! Before indulging, you must literally roll your sleeves up past the elbows and remove all jewelry on the hands and wrists. Hair should be away from the face. This will allow you to use both hands to break open the crab as butter runs down your arms. Orgasmic! Like vampires drinking blood.
I don't bother to comment on the pricing or ambiance, because the food was always worth whatever we paid and we rarely bothered to look up.
author: Catherine P.

description: Being Vietnamese and having a mom thats a great cook...or a cook that a great mom....makes u think twice when paying for vietnamese food,,,,,especially paying for expensive vietnamese food.....but oddly enough this place gets 4 from me.....the service was always good when i went and the food was good...to be honest my opinion may be limited due to the fact that i really only remember the garlic noodles and the crab,,,,,so good you wont forget it tho,......
author: dates w.

description:
Yum yum...................-NOT-!!!!!

We went to Crustacean for dinner last night, treating my good friend from out-of-town to what we had hoped to be a great dinner of crab and other delectable Asian-inspired seafood dishes.  We were sorely disappointed.  The first red flag was how quickly the food came out.  All of the dishes we ordered (including the roasted crab that was noted on the menu that it "may take longer to prepare") were on our table in five minutes after placing the order.  Literally.  My husband ordered, went to the bathroom (to do a number one), and came back to find food on the table (!!!).  We were all surprised, but decided to give the food a try.  Here's a rundown:

1. The crispy fried rice paper rolls were pretty good.  The outside crispy part had a nice texture and made the overall roll unique compared to the typical imperial spring roll you order at Vietnamese pho restaurants.  
2. The roast crab was fine, but didn't taste like it was cooked-to-order.  
3. The calamari special was good, but the order was small and there weren't nearly enough tentacles (tentacles are so much more tasty and interesting to eat).  
4. Our final dish was the "catch of the day", which I think should have been called the "release of the day".  The fish was bland, nondescript looking and overcooked, and the hyped, "secret recipe" garlic noodles were much more buttery than garlicky ("greasy" was how other Yelpers have described them).  The presentation of the dish was also sloppy.
5. My husband's drink didn't arrive until quite a bit later.  They said that the bar was backed up, which was fine, as the area was crowded.  The martini drinks were expensive and small.  

The quality, presentation and speed that the food arrived gave us the distinct impression that we were eating at a cafeteria.  The overall service was passable, but felt forced, artificial and aloof.  Finally, the cost is very high for the meal and experience.  We didn't even stay for dessert because we were so disappointed.  Come if you want to try it out for the first time and/or love crab, but you would do yourself much justice by visiting Thanh Long (in the outer Sunset) instead or another fine restaurant in SF, rather than this tourist trap.
author: Supak C.

description: This place is waaaaay over-rated.  I'll admit their crab was pretty good, but everything else was just ok.  The reason I'm giving them a two star review is not because of their food, but because of the experience we had there.  We strolled in dressed casually because we came here on a whim and didn't plan on having a fancy dinner.  I wasn't aware that there was a "dress code" they enforce here.  I had a t-shirt on and was holding a long sleeve sweater.  The host told me we would be ok as long as I put on my sweater.  I sucked it up and went ahead and put my sweater on.  Someone explain to my why we were seated next to a table where this guy obviously brought these two cheap looking hookers that were wearing skimpy hooker clothes and reeked of STDs.  And the host had the nerve to tell me to put my sweater on?
author: Mike L.

description:
this place is awesome!!! ROASTED CRAB is a MUST!! ..probably the meatiest and buttery-est crab i've ever had!! Also, the CALAMARI we had for appetizer was ON POINTT!! .. The PRICES are definitely NO JOKE, i dropped 2 bills that night.. but it's San Francisco on VALENTINE'S DAY..so it was definitely memorable.. 

the only flaw was the mixed drink i ordered.. it was $6.25 and definitely too strong, i mean..i'm not complaining about the extra alcohol, but it just didnt taste right.. that's it.

Overall, a MUST-GO (at least once in your lifetime)  ..Enjoy!
author: Jeff G.

description: Garlic noodles and crab.  I first thought what a weird combination, but I had to give the SF location a try.  The LA location I heard was actaully better than SF, but either way I am definitely not impressed with this restaurant.  Since I am fat I had to get the noodles, crab, and some other fish dish.  The fish dish was so good I dont even remember what kind of dish I ordered.  I just remembered it as a block of fried fish with some sauce on top.  Not impressive.  The crab I dont remember being spectatular.  I just remembered the crab with wine or something was not good.  Even a fatty like me wouldnt eat it.  This is a great place for group dining if you are willing to spend the money.  I will not be visiting this location again.  Tip: Go in with low expectations and come out happy!
author: Fatty A.

description: Visited again last week.  Dirty Goose Martini set the tone.  Anchor Steam, roasted crab and garlic noodles...perfect.
author: Chris P.

description: yum - yum! Well after reading all the bad reviews, I was a bit worried. We LOVE crustacean LV though so we decided to go anyway. We got the dineaboutsf prix fixe and it was great. the service was A+... we were late and they still held our reservation. I LOVE the lychee martinis. we got the tuna sashimi app and i got the shrimp roll things & hubby got chicken satay. we both got the shaken beef and the fried banana was soooo BADDDDD (in a good way) we will both have to do extra mileage at the gym tomorrow for that one! only down fall was that the restaurant was cold (they sat us next to the window)
author: Pamela M.

description: This place is bomb diggity and I must say if I were rolling in the dough, I would eat here almost everyday.  It's pricey, yes, but the price is outweighed by the delishishness that comes from the kitchen.  I had the calamari appetizer and it was scrump, howeveer the Calamari main dish leaves something do be desired.  But my favorite dish by far there has to be the crab cakes, two thumbs up.  We sat out on the deck when it was raining and it was really chill. Come visit if you really love seafood.
author: Marie B.

description: The garlic noodles and crab are pretty good, but I think PPQ and Yummy Yummy are better.
author: L C.

description: I felt gross just being inside this establishment.  Nothing felt clean, none of the staff really seemed to care about much, and my food was barely adequate at best.  I won't be going back here for anything.  Really odd location too.  It was really a let down because other humans had actually recommended the place to me and said it was superb.  Maybe they were good in the past or this was just a cruel joke or something.
author: Spidermonkey J.

description:
you guys know that movie with salma hayek and matthew perry (can't think of the name right now) where she brings him grey's papaya hot dogs?  i wish someone would be bring me crustacean's garlic noodles.  they are SOOOOOOOO good.  the seafood is average, but for me i would just come here for garlic noodles.  

ahh...yes, on a great san francisco day if i were you i would do a little walk down polk street.  ahi poke at yabbies, cup of chowder at swan oyster depot, topped off by garlic noodles at crustacean.
YUM!!
author: becky k.

description:
i have limited memory of this place since we came straight from happy hour at the harlot on empty stomachs.

all i remember is: crab, good.  noodles, yum.  and wearing a bib will make a drunk girl very very sad.

next time, i think i will try to enjoy my crab sober instead.
author: Rose J.

description: Let get real, those of you that barley get out must think this place is "bomb" The roasted crab taste alright... and especially not for that "$40" per a crab w/o distilled water nor the basic fundamental steam rice. $10 for Garlic Noodles, that's a reasonable price, but its just noodle!?!?!? Yall need to try Boiling Crab in San Jose a fraction of Crustacean price, and packed with a lot more of flavor. I would recommend this place to "upper class" folks w/no balls to explore the working class taste buds.
author: Jenny's N Quan's Adventure D.
